PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Chiropractic Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows -
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Cross,Mr Drummond,Mr Groom and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms,
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Mr Groom.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique inherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia, firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/ or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ''Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characterstics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation 's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian National flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth.
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a 'first strike' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
Your petitioners pray that Members and the House assembled will close Omega.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we object most strongly to the present Medicare system as it operates today, because despite being covered by both private insurance and Medicare, we are not fully covered and have to pay the excess portion of medical and hospital accounts.
We would request that immediate action be taken to have the excess portion reimbursed by our private insurance funds.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of concerned people of the Electorate of Indi respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Patersons Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Your Honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Patersons Curse
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Avalon Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the electors of the divisions of Corio and Corangamite respectfully showeth that the population of the Geelong Region is approximately 170,000 persons and yet Geelong does not have a true regional airport capable of receiving regularly scheduled commercial aircraft. It is our understanding that no other city in Australia having a population exceeding 12,000 persons is similarly disadvantaged.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that regularly scheduled commercial aircraft be permitted to use Avalon Airfield for the carriage of passengers and freight to and from the Geelong Region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Forrest respectfully showeth that the Australian Citizenship Act contains provision for the Oath of Allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth II Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors, and an Affirmation of Allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth II Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors: That the said Oath and Affirmation of Allegiance are supported by the overwhelming majority of Australians.

Your petitioners humbly pray that Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will ensure that the present Oath and Affirmation of Allegiance are retained; and would strongly oppose any attempt to remove all reference to God and the Queen from the Oath of Allegiance, and any attempt to remove all reference to the Queen from the Affirmation of Allegiance..
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL (No. 1) 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 April, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill, the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No.1) 1984, proposes amendments to the Companies Act 1981, to the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1980 and to the Securities Industry Act 1980. The Bill, as is characteristic of amendments which come to the package of legislation which we have come to call the 'securities industry package', contains some amendments of a highly technical nature and other amendments of a more broad character, including in this case amendments of a very broad character which relate to the operation of the stock exchanges throughout this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that under the scheme that has been set up on a co-operative basis between the States and the Commonwealth once a legislative package gets to these Houses it is virtually unamendable. The present package has been passed by the Senate and in general terms we support the Bill which is now before the House. That support is subject to one question or qualification which relates to the subject of time-sharing agreements. That is something which I will come to and explain in a little detail so that the responsible Minister-I thought the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) would be presenting the Government's response to the House-can explain to the House a problem which appears to arise out of the width of a definition given to time-sharing agreements.

It may be convenient, since I have raised the problem, rather than returning to it at a later stage, to go directly to it now. Even though the Deputy Prime Minister is not in the chamber I trust that his advisers are, that they will take a note of what I am going to say, that they will relay the note to him and that he will be able then to relay back to this House the note that he is given by them to pass back to the House. It is effectively a conduit pipe and I hope that the Deputy Prime Minister gets here to act as a conduit.

The question that arises is in relation to the desire of the Government to catch time-sharing agreements within the provisions of the legislation which relate to the offering of prescribed interests. As the Deputy Prime Minister said in his second reading speech to the House:

'Prescribed interests' is a wide net which catches most profit making schemes and investment schemes marketed to the public. Examples of other types of schemes which are or have been liable to be regulated in the same manner-
in the same manner as is now proposed in relation to time-sharing schemes-
include property trusts, franchises, various plantation schemes, horse-racing syndicates and retirement villages.
He went on to say:

The purpose of the proposed amendments to the definition of prescribed interest in both the Companies Act and the Securities Industry Act . . . is to ensure that all time-sharing schemes will continue to be regulated under the prescribed interest provisions, notwithstanding that in some cases the investment in question is structured by reference to rights attaching to shares in a corporation.

I do not think we need go again into the detail as to the technical reasons why the definition is needed. It is needed to overcome, in effect, doubts that have arisen as a result of a decision in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. It is of particular interest to the Government-this has been made clear by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in the Senate-that resort-sharing arrangements are brought within the time-sharing provisions. It is said in the explanatory memorandum at page 13 in dealing with this subject:
It is proposed that this approach-
that is, to catch what we are concerned with-

be adopted in respect of the promotion of interests in 'time-sharing' developments in which the use or ownership of property is divided amongst a number of people by reference to a specified period of time (typically, the use of holiday resort facilities for a number of weeks each year).

What is intended, therefore, is to enlarge the definition of prescribed interest in the companies and securities industries legislation. Therefore, that prescribed interest would include any right to participate in a time-sharing scheme. A time-sharing scheme is defined for that purpose as meaning:
. . . a scheme, undertaking or enterprise-

(a) participants in which are, or may become, entitled to use, occupy or possess, for two or more periods during the period for which the scheme, undertaking or enterprise is to operate, property to which the scheme, undertaking or enterprise relates; and
(b) that is to operate for a period of not less than three years; . . .

Therefore we have the two components in relation to the scheme, undertaking or enterprise. Firstly, the participants are, or may become, entitled to use or occupy certain premises for two or more periods during the period of the scheme. Secondly, the scheme, undertaking or enterprise is to operate for a period of not less than three years. The importance of that is that where a person wished to offer a prescribed interest for sale that person would need to look at the operation of section 169 of the Companies Act. That section provides:

A person, other than a company or an agent of a company authorised for that purpose under the common or official seal of the company, shall not issue to the public, offer to the public for subscription or purchase, or invite the public to subscribe for or purchase, any prescribed interest.
That is the prohibition. Secondly, section 170 of the Companies Act provides:

(1) A company or an agent of a company shall not issue to the public, offer to the public for subscription or purchase, or invite the public to subscribe for or purchase, any prescribed interest unless the issue, offer or invitation is by means of a statement in writing.

The section then goes on to describe that that shall be 'a prospectus issued by a company'. That then of course attracts the operation of conditions which require certain prescribed information to be furnished. The question has been raised by an organisation which calls itself the Australian Time Sharing Resort Council as to whether the proposed definition is too wide. At this point I mention that I am glad to see the Deputy Prime Minister in the House. It is always good to see him here.

This is a technical subject. It will take a little time for us to get through it. What the Time Sharing Resort Council has raised-I have no view about the business of the Council one way or another; indeed, I do not really know what it does but I understand that it is interested in time sharing operations-is whether the definition in the Bill is too wide and might apply, for example, to such matters as contracts for the use of public entertainment or sporting facilities. I instance a football ground used on Saturdays for three years or computer sharing contracts and other matters. That matter was raised very directly by Senator Durack in another place. As I said earlier, I raise the point at this stage so that when we get to the Committee stage the Deputy Prime Minister will be in a position to give an answer to this question as to the apparent width of the definition of time-sharing schemes. The Attorney-General said in the Senate on 3 April:

The more particular matter that Senator Durack raised concerned the effectiveness of the definition of time sharing to confine its operation to what it is manifestly intended to cover, and that is the marketing of time-sharing arrangements in the context essentially of resort accommodation, which is the area in which time-sharing schemes have become most familiar.

The Attorney-General said with his characteristic confidence that that is what the definition is intended to cover. The question obviously arises: Has the definition, in fact, achieved that or has it achieved something far wider? He went on to say:

The criticism is that the definition of time sharing has been expressed so broadly that it might inadvertently catch a variety of investment schemes or activities other than time-sharing activities strictly so called. This is something which the Government will have another look at, as Senator Durack invites us to do, in the period between this debate and that in the House of Representatives to ensure that we really have done the best we can so far as this definition is concerned.

One can assume only that that undertaking, having been given to the Senate, has been fulfilled, that Senator Evans has looked at this question further and that we will have a detailed response on the subject by the Deputy Prime Minister. So that he is not caught by surprise, let me also say that Senator Evans, again in the Senate on 3 April, reverting to the operation of the definition of time sharing, said:

The other more general point to make not only about that but also about all the other examples that are given-public entertainment, sporting facilities, computer sharing contracts, hotel or permanent accommodation agreements and so on-is that the difficulty about all of these things is that they ignore one of the central elements in the definition of prescribed interest in the parent Act, section 169 of the Australian Companies Code, which makes it clear that what we are talking about here are schemes which are offered to the public, and something which is in the nature of a scheme.

I think that Senator Evans has somewhat confused matters. The prescribed interest provisions define certain matters. Section 169 prohibits certain transactions. Senator Evans appears not to have understood that or somehow-and it is very difficult to see how-to have confused the two because, as I say, he said:
. . . the central elements in the definition of prescribed interest in the parent Act, section 169 . . .

The parent Act does not define prescribed interests. That is to say, section 169 has nothing to do with defining prescribed interests. It fixes on what may be done in relation to prescribed interests. I raise that question so that the Deputy Prime Minister will be able to respond. It would be perfectly ludicrous if a football field which was to be offered out on a time-sharing basis for a period of more than three years were to be caught by the width of the definition which was intended, as Senator Evans says-and he, after all, should know what was in the Government's mind-to attach to resort-sharing operations and perhaps to operations of an allied kind. I have taken some time on this question because it is most important when legislation of this kind is before the House that, in seeking to attach consequences to specific matters, the operation of the legislation does not go beyond what is intended and attach consequences to matters which it really did not intend to touch.

The amendments which have been introduced today also touch on a number of matters. As I have indicated, some are of a very technical nature, such as those made in relation to charges. Others have great significance for the Australian investment community. It is a great pity, therefore, that this legislation has been rushed through in the way in which it has. It was before the Senate last week. The Bill may have been available for a week or so before then. As far as I am aware, no exposure draft of the Bill has been presented to the Australian public so that interested parties could comment on it. That is particularly unfortunate because, in part of the Bill-the part which will have the most wide- ranging effect-we are dealing with amendments which will change the nature of the stockbroking industry in this country.

All honourable members will know that in our community the main way of raising funds for private investment is through the mechanism of the stock market. That is a characteristic of the capitalist system which allows people to pool money and for the pooled money to be used for general or specific investment purposes.

It is worth while going over briefly some of the history leading up to the amendments now before the House which affect stockbroking activities in this country. It started, I think, around 1974 when, after the introduction of the Trade Practices Act, the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges were put on notice that their practices in relation to the fixing of brokerage rates and restrictions of membership contravened the Trade Practices Act. Authorisation was then obtained for those practices. The introduction of the Act raised the issue of whether exchanges could restrict membership or fix charges. Of course, outside groups, especially merchant banks and overseas financiers, were anxious to open up the market. I think most people would agree that opening up the market usually works to the benefit of the consumer and to the community at large. Debate went on over a number of years. In 1975 preliminary discussions were held on the introduction of the national companies and securities scheme. At that time the broking industry perceived that under a national companies scheme it would be possible simultaneously to open up the market to competition.

In July 1981 a group of Australian merchant bankers brought mandamus proceedings against the Trade Practices Commission. These proceedings would force the Commission to exercise powers, claimed by the Australian merchant bankers to reside in the Commission, to examine the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges' rules and articles of association. That case was settled on the basis of undertakings given by the Commission and in July 1981 an examination began. Findings were issued by the Trade Practices Commission in September 1982. It refused authorisation for the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges' rules, but granted interim authorisation for 18 months to enable amendments to be made. On 6 March 1984 the Trade Practices Commission granted interim authorisation to new draft rules and articles of association for stock exchanges. These new draft rules are of great importance to all who believe that the stock exchange was too much of a closed shop, that it needed to be opened up and that there should be greater flexibility in the fixing of fees charged on transactions effected through an exchange.

In summary, the major changes made were, firstly, the allowance of 50 per cent outside ownership of broking firms, something which will assist broking firms in raising capital; secondly, incorporation of broking partnerships; thirdly, a freeing of restrictions on exchange membership to allow broking firms to trade on and be members of more than one exchange, that is, to be members of more than one of the six exchanges in Australia; fourthly, to allow outside non-broker directors to be directors of member corporations; and fifthly, the negotiation of rates for all transactions over $100,000. These changes came into effect from 1 April 1984. This does not mean to say that we do not need to do anything more or, perhaps more properly, that the broking community does not need to do anything more. When one is involved in any attempt to open up an industry, there is a great temptation to open up that industry by regulating it out of existence . It is always better for industries to propose means by which they will free up restrictive practices, rather than having government step in and do the work for them, with all the consequences in terms of restrictions, bureaucratic interference and general intervention that that process involves.

There are a number of outstanding matters, such as conflict of interest problems. When stockbroker firms are incorporated, there is of course potential for complaints that shareholders or directors may be treated differently from ordinary clients. The brokers propose, I understand, to put up a so-called Chinese wall around broking firms' operations so that non-broking personnel do not become privy to sensitive information. This kind of Chinese wall, if my recollection is correct, does occur in firms in the City of London when it is desired to keep certain transactions isolated from the general knowledge of all the personnel in a firm. It is possible to do that, but it does present obvious and real difficulties.

There is a question as to whether corporate members should pay higher entry fees than individual members, and that is yet to be decided. A question arises in respect of fidelity funds. Since the new rules enable a broker to be a member of more than one exchange, this immediately raises the question of whether the present approach in the legislation in relation to fidelity funds is apt. At present, fidelity fund regulations are premised on brokers being members of only one exchange, and each exchange has its own fidelity fund. Should we continue with the arrangement that each exchange should have its own fidelity fund? Should we have in place of that arrangement a fidelity fund for the whole of Australia? Or is there to be some compromise between those two alternatives?

There are, therefore, a number of major matters still in the air. In addition to the ones I have mentioned, I should touch as well on the question of the Foreign Investment Review Board regulation of membership of brokerage firms by financial institutions. In particular, of course, local and overseas organisations want to know at the inception of the scheme whether the Government will allow overseas participation. This is something on which the Government should have had a view before the amending legislation was introduced, because it is most important at the outset to be able to state clearly to the investing community what the rules and guidelines will be under this legislation.

Another matter which is in the air is the question of a decision as to what requirements and fees will be placed upon companies seeking to acquire membership of the exchange. There are other matters as well but, in summary, the move towards deregulation of the broking industry is a move in the right direction. It has come from within the broking industry. It was supported from within the previous Government and, had it been returned to power, which unfortunately due to the vagaries of the election it was not, it would no doubt be implementing this legislation-but, I hope, with a very much clearer statement of future purpose and with greater clarity on such important matters as whether or not overseas financial institutions are to be allowed to participate in the Australian stock market through participation in incorporated broking organisations.

There are, as I have said, other technical matters which are dealt with in the legislation. I do not think it is useful or necessary to address those questions . They have been addressed in the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech. Subject to the question that the Opposition has raised concerning the application or ambit of the definition of 'time-sharing arrangements', it supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1) which is before the House today involves a number of amendments to the companies and securities legislation of our nation. The areas being dealt with are somewhat esoteric but I believe quite important and practical. The first section that I want to touch on, which has been canvassed by other speakers in the debate, is the notion of time-sharing. It is a new concept and is more easily understood if one thinks of the letting of ski lodges , although I believe it relates essentially to holiday premises. A purchaser may buy a parcel of shares in a holiday lodge or holiday flat and have certain rights to use it at certain times of the year. It is a new concept, but I think it is one that has quite wide community implications.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides that if time-sharing is being regulated under prescribed interest provisions, which is the technical term, there will be a certain number of safeguards for any person who buys shares and proposes to use the property for a certain number of weeks each year. There are many groups in the community, including voluntary groups and non-profit organisations, which wish to share properties. Of course in another age these groups were catered for by using local working men's institutes, schools of arts or mechanics institutes , but in most country or suburban areas these buildings have either disappeared or fallen into disuse. Their use was regulated under State Acts. Legislation has always provided for schools of arts activities and other such community activities. However, since the Whitlam period of government, we have had a great mushrooming of community pre-schools, community centres and community health centres. There are many groups wishing to use and share such centres. (Quorum formed)

The most important section of this legislation is the new concept of time- sharing. It relates to companies and is particularly relevant, as I said earlier , to people who wish to obtain the right to use a ski lodge, a holiday cottage or a holiday flat for certain periods of the year. It is essentially part of a prescribed interest scheme. The prescribed interest is defined in the legislation. I will not go into more detail on that, but I think this will be a very relevant form of sharing property-local halls, meeting rooms and the like- by community groups.

In my area I have found that Commonwealth funded pre-schools have become incorporated as community centres and pre-school centres either as a co- operative under a State co-operative Act or as a company limited by guarantee. This form of incorporation of a company is available to a charity and is quite common. I am sure that many honourable members are involved with local community centres which are being established and are concerned about the form of establishment and structure that the centre should adopt.

I feel this legislation will be widely accepted throughout the community when it is known because it guarantees to the different groups which share a community centre that they can use that centre for their meetings on certain defined days in each month. I imagine it could be used by even a political party , the local Red Cross Society or any voluntary or school groups. It essentially involves setting up a company limited by guarantee to run a community centre. Each group which will use the centre will buy its shareholdings and have an inalienable right to use that community centre on certain days or nights of the week. There is a proposal in Drummoyne for the council to build a community centre to be shared between the local community group and the Second Drummoyne Scouts. This system of time-sharing under a prescribed scheme would be ideal for ironing out difficulties which could arise. These two groups could use the centre-the scouts could have certain access. That is the purpose of the legislation.

This legislation arose out of difficulties in a case in the New South Wales Supreme Court, Brentwood's case. Brentwood Village created certain worries and doubts about the whole matter. I see great usefulness in time-sharing in the ski lodges that are so important in the States for tourism, in the Snowy mountains at Thredbo and Perisher, and in Victoria, and also in the holiday industry. The nature of time-sharing and the rights of shareholders in companies who wish just to have this limited interest are being clarified. It will not be a lease or a licence; it will be a time-sharing arrangement.

The second part of the legislation deals with various changes to the companies legislation concerning registration of charges. It removes some of the worries about registration in the various States. However, I notice that in the second reading speech of the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in this House, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), he said that no crop lien, wool lien or stock mortgage had been registered in the Australian Capital Territory since 1979, so this legislation merely clarifies the present de facto position in relation to the registration of all these country interests . This legislation is, therefore, of some importance to Australia's rural sector .

The third part of the legislation deals with the regulation of stock exchanges in Australia. It is particularly relevant to a stockbroking firm which operates in several States. This is tied in with the problem of fidelity funds. It is of great importance to the ordinary citizen who wishes to buy shares, and perhaps to trade in shares. It is essential that the situation with the fidelity fund is clarified. It is a tragedy that there is a need for such funds but it is essential that there be a guarantee. If money is paid to a professional person, a solicitor, stockbroker, real estate agent or whatever, it is essential that the client is protected. If unfortunately, as happens from time to time, money is stolen, either by a member of the stock exchange or by an employee, there is some guarantee that the investor or the client will receive compensation eventually or all moneys missing will eventually be repaid.

I notice that the Deputy Prime Minister mentioned the need for, perhaps, a national fidelity fund covering the whole nation. As it is now, with a stockbroking firm registering in New South Wales and Victoria, there are problems and doubts about whether there should be contributions to both fidelity funds. That is what this section of the legislation is aimed at sorting out and resolving. The other clauses of the legislation are essentially related and ancillary. I shall not delay the House further. I commend the Bill to the House. It arises out of the joint consultation on the companies and securities legislation throughout Australia, and the amendments have been recommended by the meetings of Attorneys-General in our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies and Securities Legislation ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No.1) makes amendments to three Commonwealth Acts pursuant to the co-operative companies and securities scheme, that scheme being, as the House will be well aware, a formal agreement between the Commonwealth and the States executed on 22 December 1978. The agreement provides the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth-State scheme for a uniform system of law and administration in relation to company law and the regulation of the securities industry in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. That formal agreement, among other things, established a Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, comprising Ministers of the Commonwealth and of each of the six States. In accordance with the co-operative scheme, this Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill contains a range of complex amendments. Firstly, it contains amendments defining and allowing for the registration of persons participating in time-sharing agreements. Secondly, it contains amendments altering the law controlling the registration of charges to overcome specific problems that have arisen. Thirdly, it contains amendments consequential upon the deregulation of the six Australian stock exchanges as from 1 April 1984. My colleagues the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) have dealt with a number of aspects relating to time-sharing arrangements. (Quorum formed)

The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) was totally justified in calling a quorum in order to bring this important legislation to the Government's attention. If my memory serves me correctly, there were but four Government members in the chamber when the quorum was called.

The main thrust of this legislation is to deregulate the stock exchange industry. This Government is only slightly concerned with that most important aspect of our economy. I realise that the legislation is somewhat complex and is beyond the understanding of most members of the Government. Whilst it is complex , more members of the Government ought to show an interest, as members of the Opposition do, in this important aspect of the behaviour of stock exchanges. As I said before the quorum was called, the honourable member for North Sydney dealt with the Opposition's concern relating to time-sharing arrangements, and there is no need for me to cover that ground again.

I wish instead to concentrate on the deregulation aspects of this legislation. This legislation will prevent the fixing of brokerage rates. It will permit corporate membership and allow non-members to own up to 50 per cent of a stockbroking firm. The advantages of deregulation are self-evident but need to be spelt out for those members of the Government who take no interest in this area. First and foremost, deregulation will provide greater competition, lead to more efficiency in the behaviour of stock exchanges and ultimately provide a greater and better service for investors. This is in line with the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I notice that the Government is at present considering the report of the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System which was set up to examine certain aspects of the Campbell report.

Today's Press reports indicate that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are to meet with the entire grouping of the Left. I understand that that meeting will take place in a very small room, if not in a telephone box. Nonetheless, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have deigned to meet with that phoenix rising out of the ashes which we affectionately term the Left. Those two gentlemen will try to persuade the Left that the Martin report will be beneficial to the private sector. I suspect that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer will meet a united opposition to that position because the Left has not the slightest concern about, and in fact has a great antipathy towards, the private sector. Regrettably, this Government, particularly the Treasurer, is persuaded by those views and accepts the proposition of the left that it is the public sector which can best lead to economic recovery in this country. The Opposition rejects that out of hand. The stimulation of the private sector will best provide sustained economic growth which will lead to the creation of employment, and that is the first concern of the Opposition.

The deregulation aspects of the stock exchange legislation have a long and very interesting history. When the Trade Practices Act was introduced in 1974 the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges was put on notice that its restrictive practices relating, firstly, to the fixing of brokerage rates and, secondly, to restrictions on membership of exchanges would contravene the Act. Therefore, the Associated Stock Exchanges sought and obtained from the Trade Practices Commission authorisation for those practices. The Trade Practices Commission granted that authorisation but made it very clear to the Associated Stock Exchanges that that authorisation was finite and that a number of its housekeeping aspects would have to be put in order.

The introduction of the Trade Practices Act, interestingly, raised the issue of whether exchanges could restrict membership or fix charges. Outside groups, as the honourable member for North Sydney stated earlier in this debate, were very anxious to open up the market. I refer particularly to merchant banks and overseas financiers. One of the difficulties was that the securities industry legislation for each State contemplated an industry of individual brokers and not corporations. The debate quickly gathered pace from the introduction of the Trade Practices Act in 1974 and from 1975 onwards discussions took place as to the introduction of a national companies and securities scheme. The broking industry believed, quite correctly, that a national companies scheme would provide the best oportunity to open the market to corporations.

The next major stage in the development of the deregulation of the stock exchange industry occurred when a group of Australian merchant bankers in July 1981 brought mandamus proceedings against the Trade Practices Commission to force the Commission to examine the Associated Stock Exchanges' rules and articles of association. That case, brought by the Australian merchant bankers, was settled on the basis of undertakings given by the Commission to examine the Associated Stock Exchanges' rules and articles of association. The next stage was when the Trade Practices Commission, in Septemer 1982, issued the findings of its examination. The findings were that the Trade Practices Commission, firstly, refused authorisation for the Associated Stock Exchanges' rules but, secondly, granted interim authorisation for 18 months to enable amendments to be made. We are now at that stage.

On 6 March 1984 the Trade Practices Commission granted interim authorisation to draft rules and articles of association for exchanges which will allow-these are important to note-the following: Fifty per cent outside ownership of broking firms; incorporation of broking partnerships; a freeing of restrictions on exchange memberships to permit broking firms to trade and to be members of more than one exchange; outside-that is, non-broker-directors of member corporations; and, finally, negotiated rates for all transactions over $100,000. These charges took effect from 1 April 1984.

However, a large number of problems are still outstanding in regard to the stock exchange industry. There is, for instance, the problem of conflicts of interest. This occurs, or may be seen to have occurred, with the incorporation of stock broking firms because there is a great potential for complaints by shareholders that directors or other persons are treated differently from clients or are able to obtain secret information concerning clients' activities. That is a perfectly reasonable concern by clients of stock broking firms and it is one which the Government will have to address.

There are other problems which the Government will have to address. For example , the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges recommended the retention of the existing rule which requires all deals of less than $500,000 to be made on the floor of the exchange. In addition, there is a problem of whether corporate members should pay higher entry fees than individual members. As the honourable member for North Sydney said, there is a further problem in regard to fidelity funds. The new rules are said to enable a broker to be a member of more than one stock exchange.

I realise that I have touched on some complex matters and foreshadowed further complex matters which will have to come before this House. The concern of the Opposition is that the Government has an ad hoc approach in regard to deregulation of the stock exchange industry. We are also concerned that this legislation was rushed through the Senate and is now being rushed through the House of Representatives. The legislation was debated in the Senate on 3 April 1984 and, as I understand it, the Bill was available for discussion and perusal in the last week of March. That is simply not sufficient time to permit the industry and other interested persons to consider carefully each of the provisions of the legislation so that they can have some further input into discussion on these matters. In other words, I believe that the Government has at the last minute taken a slap-dash type of approach in regard to this legislation. After all, as I have outlined, these changes have been mooted and considered publicly since 1982 when the Trade Practices Commission issued its findings into its inquiry into the rules and articles of association of the Australian Associated Stock Exchanges. As I said, they were approved by the Trade Practices Commission on 6 March 1984. For that reason, I do not believe that this Government has permitted sufficient public discussion or time for a position to be formulated.

In summary, the Opposition supports the legislation, but we express concern at the apparent ad hoc approach of the Government. What is needed is clarity and as much simplification as possible in this fairly diverse and complex area of law. I have little confidence from the Government's performance to date that it is working along the principles of clarity and simplification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will be brief as there are a number of other legislative processes that have to be dealt with. I do not accept the criticism of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) who has just resumed his seat, for this reason: This Government was always anxious that we might have a national approach to matters such as this. I can understand in a federal structure that there are pressures from the States. The previous Government, which was of the same philosophy as that held by the honourable member, said that these matters have to be left, in the terms of the federal structure, to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. It is an extraordinary situation in that by way of compromise we now endeavour to legislate in what he might say is an ad hoc way on a national basis. We cannot do anything until such time as the States and the Ministerial Council agree. That is the great burden.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised, for the benefit of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) whose contribution I appreciate, that the amendments have been under consideration for two years by the Ministerial Council. That Council has to use its agency, which is the National Companies and Securities Commission, to advise it as to how the Commission evaluates all the various problems that have been raised here today. In fairness to the Council and in rebuttal of what might be legitimately argued-that there has not been sufficient time-I point out that there has been two years discussion through the Commission, which is the agency of the Ministerial Council, with all those who are interested in this matter- brokers and everybody else. In fairness to the Council, there has been a strong input on all those matters. It is not just a question of exposure for a week or a fortnight; it has been exposure for a period of years--

TALK.START.PARA: —But not this legislation or the draft.

—Yes, just that, in the terms of what it means. I appreciate that the actual legal drafting might be another matter, but the Ministerial Council has had to approve these matters. I assure the honourable member of that . I just say that at the outset, because it is cumbersome; it is contrary to what the people in the federal structure would expect-that a national parliament will legislate in accordance with what it, the national parliament, dictates rather than, at the end of the line, our being merely the people who put the label on the product. The legislation has been prepared by our State counterparts and that is a problem.
—Is that a bad thing?

—I am glad the honourable member says so. That is not the philosophy of the honourable member's Party. I will turn now to some of the matters that have been raised by the honourable member for North Sydney. He said quite fairly that the Government ought to make up its mind on the level of foreign ownership for the proposed new corporate members of the stock exchange. I have to admit to the honourable member that this matter is still under consideration by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the context of the Government's view on foreign investment. But I think the fact that this matter has been raised here today might accelerate some determination of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate also that the honourable member for North Sydney wants the Bill to be dealt with in Committee and I am not going to delay the course of action in any way. But there are some things I should say that might encourage him to comment at a later stage. According to the honourable member, the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans), in the debate in the Senate, had misunderstood the manner in which section 169 of the Companies Act operates. I am advised by my officers here today that that is not really correct. The Attorney-General was indicating that prescribed interests operate only if they are issued or offered to the public. There are prescribed interests which are not offered or issued to the public. There is a distinction to be drawn. This latter expression is a defined term. Section 5(4) of the Companies Act would have the effect as cited in this example: The hire of a football ground would not involve an offering to the public of a prescribed interest. The view is taken that the people who were interested in football would be the ones who were involved and not the public generally. Therefore, that distinction is drawn.

The honourable member for North Sydney also asked whether contracts for the use of public entertainment and sporting facilities-for example, that football ground which is used on Saturdays for three years-inadvertently fall within the time-sharing definition. The attitude is that it would not fall within this definition because it is not an offer to the public. If a particular arrangement were caught, recourse could be had to the wide exemption powers of the National Companies and Securities Commission under section 215 (1) (c) of the Companies Act, State codes and section 16 of the State Companies (Application of Laws) Acts. But the definition will be kept under review and it could be amended if examples come to light of schemes which have been inadvertently caught.

The other matter which the honourable member for North Sydney raised was that the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1) should have been exposed to the public and given--

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Bill.

—As a Bill. I am advised that the Bill contains amendments to the co-operative scheme legislation consequent upon changes to the articles and business rules of the stock exchanges which came into effect on 1 April when the interim Trade Practices Commission authorisation for the previous articles and rules expired. For that reason, the Bill has had to be introduced very promptly. Consequently, in view of the delay that public exposure might entail, it cannot be offered because the other rules expired on 1 April. I think I have covered the matters that have been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) for replying to the questions that I raised in relation to the definition of a time-sharing agreement. But there are one or two further questions that I would like to raise on that matter because I am really not sure that he has answered the problem. Let me set it out sequentially. Under the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1) which is now before the Committee, it is proposed to amend the definition of prescribed interests to include a definition of the time-sharing scheme. The effect of section 169 of the Companies Act is to prevent persons other than an agent of a company or a company itself from offering to the public prescribed interests. Where prescribed interests are to be offered to the public under section 170, it is provided that this shall not be done unless certain things are also done. Globally stated, that means that there has to be a document in the form of a prospectus with the modifications indicated by section 170. There cannot be an offer or issue of a prescribed interest unless there is an approved deed. That is provided for by section 171. The Deputy Prime Minister may be right in what he says of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I should have thought that the Attorney-General had confused the question when he said, as recorded on page 1116 of the Senate Hansard dated 3 April:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the central elements in the definition of prescribed interest in the parent Act, section 169 of the Australian Companies Code, which makes it clear that what we are talking about here are schemes which are offered to the public, and something which is in the nature of a scheme.

It is difficult to follow what the Attorney-General had in mind, but I read it as a confusion in his mind as to what section 169 was. It does not help us to say that there is not an offer made to the public since, if I recall correctly, there is a definition in section 5 of the Companies Act of what constitutes an offer to the public. It does not mean to say that an offer has to be made to the whole of the public. That definition is to be found in section 5 (4) of the Companies Act, which states:

A reference in this Act to, or to the making of, an offer to the public . . . or to the making of, an offer to any section of the public . . . or to the issuing of, an invitation to any section of the public, as the case may be, whether selected as clients of the person making the offer or issuing the invitation or in any other manner and notwithstanding that the offer is capable of acceptance only by each person to whom it is made or that an offer or application may be made pursuant to the invitation only by a person to whom the invitation is issued . . .

That is a rather complex definition, but it provides that a selective offer is to be construed as an offer to the public. If I put an advertisement in a newspaper and I offer a prescribed interest then I am caught, even though it is offered only to people who may, for example, be interested in hiring time on a football field over a period of three or four years. It does not have to be the whole of the public; it can be a section of the public. Indeed, that kind of question is one which has been raised frequently in the past.

The reason for the definition in its present form is that it was desired to overcome selective operations which would evade the intent of the Act, which was to ensure that issues or offers being made to the public or to classes of the public or to selected groups should be covered by certain disclosure provisions. I do not think that has answered the question. I suggest to the Deputy Prime Minister that, where an owner of a sporting facility offered out participation in that sporting facility over a period of more than three years and various clubs, organisations or individuals accepted that offer, whether it was a football field or any other kind of sporting or entertainment facility, they may be caught. Obviously, that is not intended to be the case under this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks to the amendments to the Securities Industry Act 1980. I do so for a couple of reasons, one being my very great personal involvement in the affairs which led to the position in which the stock exchanges are today. It was my recommendation to Cabinet which converted the course of the stock exchanges from the direct role of the National Companies and Securities Commission to that of the Trade Practices Commission. It probably ought to be said that that course of action led to a number of things which I believe are in the best long term interests of the securities industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, at that stage we appointed Mr Michael Gleeson-White to the Trade Practices Commission as a temporary commissioner for the benefit of this hearing . That was an unusual precedent because it injected into the hearing a man of experience in merchant banking, being the chairman of a prominent international merchant bank in Sydney, and a former Chairman of the Sydney Stock Exchange. The interests of both parties who were contesting the matter before the Trade Practices Commission therefore were known by someone who had practised in that field. I believe that that brought a sense of integrity and security to those people who were appearing before the Commission, which I recommend should occur in other areas. This matter of contest as to what the brokers should do dragged on. They tried continually to take themselves to the Securities Commission. Their presentation to the Trade Practices Commission was slow and not necessarily of the highest quality. As a result of their dragging their feet, I found that they ended up with their own position being only slightly less than they might have presented it to be. However, we are where we are.

From 1 April the stock exchanges are subject to the overall powers of the Trade Practices Commission. At the same time, the Securities Commission has taken on the role of overviewing the rules of the stock exchanges and the general behaviour in that area. To date the workings of the Securities Commission have been difficult. It has relied on the State corporate affairs commissions, which have varied enormously in quality, and the type of work from State to State has been very different in interpretation and standard. Because of that I think it might be that the Commission has followed certain courses which, if it had had a more direct interest, may not have gone that way. I refer particularly to some of the actions taken in the State Supreme Courts, which were required under the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and the shared responsibilities .

The appointment of the associate commissioners-Mr Uhrig, Mr Nosworthy and Mr Kryger-has added enormously to the role of the Securities Commission. I am particularly pleased to see Mr Kryger involved as he is infinitely experienced and a man of great integrity. He will add a lot to the workings of the Securities Commission in a very practical sense. It was in practical application that I always found difficulties. There is far too much of a tendency for lawyers to poke their noses into the stock exchange operations without an understanding of the market place, and some of the attitudes taken towards the stock exchanges certainly reflected that.

Today the stock exchanges in Australia are struggling to find what their true role is. We have seen an announcement that Elders-IXL will take a 40 per cent interest in a Melbourne firm. We have seen an announcement by the National Australia Bank that it seeks a 50 per cent interest in another Melbourne firm. Those two moves are significant. Firstly, they raise a question as to whether a commercial bank ought to be allowed to own a 50 per cent interest in a stockbroking firm. This is a development which has enormous implications. It is more down the line of the European connections between commercial banks and the stock market. It is not in line with developments in the City of London and it is not in line with Wall Streeet practice. Nevertheless, I can see the advantages of it to the larger corporations. I am not at all sure that the small investor will be advantaged by that development. It also requires some consideration in terms of the roles of the different stock exchanges, the Sydney and Melbourne stock exchanges being by far the most dominant. Something of the order of 85 per cent to 90 per cent of all the transactions in Australia are accounted for on those two stock exchanges, which means that the lesser capital cities, Brisbane, Adelaide, Hobart and Perth, have a relatively small market.

Nevertheless, in the environment of State rights, we have already seen Queensland moving to eliminate State stamp duty on share transfers. This must have implications. One that readily comes to mind is that, if one is an overseas trader in Australian shares, stamp duty is at least as high a cost as is commission on overseas transactions. That alone must have some impact on business. It also means that if the smaller stock exchanges were to move in an aggressive way they could well take themselves outside the ambit of the Australian stock exchanges. That could have an impact on the National Companies and Securities Commission should a State government declare that it was no longer part of the National Companies and Securities Commission.

I have raised a couple of points which I think are fundamental to debate in this area. Very significant changes are taking place. There is a need not only to take account of the company law consequences but also to take a look at the financial implications of ownership, foreign ownership, the position of banks and the position of major interests buying themselves into the stock exchange industry.

Finally, in this period of enormous change, for nearly 10 years an officer in the Attorney-General's Department, formerly in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, has played a very significant role in commercial law in Australia; that is, Peter Kennedy. He is about to take up a position outside the Department. I wish him well. His contribution to the National Companies and Securities Commission, company law, the stock exchanges and bankruptcy law in Australia in the last 10 years has been very significant indeed. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No.1) is not opposed. I thank the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) for his contribution. I think it was significant. He immediately alerted us to the fact that problems are arising because of what we might term the new aspect of major corporations and banks taking interests in share brokerage firms. I think this will be significant. In some cases I think it will dominate the market and affect the small investor.

SPEECH.PARA: It has always been a problem with the Trade Practices Act to get a balance between free enterprise and monopolisation, which would prevent free enterprise. I think the problem is highlighted further by the fact that the States themselves have a tendency to bid for business in the area of State taxes-be it death duties or anything else. We now have their involvement in the matter the honourable member mentioned. I think that will have a negative effect. In many cases that sort of counter-bidding by States destroys the national interest.

It is significant that the Senate inquiry we set up to inquire into what were called the malpractices that bedevilled the stockbroking industry clearly indicated that there was only one economy, one Budget and one market in Australia, not six or seven. That always needs to be understood. We do not want in any way to intrude into State rights, nor should we; but there is a valid argument that there is a national interest and a national capacity. I think that always has to be agreed to by the States. It will weaken the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, it will weaken the whole concept of the enforcement of a national code, if those other matters are allowed to dominate the issues; for example, small markets will probably fail and small investors will be ignored. If that happens I think we will be very hard pressed to guarantee that the States themselves will give us the support we need in the Ministerial Council.

Having said that, I think the contribution of the honourable member for Ryan was significant. I thank him for it. I, with him, judge that the future holds a few problems. The organisations that dominate, be they banks or trading houses, have a tendency to look at their own interests, their own profits, rather than at the general public interest, which is our responsibility.
I now deal with the matter raised by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). Quite fairly, he raised the point of how we define 'public interest'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Public offer.

—I thank the honourable member. The way in which 'public offer' is interpreted certainly is subject to argument. I take refuge in the fact that an offer of a football ground to other football participants is not necessarily an offer to the public. The honourable member can argue that there would be so many participants that they could be defined as the public. I think, though, that we eventually have to take refuge in the fact that section 215 (1) (c) of the Companies Act, concerning the powers of the National Companies and Securities Commission, gives a right of exemption from that application; that is , section 215 (1) (c) provides an exemption from section 169 of Division 6.

SPEECH.PARA: What I think we are saying on behalf of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is that if an arrangement is made with specific people, pursuant to a limited offer, it is not an offer to the public because we are talking about, for example, the use of a football ground, but that if it were to be interpreted as an offer to the public we could get an exemption under section 215(1)(c) of the Companies Act. I take final refuge in the fact that if all that fails the matter will be kept under continual review by the Ministerial Council. I think the matter has to be left at that. I thank the honourable member for North Sydney for his concern. Of course, the Act will be amended if it becomes apparent that the scheme is not working as intended or that it has been inadvertently caught up.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
ROADS GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1984]
Debate resumed from 4 April, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I was speaking of the effect that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill will have on the road system in my electorate. Honourable members will remember that I spoke of a number of roads. When the debate was interrupted I was talking about the Cobb Highway, which runs from roughly east of Wilcannia through Ivanhoe to Booligal. Most of that road is bad and is unsealed. I would now like to travel from Mossgeil, which is on the Cobb Highway, across toward Hillston. That is Trunk Road 80 and it is impassable after a few points of rain. I was interested to read in today's Barrier Daily Truth, a Broken Hill publication, a report by the chief traffic engineer of the National Roads and Motorists Association, Mr Searle, who said that many roads in New South Wales west of Griffith and towards Deniliquin are simply pushed up or graded out of the surrounding local soil and are impassable after light rain. Trunk Road 80 is a typical example.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am talking about these isolated roads I would like to pay a tribute- because the opportunity is not afforded all that often-to employees of the Department of Main Roads in New South Wales who work in particularly isolated locations. They are there whether it is 110 degrees in the waterbag or whether it is below freezing, as it is on some mornings. They live and work in very isolated locations. Fortunately, now that they have two-way radios they are not so isolated. But it is still a very difficult job. They work on Trunk Road 80 and other roads to the west.

The important Hillston to Mount Hope to Cobar road is in red soil country. That is also a very treacherous road after rain. What I am trying to put across is the fact that the present Government has decided to index the diesel and petrol levy and, after receiving that indexed amount, will not put it towards roads. The $500m which we would have received from that levy over the period to 1988 would certainly have improved the situation, if not in the Riverina, certainly over most of Australia.

Main Road 371 runs between Rankin's Springs and Lake Cargelligo and is one of the most dangerous roads in my electorate. Recently I had a meeting at Naradhan of which the presence of the young school children in the gallery reminded me. In that area the mothers are very concerned. The State Government has taken away the school bus because of the lack of student numbers. They are very concerned by the fact that they have to take children out on that road to get to the school. The accident rate on that road is horrendous. Three shires are involved with Main Road 371, the Bland, Lachlan and Carathool shires. Those shires are hard pressed just to maintain that road, let alone carry out further construction. In the south of the electorate is Main Road 296 from Balranald which links with the south-eastern part of New South Wales. That is another bad road. On most of these roads one has the problem anyway of trying to dodge kangaroos, emus and stock which may be crossing the road.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Tibooburra road?

—The Tibooburra road is a good example. It is terrible. I know that the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) has travelled extensively on those roads, particularly in his younger days. He would know exactly what I am talking about. Trunk Road 67 from Wentworth to Pooncarie and thence to Menindee is another bad road. Actually, I am hard pressed to find any good roads in my electorate. Some have been sealed, but most of them are only pushed-up earth. I reiterate that it is not the fault of the Department of Main Roads or of the local shires in the area. They are all trying to do their best. The problem was caused by previous governments which did not provide enough money and did not get their priorities right. The present Government is guilty of the same thing. Roads are not being provided in areas which produce real wealth. I give as an example the area north of Wilcannia which this year had a $6m crop of grainseed. The people there are having difficulty in getting that shipment out of that area simply because of the road system. If they get any rain up there, heaven knows when they will get it out.

SPEECH.PARA: I could go on and on informing the House of the need for more funding in the Riverina. Of course, the Riverina only reflects the rest of rural New South Wales. I simply say that I support the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) who is trying to get the Government to put the indexed excise back into the road system of Australia. I do not support the Bill . I agree that we should be able to say: 'Okay, if we have to keep jobs in a certain isolated area we will not go to tender'. The cost of roads being what it is today, that opportunity should be there. On the other hand I am afraid that this Bill allows anyone to opt out of the tender system. I do not think that is good enough.

Finally, I hope that the Government takes on board all the remarks that have been made in this debate, that we get back the indexed excise and that the situation regarding the tender system is given responsible consideration by all those in authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank each of the 13 honourable members who have spoken in this wide-ranging and, in many ways, positive and constructive debate on the very important issue of roads. Let me stress to the Parliament that roads and road funding are a major priority of this Government. That is evidenced by the fact that in this very first year of the Hawke Government we are providing $l,233m for work on national highways, rural arterial roads, urban arterial roads and local roads. That amount represents an increase of some 45 per cent on the previous year's expenditure under the conservative Government. If we look at the categories of roads, we find that this year $520m is being provided by the Federal Government for expenditure on the construction and maintenance of national highways, an increase of 35 per cent. For rural and urban arterial roads $444m is being provided, an increase of 56 per cent. For local roads, or council roads as so many of us know them, $303m is being provided by this Government, an increase of 68 per cent. Roads are the vital lifeline in this country for so many people. Roads tie so much of this country together. It is important, then, that roads continue to receive a very high priority.

SPEECH.PARA: One disappointing aspect of the debate was that, given that there were so many speakers on this important issue, Tasmania did not rate a mention from the other side of the House. I say specifically with respect to Tasmania that this Government regards the provision of road funding in Tasmania as one of the most important issues for that State. I point out that some $52m is being provided for Tasmania this year, an increase of 44 per cent. Of that sum, $21.2m is going towards national highway work in Tasmania; $16m is going towards arterial roadworks in Tasmania, an increase of 72 per cent; and $14m is going towards work on local roads, an increase of 44 per cent. I think it is regrettable that, given that all of the Federal members in this House from Tasmania are in the Opposition, not one of them saw fit to participate in this wide-ranging debate.

The first point which needs to be emphasised is the need for some flexibility in the tendering arrangements. This is not an issue which has arisen only since this Government came to office. Representations have been made by each of the State and Territory governments, by local government and by unions ever since the compulsory tendering requirement was first introduced early in 1981. The amendments contained in the legislation before the House have been put forward after lengthy consideration. In particular, there have been discussions with each of the State and Territory governments and with the Australian Transport Advisory Council. There have been discussions with the industry organisations involved. There have been discussions with the unions involved. The amendments which are contained in this legislation were agreed to in principle by each of the governments. It was a unanimous recommendation by ATAC.

For instance, the Queensland Minister for Main Roads, Local Government and Racing, Mr Hinze, has been one of the strongest advocates of the need for flexibility in the application of the requirements. It is interesting to note that the members of the National Party of Australia in this chamber are opposing the wishes of their colleagues at a State level. When this legislation goes across to the Senate it will be very interesting to see what the National Party senators, who are so forthright in their support of States rights, will say in respect of this legislation if they are genuinely representing State interests in the other place. I expect, given their previous record in regard to States rights, that they will be wholeheartedly supporting the amendments now before us .

I wish to make special mention of a point raised by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) because it is a very important matter.
