I refer to the upgrading of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. The honourable member rightly exposed the very shabby role of the Northern Territory Government in this matter. In the Territory, the Northern Territory Government has been saying that the highway needs to be upgraded, but at a government to government level it has been saying to us that the road is quite adequate and that it does not require any upgrading. Honourable members may have noted the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), three weeks ago yesterday, in which he noted the repudiation by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory of the necessity for the upgrading of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin.

The matter goes further than that because during the debate last evening the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the Opposition's spokesman on northern development, made the point that he had been to the Northern Territory, that he had noticed that the roads were of a high standard and that he could see cause for support for the view being expressed by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. It is only the efforts of the honourable member for the Northern Territory that are keeping to the fore this issue that the upgrading of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin should proceed.

We have had to give further consideration to the projects that are outstanding on that highway. Honourable members will recall that yesterday afternoon the honourable member for the Northern Territory asked me whether I would make available an officer from my Department to accompany him on an inspection of that highway in the very near future. I am pleased to be able to inform the honourable member that I have given consideration to his request. We are further examining the need for upgrading the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin, and I am pleased to tell him that I have decided that an officer of the Department will be made available, as the honourable member has requested, for the task that he has outlined. I should mention also that there are currently approved works of some $9.8m for the Stuart Highway. The funds have been available under both the Roads Grants Act and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act. So it is nonsense for the Northern Territory Government to complain that there is no work to go ahead with. Substantial work is available under existing approvals. But, in respect of each of the other projects that I am considering at the moment, it is necessary to consider them in the light of the Northern Territory Government's opposition to upgrading of the highway, which I outlined earlier.

Turning to the issue of the new tendering arrangements, they have been opposed by the Opposition spokesman on transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), and by some Opposition speakers, supported in part by other Opposition speakers, acquiesced to by Oppositions speakers and opposed outright by others. A totally confused picture came forward in the debate. There seemed to be no consistent line from the Opposition as to its attitude. Experience has shown that the tendering process has been a means of getting value for the taxpayers' dollar, but it is clear-it was clear to the previous Government-that in some special circumstances a rigid adherence to this requirement would be counterproductive. The requirement always to go to tender may sometimes prevent State road authorities from efficiently deploying their day labour forces. They are forces that they must maintain for urgent works and for situations in which the private contractors do not tender or the private contractors submit excessively high bids.

The circumstances under which States may seek exemption have been set out in the Bills. However, under the legislation the onus will be on the States to satisfy the Minister for Transport that the criteria in the legislation apply before the tendering requirement is waived. There will be no open door to the avoidance of tendering procedures, as has been suggested-in fact, I think rather hoped for-by some members of the Opposition. I do not envisage that there will be more than an occasional need to utilise these provisions. At present my Department is preparing a set of stringent guidelines which will be incorporated in the notes on administration of the legislation and against which I will assess a State's application for exemption. Let me emphasise that these guidelines will be designed to ensure that the consideration of applications for exemption is based on a rigorous and detailed examination of all the relevant factors involved.

An argument in favour of private contractors was put by the Opposition. Again, I emphasise that private road contractors can tender for all roadworks across the spectrum, whether they be available for tender in the public sector, the private sector, or any construction work that is put to tender by either the public or the private sector. However, the State road authorities, the public road authorities, are generally-it varies from State to State-limited by this legislation to being able to tender only for work offered by public road authorities. They are excluded in the main from the private sector. The point to make in respect of the tendering is that all governments-Federal, State and Territory, be they conservative or Labor governments-are as one on this issue that the existing legislation is rigid, inflexible and inefficient in a number of respects. That is the reason this legislation is now before the Parliament.

The honourable member for Dawson in his comments ignored the fact that country councils in Queensland have been to the fore in local government representations , especially the Barcaldine Shire Council. It is not enough for the Opposition to say, as did the last speaker for the Opposition, the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), 'Those fellows working on the main roads are doing a great job out there in the country in isolated locations, under difficult conditions of loneliness and harsh accommodation, and we think they are great blokes'; and then, on the other hand, say: 'We do not think they are really competent enough to carry out the work efficiently and as effectively as the private sector' and by the existing legislation, which is the Opposition's legislation and that of the honourable member, give a preference, an exclusive right, to the private sector to carry out roadworks. Honourable members opposite cannot have two bob each way. They cannot run back to their constituencies and say 'We think you are great blokes', and come into this place and tell the Parliament that those men are not efficient, and that is why they are opposing this legislation. They should make up their minds on where they stand. They cannot make such a statement in their electorates and come here and say the opposite. They should be consistent. The effect of the comments from the Opposition speakers is that they judge public roadworks forces to be inefficient and far more costly than those of the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no favouritism. You know that. You are supporting it. Why don't you knock it right out?
—Order! The honourable member for Hume has already spoken in this debate.
—Toss him right out. Give him an early shower.

—I am sure the honourable member needs it after last week. I turn now to the issue of urban public transport and the funding of urban public transport projects under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act. The Opposition's spokesman on transport stated that he was not aware of the ABRD-UPT provisions being used until the announcement of the New South Wales projects during the recent State election. It seemed to me also that he was unclear about the projects actually announced.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again to members of the Opposition that the legislation as it exists is their legislation. Most Opposition members who are present voted for it. It is reasonable for the Australian people and the Parliament to expect them to know its provisions and to understand it. Urban public transport funding is available under the ABRD Act. The former Minister, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who is in the chamber, knows that, because he was responsible for it. Under that provision, projects had been approved in four States-Queensland, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia-prior to the announcement of the New South Wales projects. In fact, at the last Federal election a number of Queensland projects were approved by the previous Minister after the election had been called. Two rail electrification projects and six passenger interchanges were approved by the Minister in the former Government at an estimated cost of almost $26m. Approvals were given on 8 February 1983, a few days after the election was announced, and on 2 March 1983, three days before last year's election. Both approvals were given during the caretaker period of the former Government and both were contrary to convention relating to an outgoing government and the management of government business. So members of the Opposition, with their cant, should not raise the issue of approvals that were given in respect of projects for New South Wales. Those projects were put forward as elements of a proposed UPT program in September 1983, six months previously. It was not a matter of expediency, as was the case with the Queensland approvals last year. It was simply a matter of good government and that the items were appropriate. They met the requirements under the Act and, accordingly, they were approved.

I turn to the jobs on local roads program because it is an interesting program. It seems that because it has been so successful-to date, some 6,437 jobs have been created-because it generates additional jobs, because some 700 councils in Australia are participating in the program, and because 1,150 projects have been processed by my Department, the Opposition has to find some way of criticising it. Last night the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) declared that the jobs on local roads program was not part of the roads issue. That defies my understanding. How he can say that the great work that is being done under the jobs on local roads program is not part of the roads program is beyond my comprehension. That program is very much appreciated by local government. It has been a great success under the community employment program, and I know that local government desperately wants to see that program continue for some years.

I turn briefly to the issue of the indexation of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund levy because obviously that will come up again in the Committee stage of the debate. It is very clear that some people in the National Party organisation decided to write a Press release about the issue of indexation which was circulated. Each member of the National Party put his name on the top of the Press release and each copy carried the same words. In parrot fashion, they concentrated on how much money from indexation of the ABRD levy would have gone to local government. The amount is $2.7m. Yesterday in this chamber they repeated their argument in parrot fashion. I know it is reasonable to expect National Party members to know a lot about parrots because it fits their environment to be parroting rather than developing individual thought and analysing legislation. But they know very well that last year $70m in additional funds, exclusive of ABRD, was made available specifically for local government.

We have done something for local road funding in this country. Honourable members opposite bled local government. In their seven years in government they quadrupled Federal fuel related revenues. They trebled the price of petrol to people in the country and they robbed road authorities of $520m in road funds. They have the temerity to talk about the $2.7m that may have been lost to local government because of non-indexation of the levy. We have done something for local government, and I will deal with that issue in more detail later.

I conclude by briefly referring to some of the comments made by members of the Opposition. I mentioned the attitude of the honourable member for Dawson towards Northern Territory roads. But I was intrigued that at the conclusion of his remarks he was gravely concerned about how difficult it was to travel from Parliament House to Canberra Airport. He was not concerned about roads in the Northern Territory-they are of a high standard-but he was concerned about the trip from Parliament House to the airport, the fact that there were two bridges to cross and that there was a bit of a delay. That, again, indicates the priorities of the National Party in regard to people in the country and people in the Territory. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) bewailed the fact that work had not commenced on the Tweed Heads bypass. Members of the Opposition do not want to hear about the Tweed Heads bypass because only two National Party members are in the chamber. (Quorum formed)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During the second reading debate the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) suggested that because the Tasmanian members had not participated in the debate they had no interest in the roads of their State. There are some points I would like to make about that in order to answer that allegation and misrepresentation by the Minister.

—Order! The honourable gentleman is entitled to explain to the House how he was misrepresented. He is not entitled to debate the issue, nor is he entitled to make a personal explanation on behalf of other Tasmanian members.
—Well, I shall direct my personal explanation to my particular situation. The Minister misrepresented me--
—I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. No names were mentioned by me. There was no personal--
—Order! The honourable member for Braddon is not entitled to make a personal explanation if he was not named by the Minister in the House.
—With all due respect, Madam Deputy Speaker, if the Minister at the table says that the five Tasmanian members--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman may resume his seat.

INTERJECT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. With all respect, Madam Deputy Speaker, to the ruling that you have just made, I point out that there are only five Tasmanian members, and that--
—Order! There is no point of order.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the amendment which has been circulated in my name:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, after clause 2, insert the following new clause:
Moneys to be paid into Road Fund
'2A. Section 8 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end thereof the following sub-section:

'(8) In addition to the amounts payable into the Road Fund from the Consolidated Revenue Fund under sub-sections (1) and (2) there shall be paid into the Road Fund an amount bearing to the amounts payable pursuant to sub- sections (1) and (2) the same proportion as the current rate of Excise duty for motor spirit or diesel fuel entered for home consumption bears to such rate as at 30 June 1983.'

The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that the amount of money which is raised by indexing the 2c a litre bicentennial road levy and which at present flows to Consolidated Revenue and stays there will flow into the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund and be spent on roads. The Opposition's view about this matter is very strong. We are committed to the view that the agreement that was made between motorist organisations, State governments, local governments and the Federal Government, and finally introduced in the form of legislation by the then Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), was clearly to an arrangement by which there would be a levy and that the money raised by the levy would be paid to the Trust Fund and made available for roads.

At that stage there was no intent on the part of the former Government to index anything by way of levy. That is something which has come about only as a result of the avariciousness of the Hawke Labor Government and of the present Treasurer (Mr Keating), who is having all sorts of difficulty in trying to keep his Budget balanced. As a result of that, it was quite appropriate that when the levy legislation was introduced we provided for 2c a litre of the levy that was paid into Consolidated Revenue to be paid into the Bicentennial Trust Fund and then allocated, in turn, to roads. One can imagine the disappointment that the Opposition felt-and all the motorist organisations, local government organisations and everyone who is concerned with roads felt-when the Treasurer indexed that levy, among other levies, and we learned that the amount of money raised over and above the 2c a litre as a result of indexation was to be left to sit in Consolidated Revenue and not be paid across to the Road Development Trust Fund.

We have raised this matter time and again. We have raised it by questions in this place. It has been confirmed by both the Treasurer and the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) that that money is not being paid across to the Road Development Trust Fund and that they have no intention of so doing. The legislation before the House has been brought forward by the Minister because he wants to make changes to the tendering arrangements and changes to the arrangements that are required by States in relation to urban public transport and to their traditional road spending effort. Yet the Minister was not prepared , when he brought the legislation before the House, to raise the question of the indexation effect on the bicentennial road levy. So, the Opposition is raising the matter. We shall put the Government to the test. We shall make Government members vote, if that is what they want to do, against paying that money across to the Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund, as was clearly the intent of everybody associated with this particular levy when the deal was struck and prior to the introduction of the legislation by the former Government. I do not know how I can express more strongly my view and the Opposition's view about this matter. We are committed to the view that if there is to be indexation it is imperative that the additional revenue must be paid across for roads.

The estimate which I mentioned in the second reading debate last night was prepared by the Australian Road Transport Federation. I have put it to the Treasurer; he has not been prepared to dispute it. To my knowledge, the Minister for Transport has not been prepared to dispute it. The estimate shows that $491m will be raised as a result of the indexation of the 2c levy. That $491m will lie in Consolidated Revenue and be spent on other priorities of this Government, but not on roads. If the figure of $2.5 billion, which was the figure used by the former Minister as to what would be raised by the bicentennial levy over the life of the program, remains a correct figure, the figure of what will be raised by indexation, about $500m, means that the indexation effect will raise an additional 20 per cent, one-fifth, of what was being raised by the levy itself, and that money will not be going to roads.

I make it clear to the Committee and to anyone who might be interested that there would never have been agreement on the part of States, local government and motorist organisations to the 2c levy in the first place had it not been clearly stated and agreed by the Federal Government that it would be hypothecated for roads. Yet within months this Government has breached that trust, breached that faith and breached that agreement, has indexed the levy and will pull in about $500m over the life of the program up to the bicentennial, pay it into Consolidated Revenue and spend it on who knows what, but certainly not on roads. We are not prepared to accept that. That is why we have moved and shall support the amendment, and we shall see which way Government members vote on this issue.

This Government has done absolutely nothing in relation to roads, with the single exception of the jobs on local roads program. I am big enough to pay credit to the Minister for that program. It will provide additional funds for roads. I say 'Hear, hear' to that; so be it. I give credit to the Minister. But the Minister will not give credit to the former Government for what is going on. A few minutes ago in this debate he took credit for the fact that his Government , his ministry, has increased by 45 per cent the amount of money going to roads this year. He knows that that is absolute nonsense. He knows that it is so close to being an untruth that the procedures of the House of Representatives ought to provide a way of dealing with him for having said that. He knows that it is because of the introduction of the ABRD levy by the previous Government. He knows that it is as a result of the increased flow coming into the revenue and into the Trust Fund and the way that that has picked up-it has gone from 1c to 2c a litre-that he is able to preside over that increase in funding which is flowing to roads. It is not due to one decision that he, the Treasurer or the Government took. It is due entirely to decisions of the former Government, over the results of which he is now able to preside as the incumbent Minister. That is so in much the same way as the wages pause has provided enormous benefits for Australia's economic recovery, which is now being presided over by the Hawke Labor Government. Just as the Labor Government is taking credit for that initiative of the former Government, so it is with this increase in road funds.

Everyone in this Committee knows, and everyone in the country knows, that the credit is due to the former Government and to the former Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). However, although I am prepared to acknowledge the present Minister's contribution in the form of the jobs on local roads program, he will not acknowledge the former Government's contribution and that of the former Minister in his initiatives and that Government's initiatives in getting through the ABRD program and in providing the mechanisms which have provided that 45 per cent increase in funding, over which he is presiding and for which he seeks to take credit. Shame on the Minister for not being prepared to acknowledge that. Shame on him for being able to sit in that chair and claim the credit for a 45 per cent increase in road funding for which he knows, as does everyone who sits behind him, he can take absolutely no credit.

What has the Government done apart from introducing the JOLOR program? It has let the States off the hook. It is changing the arrangements that relate to tendering-one of the few sensible things that have been done in roadmaking in this country over recent years. Those arrangements ensured that there would be value for the dollar in the roadmaking area. I think that the Government and the Minister stand condemned for the miserable nature of the approach they have taken in relation to this. They will not give credit where credit is due. They say: 'This Government's commitment to roads is such that we have been prepared to put 45 per cent more funds into roads than you were'. What absolute hypocrisy , cant and nonsense! It is about time the Minister was prepared to give credit where credit is due.

The Opposition is putting the Minister to the test. We know that in opposition he opposed the ABRD program. I have quoted from his Press release. I have made it clear to the chamber that from the beginning he would not have a bar of the ABRD program and opposed it. I know and his colleagues know that in opposition he opposed it in the Caucus. He was told by his colleagues: 'Don't be stupid, Peter; this is a sensible program which will get money into roads'. Finally he was forced to capitulate. Now, in government, as a Minister, he has no choice but to live with the ABRD program that we introduced in government. It is providing 45 per cent more money for roads this year. Under indexation it would have provided another $500m over the life of the program for additional spending on roads. The amendment which I have moved and which the Opposition will support will ensure that that money will go to roads if the Government is prepared to accept it.

—Let me explain that the agreements introduced in the 1983-84 Budget provide for automatic six-monthly indexation of excise charges to replace the previous system of ad hoc adjustments which had evolved over a number of years and which were so beloved to former conservative governments. They just increased excise and whacked the proceeds straight into Consolidated Revenue without accounting for it. The Australian bicentennial road development legislation which was passed by the previous Government simply provides for payment to the ABRD Trust Fund of an amount equal to 2c per litre from net fuel excise collections.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again that the previous Government-its remains now sit on the other side- did not see fit to specify in the legislation any form of indexation, any form of hypothecation or any adjustment other than the 2c per litre. It is its legislation. I sat right through the debates at the time. There was no suggestion that there was to be any change from that position. In fact, the legislation required that for the first year the amount be one cent and that for the second year it be 2c. Honourable members opposite did not see fit to make any adjustments for the third, fourth, fifth or sixth years. They should not come to me complaining because they have suddenly got the idea that it ought to be indexed. That was their failing. That was their decision. The agreement that was reached between the Australian Council of Local Government Associations, the previous Federal Government and the State governments is contained in the legislation and is being faithfully implemented by this Government. The arguments have been about what that means for local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have totally breached the spirit of it. You know that.

—I say to the honourable member and to his colleagues in opposition that that is one of the reasons for their being in opposition. They did not understand what they were doing. They still do not really understand what they did. It is their legislation. They do not understand the provision. That was obvious from the debate last night and it is obvious from their interjections and comments now. They have concentrated on the money that may have gone to local government as a result of indexation. That amount would have been $2.7m. In the same Budget, the current Budget, a special allocation of some $70m-26 times as much-has been provided to local government for work on local roads. It has been provided not out of the ABRD Fund but out of additional funds ; it is a special allocation under the JOLOR program. For heaven's sake; honourable members opposite should get their priorities right. Local government is concerned about the $70m it is getting, not about the $2.7m that it may have got. That is why honourable members opposite are in opposition. They do not understand. They have not been concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go on. If the revenue from the indexation of the ABRD surcharge had been paid into the Trust Fund in 1983-84 the total would have been some $22m. Consider that in the context of a total Federal road expenditure this year of $1 ,233m. Honourable members opposite have themselves in a knot over the $22m, not the $1,233m or the $70m for local government that is included in that amount. They can stay where they are. They will be there for a long time if they follow that set of priorities. We are very happy about it.

I turn now to the broader issue of public finance. It is clearly inappropriate in light of the practice of the gentlemen opposite when they were in government, and of previous conservative governments, to respond definitively on this issue at this time. They know very well, as I know, that it is a matter for consideration in the Budget context. They know that, but they are going through the stage play. I think they protesteth too much. They could have done something about the legislation last year but they did not. I and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have already indicated that the general issue of excise and the application of the proceeds from excise will be considered when the Budget comes up for consideration later this year. It is quite fatuous for those on the other side to suggest that we have breached the spirit of the legislation. The legislation is being implemented exactly as it was written.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House is of the opinion that the Government should establish a uniform system with the States for the rapid exchange of data on stolen vehicles so that the disposal of stolen vehicles is made more difficult.

In the Western world and in countries such as ours there are two major material ambitions that most people adhere to. The first is eventually to own one's own home. But prior to that most people, upon entering the work force, look forward to the day when they buy their first vehicle. That is something that everybody looks forward to and something that is expected. However, today we are finding a rapid increase in the incidence of stolen vehicles in Australia. Latest information from motoring organisations is that some 100,000 vehicles were stolen in 1983, an alarming 10 per cent increase over the number of vehicles stolen in 1982. To give some idea of the magnitude of the problem let me cite the following figures. In New South Wales there were 50,000 vehicles stolen; in Victoria, 19,000 vehicles; in Queensland, 10,000 vehicles; in Western Australia, 10,000 vehicles; and in South Australia, 6,000 vehicles. To put it into another perspective, last year in Victoria a vehicle was stolen every 28 minutes. In New South Wales there was a theft every 10 minutes.

An indication of the fate of stolen vehicles is that in New South Wales about one-third of stolen vehicles are not recovered. That is an enormous amount of vehicles. Some are reregistered successfully, often interstate. That is the reason I believe there is every reason for Federal concern. Many are broken up for parts or simply wrecked, hidden or destroyed. Of the remaining vehicles, it has been estimated that 33 per cent are recovered as a total loss; 39 per cent are recovered with some damage; and 8 per cent have articles removed. It is, therefore, clear that any person unfortunate enough to have a vehicle stolen is likely to lose in one way or another.

The Government is aware of and very concerned about this problem. However, its resolution will require the concerted efforts of all governments, vehicle owners and motor vehicle insurance companies. Discussions have already been initiated between governments in several forums. One forum is the Australian Transport Advisory Council. This Council comprises all Federal, State and Territory transport Ministers. The ATAC meets at regular intervals. Another forum is the Australian Police Ministers' Council. This comprises the Federal, State and Territory police Ministers. Both the Australian Police Ministers' Council-the APMC, as it is known-and the Australian Transport Advisory Council have been working on ways of combatting the problem. The APMC has established a pilot scheme for the exchange of information on stolen vehicles on a computer-to- computer system between New South Wales and Victoria, with links to the Australian Federal Police and Queensland. Early results from this scheme are most encouraging. However, because of the differing arrangements for registration in the various States and Territories, the Chairman of the APMC, the Hon. Race Mathews from Victoria, has drawn the matter to the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for consideration at the next Premiers Conference.

Automobile associations have also expressed concern. Residents in New South Wales will be aware of the recent National Roads and Motorists' Association campaign aimed at reducing vehicle theft and insurance fraud. Other speakers in this debate will no doubt touch on these campaigns. The Australian Transport Advisory Council and Australian police Ministers agree that the matter is of such magnitude that it warrants support from the highest levels of government. This support is required because of the need for co-operation of agencies, particularly in a number of jurisdictions. As I said before, it has been suggested that the matter be addressed at the next Premiers Conference.

The resolution of this problem will need to address a large number of issues. The different councils will need to come up with a package that helps to control each separate aspect. Issues that will need to be examined should include: How do these vehicles come to be stolen? What types of cars are stolen? Where were the cars parked-in a parking area, a street, a carport or a garage? Was the car locked? Are the keys left in cars? All these issues clearly need to be looked at . A recent survey in Victoria found that 33 per cent of stolen cars had been left unlocked and 8 per cent had even had keys left in the ignition, making it very easy for the thieves, particularly the petty thieves, to help themselves.

We also need to look at who steals cars. There seem to be three main areas: The joy-riders, organised crime and petty thieves. Joy-riders are usually the disillusioned or irresponsible young who use the car and then damage it as an act of vandalism or abandon the car undamaged or with some collision damage. But most cars are recovered at some cost to everybody because of the insurance problems. Professional thieves involved in organised crime change the identity of the car, sell it or dismantle it for parts or selectively remove parts. In that area too we have the fraudulent claims on a smaller scale-those who stage thefts or theft-and-burn incidents in order to profit from an inusrance payout. As well as this, we have the petty thieves, the 8 per cent who remove articles from the car.

How effective are current controls imposed by the State and Territory registering authorities when interstate or unregistered vehicles are presented for reregistration? This is an issue that needs looking at seriously and that we hope will come before the Premiers Conference. What checks are used to ensure that the car being reregistered is not stolen? Are they effective between States ? How effective are current methods of identifying the vehicle?

Many manufacturers use their own vehicle identification number system. There is no uniform standard in Australia. I believe that a uniform system should be introduced, together with an Australian design rule. Supportive legislation should then make it illegal to alter or to remove the vehicle identification number from the vehicle or the component part. It should be a crime to traffick in vehicles or parts from which the vehicle identification number has been removed or altered. Recommendations have been put forward for the adoption of the United States practice of requiring vehicle identification numbers to be displayed in a place easily seen from outside the vehicle, for example, on the instrument panel at the bottom of the windscreen. Another recommendation is to seek laws which require manufacturers to keep records of body numbers, engine numbers and transmission numbers which are represented by a production sequence number which forms part of a vehicle identification number.

Tighter controls should be applied to interstate registration laws and administration. It is easy in some Australian States to register a vehicle stolen in another State. Body numbers, as well as engine numbers, should be recorded by State departments of motor transport to facilitate the identification of vehicles. Each State registration authority should inspect each vehicle being registered for the first time in that State and compare the vehicle's engine chassis number against a national stolen vehicle register. It is understood this problem is under review and that some uniformity in registration laws may soon be reached. If this can be achieved, it will help to close one avenue for the disposal of stolen vehicles. A national stolen vehicle register should be set up to facilitate the exchange of information between States and to enable police forces to co-ordinate their efforts to combat the crime of car theft. The register could be kept by the Federal police and circulated to State police and State registration authorities.

Another question that needs attention is the adequacy of police resources and of the methods to recover vehicles and catch the people responsible for car thefts. That will be covered by other speakers in the debate. Is there room for improvement of administration systems between the police and registration authorities? Can we improve the security of vehicles by using improved locks, alarms and the like? Because car thefts immediately mean higher premiums for all motorists, what role do insurance companies play, and do they have a greater role to play in the system? We need only look at page 10 of the report by the NRMA in September 1983 on motor vehicle theft and insurance frauds to see who suffers. The report, on page 10, states:
In 1982, less than 10 per cent of people with NRMA car insurance were under the age of 25 but they suffered 19 per cent of the thefts. Factors which contribute to this imbalance include:
1. Young people own cars which are attractive to thieves because of their make or model.
2. They are often fitted with expensive optional equipment including stereo/ radio, alloy wheels, etc.
3. Cars driven by young people are more likely to be parked in the street or in public places where thefts are prevalent.

Fifty-one per cent of insurance claims for theft of vehicles received by the NRMA in 1982 related to insurance policies which had been in force for less than two years. By contrast, 33 per cent of all car policyholders had been insured with the NRMA for less than two years. Thirty-two per cent of the theft claims related to cars which had been insured for less than 12 months, but only 19 per cent of policyholders had been insured for less than 12 months.
The NRMA believes that factors which contribute to this are:
In the case of genuine theft claims, many of the cars in their first year of insurance are new and are therefore attractive to the professional thief.
In the case of fraudulent claims, it is older cars in their first years of insurance from which claimants profit by staging their theft and the destruction after they have been over-insured.

Many young people around Australia today are finding it very difficult to attract any sort of insurance at all to their vehicles. It becomes a matter of concern to all governments when we have on the roads these vehicles which cannot be insured simply because of the enormous costs of the situation. Therefore, we need to look into this situation. We need to take a national interest in it to see what can be done to overcome the problem.

The list of issues that we are looking at is not exhaustive. However, it is clear that the stealing of these motor vehicles is a major problem. It is not simply a question of a few joy-riders; it is an issue of significant crime which affects all Australians. Consequently, it would seem to me that there is a need for governments to fully co-operate in developing the improved data system to ensure the rapid exchange of data on stolen vehicles. It is good to see that even at this stage the Australian Police Ministers' Council and the Australian Transport Advisory Council have established a pilot scheme. It is also good to see that the early results of that scheme are most encouraging.

We do need to improve the reregistration checks to ensure that stolen vehicles are not reregistered. Data from New South Wales indicates that each year there are about 124,000 pre-registration engine number checks and that 140 stolen vehicles are detected as a result. We are not covering all the vehicles. We do not know how many stolen vehicles get through the registration system. Further safeguards against reregistration which could be brought into operation involved prospective purchaser checks with police. A person buying a vehicle could be assured that that vehicle was genuine when he or she bought it if the data were available from the police for the public. A consumer advisory service covering legal ownership could also be established.

There are other areas that need to be covered. We need a review of penalties relating to stolen vehicles. Are they solid enough? Are the courts handing out strong enough penalties to deter those who are breaking the law and stealing vehicles? It seems that right through society we have these problems now. The evidence is quite clear from the number of cars being stolen-I detailed earlier in my speech that some 50,000 vehicles were stolen last year in New South Wales alone-that the criminal element is certainly involved in this issue. Some 19,000 vehicles were stolen in Victoria-up 10 per cent on previous figures. Any organisation that is increasing its business at the rate of 10 per cent a year in an illegal area needs careful consideration. We know the problems that the police have in trying to track down stolen vehicles. We know that the police forces are understaffed. There needs to be a complete national look to see what funding is required to overcome this problem.

It is quite conceivable, and accepted by many police, that the total crime situation, the drug situation, is involved also. The criminal element of the country is very much involved in the turnover of these vehicles that are being stolen in such a way that it is very hard to detect. Hence, I bring this forward as a matter which the Federal Parliament should take a great interest in and should be involved in.

We need a review of the current locking devices on cars and of the need for better vehicle security. Vehicle manufacturers need to be brought into line with regard to these sorts of things and to discuss with governments what can be done , because there is no doubt that any professional would take only a minute or two to get into today's modern car. I have occasionally left my keys in my own vehicle, and it takes me only three minutes at the most to get hold of a clothes hanger and get in. So, a car is not very safe when left in the street even if it is locked.

We need to develop the co-operation of car owners and insurance companies. This is very important, because the situation has developed to the stage where insurance companies now have to have people with training in anti-fraud measures on the job at all times, first of all, to make sure that a claim is correct, but also to protect the honest person who has insured his car and had a genuine accident or genuinely had that car stolen. It is becoming more and more difficult to put claims forward to insurance companies simply because of this growth in car thefts.

It has given me great pleasure to move that it is the opinion of this House that we should estalish a uniform system. We should do it in conjunction with the States. We should set up a rapid exchange of data on stolen vehicles to protect the public, to catch those that are involved and to see that justice is done, particularly to our young people who today are having such great difficulties in having their vehicles insured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to second the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) and I agree very much with the points he made about the seriousness of this problem. For that reason I was a bit upset to see in yesterday's Age newspaper a report by my good friend Robert Haupt which sought to cast some doubt on whether this was a proper matter for the Parliament to discuss. Of course, everybody has his own feelings about what it would be a good idea for Parliament to discuss, but in view of the seriousness of this problem it seems to me to be absolutely the right thing for the Parliament to turn its attention to it. As for the size of that problem, it is the case that one in 10 registered motor vehicles will be stolen before it reaches the end of its life. It is the case that the stealing of cars in Australia is now a $200m a year business. The numbers are just frightening. As my colleague has said, nearly 100,000 motor vehicles, including motor bikes, trailers and caravans, were stolen in 1983-a 10 per cent increase on last year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a serious thing just because it is an industry, as one might call it; it is also very serious for the individual who is affected by it. Short of one's family home, for most of us our car is the thing in which we invest most. Indeed , to keep it running costs us a great deal as well. So one is caused a great deal of inconvenience and distress when one's car is stolen. Because of the size of this industry, most people are at risk in one way or another, are affected either directly or through their hip-pocket by virtue of the increase in insurance premiums necessary to cover the cost of insurance as a result of so many cars being stolen. In fact, the estimate is that about $1 in $8 of the cost of a current insurance policy is needed to cover just the risk of theft. An average premium for insuring a car nowadays is around $230. About $30 of that is required to cover just against theft. Last year that figure was $20. The year before that it was only $10. That is really hitting the hip-pocket nerve of not just those who get their cars stolen but also who have to pay for policies to cover the cost of it. Those figures for theft claims have doubled in the last five years, so there is a very considerable increase.

There are some considerable differences between the States in the pervasiveness of this particular problem. New South Wales, as my colleague said, easily has the biggest problem and the rate of car theft there is rising very rapidly. In South Australia and Victoria, I am pleased to say, over the last couple of years there has been a drop in the percentage of cars stolen in proportion to the vehicle population. There has been a slight rise in the numbers in South Australia, but in proportion to the vehicle population the figures have in fact dropped. I think that is because of some excellent and, as I will say later, some rather innovative work by the police force in South Australia which has led to better means of coping with this problem.

In fact quite a deal of co-operation does go on between the State police forces , and the purpose of the motion moved by the honourable member for McMillan is to ensure that this work is given the higher priority and the greater urgency it deserves. In South Australia, for example, quite a lot of research has been done on so-called 'hot spots' where cars are more likely to be stolen. This research and analysis has led to the identification of particular areas and of particular makes of vehicle which are most likely to get hit. One can construct in fact a top 10 hit list of cars which are likely to be stolen. That is headed by General Motors-Holden's Ltd products of one kind or another: Holden Monaro, Holden Statesman, Holden Premier, and particularly the more up-market range of Holden Commodores. If one puts those models together with the areas where they are most likely to be stolen one can say that if one parks, for example, a late model Commodore SLE in Light Square in Adelaide one has got a very good chance not only of getting it stolen but also of never seeing the car again because the chances are that it will be taken by an organised car theft ring which specialises in either making the car unidentifiable and then re-selling it, probably interstate, or stripping the whole thing down totally for parts so that it is never seen again. These 'hot spots', I might add, typically in other cities, include newer suburbs in my electorate of Kingston. They also include public car parks at such places as train stations. Very many people in my electorate drive their cars to the train, park them in a public car park and then take the train to work because it is a very considerable problem to find a car park in Adelaide. Those people are not only at risk but also, as I am well aware, have had experiences of their cars being taken, never to be seen again, or being taken by a joy-rider and being damaged.

This question of organised car theft rings is now obviously far and away the main category for concern, along with people who put in fraudulent claims for cars which either are never recovered or become a total loss. The typical joy- rider takes a car which one gets back in a day or two. It may be somewhat damaged, but at least it is usually repairable. The cases which really cause the rises in premiums are the ones in which the car is never seen again. These gangs change the identity of the car, take off the compliance plates, scrub off the engine number or dismantle the engine for parts. Some of these professionals are totally undeterred by the locking systems on cars at present. In fact, recently there was a much publicised demonstration in Sydney. Several late model cars were placed in a ballroom and some people who had the skills of professional thieves were let loose on them. They took 20 seconds to get into a locked car and 40 seconds to drive the car away. The present locks are a problem only for joy-riders; they are certainly not a problem for people in the professional category. In South Australia three organised car rings have been identified and smashed by the activities of the police in recent years. My understanding is that, when these three major car gangs were broken, over $250,000 worth of cars was recovered and the offenders were identified and caught. The individual State police forces, including that in South Australia, are doing a very good job, but the motion moved by the honourable member for McMillan is directed to making sure that this problem is treated with higher priority and on a national basis.

Those are the dimensions of the problem and now it is really a question of finding some solution to it. Amongst those solutions, of course, one of the main things is greater public awareness. An extraordinary number of cars are stolen because they are simply left in the street unlocked, in a high proportion of cases, nearly 10 per cent, with the keys left in them. So, perhaps the best advice one can give to anybody who wants to tackle this problem in respect of his or her own car is simply to lock the car or put it in a garage and keep the garage locked. Another piece of advice would be to avoid the 'hot spots' which have been identified although that is quite difficult to do if one is dependent on one's car to get to the train. But I must say that the police, having identified the areas where cars are at most risk, change their patrolling patterns. According to my information, the biggest, single effect that they have had, in South Australia at any rate, is by gathering intelligence and working out where to patrol most.

One aspect, as my colleague has mentioned, is better security systems on the cars themselves. This means electronic ignition locks and better locks on steering wheels and doors. Of course, it will cost something to have these, but my information is that the cost is very marginal and is certainly a great deal less than the very steep rise in insurance costs over recent years. But I do not believe that the car companies will do this until the problem is heightened and made to seem to them more important than obviously it is now.

This debate is concerned more with methods other than ones which can be taken by individuals. The first and perhaps the most important outcome might be to arrive at agreement between the States and the Federal Government on a standard system of vehicle identification numbering. At the moment most manufacturers have their own systems of vehicle identification numbering-VIN, as it is called. But what really needs to happen is for this system to be made a national system which applies to all vehicles so that it is much easier to check. It should also cover not just the body shell and the engine, but desirably other components as well. Other parts of the car should be made easily identifiably so that people will not be found receiving stolen parts and so that it is much harder for those parts to be stolen and subsequently resold.

A second desirable aspect would be a national stolen vehicle register system. When a vehicle is stolen the information is punched into a computer and that information is immediately available to the police forces of all States. There is a considerable degree of co-ordination already, but it is not perfect. Such a system as a national stolen vehicle register would assist this exchange of information and assist in catching offenders.

A third aspect might well be something in the nature of differential insurance premiums. Why should the person who takes care of his or her car, who parks it in a garage at night and who fits a lock to it be paying the same premium as other people who do not take the same degree of care? That may not be possible in all instances and one would not want to penalise particular classes of people , but it would give a reward for prudence.

Fourthly-and this was mentioned by my colleague-there needs to be closer co- operation between the police and the reregistration authorities. At the moment this happens to a considerable extent at the State level, but it needs to be upgraded much more on a national basis. Many of the cars taken by organised rings are in fact transported across the border. Then they are given a new coat of paint, their engine numbers are taken off, different compliance plates are fitted and they are sold within a few days. This work needs to be given a much higher priority. One needs also to look at the kind of people who steal these cars. I noticed that one young man, an 18-year-old, was charged a short time ago with stealing 99 cars. One needs to identify that sort of person and nip their activities in the bud. In fact, some people take cars with such a lack of seriousness that they are caught by quite amusing means. There is the perfectly true story of the three joy-riders in Melbourne who had so much fun once they had stolen a car that they took pictures of themselves by the car with a camera they found in the car. Having done that, they left the camera in the car. The police came along, developed the photographs and caught them very rapidly. Unfortunately, we are dealing with a much more serious problem than that. For that reason I support the motion and the efforts of the part of this House to give a greater priority and a greater sense of urgency to a very distressing problem in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take as long as the previous two speakers. I enter the debate in a strictly bipartisan manner. I will break down the boundaries of State rights on this one because I believe that it is a national problem and that we all should get involved. Australia used to be called the lucky country, but, believe me, it has become a little sordid in certain regards, especially because of home thefts. I think most of us saw the 60 Minutes program last week which indicated the anxiety and the problems created as a result of home thefts where elderly people had been robbed of all their priceless possessions, had lost everything as a result of certain actions by certain people in our community. I think we all have to face up to the fact that we have in our community a dirty lot who seem to take everything for granted; if they want something, they will take it. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), who is at the table, will agree with me that unfortunately there are two growth industries that neither his Government nor my Party wants to be involved in; that is, the growth industries of vehicle theft and home thefts.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation has become completely outrageous. I am pleased that the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) has brought up this subject for debate. The cheek of somebody saying that the national Parliament should not get involved in it. Of course we should get involved. Of course we should start telling people about what is happening in our beautiful, lucky Australia that has become, as I mentioned, a little tainted as a result.

There was a very good article by David Robertson, the motoring writer for the Sydney Morning Herald. I thought it was an excellent article. It really indicated a few facts that I was completely unaware of. In Australia today there is a robbery in a home every four minutes. It is nice to see some people from Tasmania here today, incidentally. As an island Tasmania is sometimes insulated to a degree against some of the things that occur on the mainland. It is outrageous to think that every four minutes a house is broken into and things are taken-priceless things-and sometimes to the ruination of the families involved. Every eight minutes a car is stolen in Australia. Every eight minutes! Really it has just got completely out of hand.

The National Roads and Motorists' Association, the motoring organisation in New South Wales, has indicated certain things that should be done. Sometimes we all become very careless with our motorcars. The first big investment that most people make in their lifetime is a house and the second is a car. I was in the motor game for about 15 years and I found that some people think more of their motor car than of their house and their wife. That aside, they really love their motor car and will do everything in their power to make it nice, neat and attractive. They will put floor carpets in; they will put seat covers in; they will do everything to that motor car. Then they leave it unlocked.

We all need to educate ourselves and, I think, the manufacturers. We have talked about the Commodore. David Robertson mentions the Commodore. It is a very good motor car, but it is so indistinctive. If one owns a red Commodore, for example, one finds it very difficult to find the car in a carpark, because there are so many of them. Ten or 12 could be stolen from that carpark and nobody would be the wiser. It is a massive problem. I fully support the motion. I hope to God that we can get a little stricter law enforcement. Incidentally, the stealing of motor vehicles has become organised crime. It is done not just for the parts anymore, not just for the joy-rides; it is done for the purpose of transferring those motor cars to other people at a great profit. The thieves in New South Wales are set up and geared to do that very thing. I think the honourable member mentioned that about 56,000 motor vehicles are stolen each year in New South Wales. It has just got completely out of hand. I support the honourable member for McMillan. I was very pleased to enter the debate briefly to give support. I believe it should be a national problem, with all States involved. If we can bring down legislation hopefully to overcome this problem, I support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The theft of motor vehicles has become a major growth industry in Australia today and there is an urgent need for governments to take urgent action to combat this massive crime industry. I strongly support the motion before the House and call on the Government to respond quickly to establish a national data base to combat the disposal of stolen vehicles. The theft of motor vehicles is a growing problem but is one that is not easily resolved. I commend the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) for moving this motion and the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) for seconding it. It shows their interest in matters where ordinary members of the community are missing out. I must say that I am also pleased that this matter crosses party political boundaries. I see that three members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety are here adding their bit to the debate this afternoon. They are the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby ), the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker).

SPEECH.PARA: This issue has been discussed both at recent police Ministers conferences and at meetings of the Australian Transport Advisory Council and has been referred to the Premiers Conference. Really, it is at the Premiers Conference that work can be done to achieve a national attack on the problem on all fronts. We need that co-ordination by a national government pulling in very necessarily the State governments who are on the spot and who are the people to deal with this particular problem-but with that national co-ordination. There is a great need for such a national attack because it is only as the police forces, monitoring organisations and insurance companies work together that any real progress can be made; and progress must be made.

It is estimated that in New South Wales alone a theft occurs every eight minutes, while in Victoria the figure is a theft every 28 minutes year round. Those are mind boggling statistics, right here in Australia. Nationally this represents an illegal industry worth $200m per annum and involving thousands of people. Insurance companies paid out $80m in car theft claims nationally last year. In support of the motion for the establishment of such a national data base, I will say that it is nearly impossible at the moment to obtain accurate, up-to-date figures on the numbers of cars these enormous figures represent. The most accurate estimates indicate that 70,000 vehicles were stolen in Australia in 1982, but when it is remembered that the industry is growing at an estimated rate of 20 per cent per year, the figures for 1982 become little more than rough indicators of the problem.

What is desperately needed is an effective package of counter-measures to fight this crime. Obviously, the most important first step is an upgrading of police information systems to handle the rapid exchange of data on a national level. In this regard, I believe proposals are emerging for a national police register of stolen vehicles. These moves are to be applauded and encouraged. In line with this there is a great need for closer co-operation between police and registration authorities in gaining expeditious access to the necessary data. There is a need for a major publicity effort on the part of motoring organisations. In this regard, I would like to commend the National Roads and Motorists' Association of New South Wales for the new 'Stop a Thief' campaign. It is community services of this kind that heighten people's awareness of the problems of widespread theft of motor vehicles, which goes some of the way to beating the thieves.

An area of urgent attention is that of built-in vehicle security. Honourable members may have heard of the new Commodore released only last month that was purported to contain the latest anti-thief technology available. Yet it caused a thief little trouble when he stole it from a Sydney street. Manufacturers must be encouraged to plan anti-thief devices that realistically prevent entry and removal of vehicles. With more than 70,000 vehicles stolen every year in Australia, they can do no less.

Police authorities talk of three major types of car theft. The first, and by far the most common, is simple joy-riding. This destructive pastime accounts for 85 per cent to 90 per cent of all reported thefts. Usually involving amateur thieves and first offenders, joy-riding nevertheless breeds owner carelessness. Approximately 33 per cent of cars stolen were left unlocked and 80 per cent had keys in the ignition. The New South Wales 'Stop a Thief' campaign and other State campaigns are going some of the way to reducing the major contribution owner carelessness plays in joy-riding car theft.

The second major type of car theft is done by professionals. The aim is to steal specific makes of cars which then are either stripped for parts and components or rebuilt into cars with new identities, including new paintwork and registration, engine and chassis numbers. Police estimate it takes professional workshops less than two days to rebuild a stolen car and that the average illegal workshop will make up to $1m per year for a four-man operation. So here is another huge area of criminal activity which should be investigated and which is flourishing alongside the actual thieving of the cars.

The third major type of car theft is the theft of specific cars for specific clients. These cars, mostly Australian-made luxury sedans, are usually never recovered. The motion before the House addresses these last two types of theft involving highly professional and well-organised thieves with well-equipped workshops for the processing of stolen vehicles. Until now little has been done on a national level to co-ordinate the resources of police, motoring organisations and insurance companies in fighting this national problem. In many areas pertaining not only to the particular problem to hand but also to road safety generally there is an urgent need to co-ordinate data on a national level . At the moment it is impossible to get up-to-date statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics because, for instance, in the areas of road trauma, number of accidents and reasons for accidents, it is left to individual State police departments to provide that information to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. If the police department is really on the ball, that information is forthcoming and the Bureau is able to give some sort of picture as a basis for planning in the area of roads generally and of transport in Australia. But if even one State police department drags its feet a little, the result is that it becomes impossible for the national Bureau to compile statistics on a national level to underline the specific needs arising in different parts of the country. Therefore, a person who wishes to plan on different aspects pertaining to roads finds it impossible to get those national figures. I think a majorcourwe which we must take is to ensure thatany national database becomes ongoing.

Certain things have been done, and I would like to commend the National Office of Road Safety for its part in getting such information together. But the motion today highlights the absolute need, in a wide number of areas, for access to such data. As I said previously, until now not enough has been done on a national level to co-ordinate the resources of police, motoring organisations and insurance companies in fighting this growing national problem. Therefore, I strongly support the motion calling for a national data base with a rapid exchange of data on stolen vehicles so that the disposal of stolen vehicles is made more difficult.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I support this motion. I think it is a great opportunity for the Opposition to show that we work in a bi- partisan way on many occasions. I always think it a great pity that the people of Australia are not aware how often in this House the Opposition supports the Government on so many things. The newspapers make one think that we are always in conflict, but I would say that in the majority of cases we agree. As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, I am very pleased to support this motion and also to endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) who, of course, is the Chairperson of the Road Safety Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that we in Australia start to look towards co-ordinating all these statistics on the problem of stolen motor cars, because it is a national problem and it is something that we need a little more uniformity on. It is very important that we work towards a system whereby there is a rapid exchange of data across State boundaries. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) is to be commended for bringing this matter before the House, because it is an extremely important problem. As honourable members are probably aware, a system is developing to some extent between the three eastern States, New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland, whereby there is an interchange of some information on stolen cars. However, it is not foolproof. In fact it has a lot of shortcomings. The fact that the number of cars being stolen and driven across the border is still so large is a fair indication that it is not working as well as we would like it to.

One of the great things about organising a uniform data base for stolen cars is that it should be relatively easy, and I hope that when the matter is taken to the Premiers Conference it will be dealt with very quickly and organised so that there should not be much delay in getting this system under way. However, there are other problems with some of the other States, including the State that the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) comes from. In Tasmania, South Australia and Queensland, there are occasions when a car can be registered without a policeman even seeing the car. I think that in South Australia one can register a car for 28 days by mail. This is an additional problem that hopefully the Government of South Australia will address.

As has been pointed out to the House already, the size of the problem is enormous. It is estimated that it is costing Australia $200m a year. As reported in the Australian on 21 May 1983, one in every 10 cars registered is stolen- rather an alarming thought. As has already been mentioned in the debate, over three-quarters of these cars are taken by joy-riders and generally returned to the owner somewhat the worse for wear. Nonetheless, they are returned. Furthermore 2 per cent are found as burnt-out shells. The problem that this motion is more concerned about is that organised thieves account for 21 per cent of thefts. Ten out of every 100 are stripped for parts or accessories and 11 out of 100 are never found.

I have had an experience similar to that of the honourable member for McMillan, having locked my keys in my car on more than one occasion. I agree with him; it is very easy to break in, even for a rank amateur like myself. Furthermore, I have had someone leave a car for me somewhere. It was not locked, I admit, but it was left for me; and they took the keys with them. I found also that it is not very hard to start a car without the keys.

TALK.START.PARA: —All you need is a bobby pin.

—Yes, it is quite easy. So there is a design problem. We always have to face up to the cost of trying to make these things foolproof. But I suppose that in that situation I was rather grateful for the fact that it was not too hard to start the car. I also remind honourable members that in any little country town well over 90 per cent of cars would not be locked and the number of cars with keys still in them would probably be similar. Yet I suspect that, because of the nature of small country towns, the number of cars actually stolen is very low.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several ways, of course, of reducing this problem of stolen cars, and I guess most of them have been touched on. The question of door locks and better ignition locks has already been mentioned. There was rather an amusing story in the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 March. Mr David Robertson, who has already been referred to in this debate, went to drive a new Holden Calais, which is supposed to have the latest anti-theft devices in it. After he had done his test drive, he returned it to the General Motors-Holden's Sydney office at Edgecliff. Unfortunately the office was locked; so he locked the car, left the keys in the mailbox for the public relations manager, and left the car overnight. Well, it was not there in the morning. So there is still quite a major problem there.

We have to look at every avenue for solving this problem. Of course, as has already been mentioned, a sizable number of people do not lock their cars. In fact, as reported again in this article in the Australian, a third of the cars stolen are not even locked. Forty per cent are taken from the street and of 8 out of every 100, would you believe, still have the keys in the lock. The first thing needed is a bit of public awareness of the importance of locking cars. That would certainly stop a lot of the joy-riders. Another point that has already been touched on, of course, is the lack of proper staffing for the police force. I think it was mentioned that in New South Wales the Criminal Investigation Board motor squad which investigates all offences relating to motor vehicles consists of only 20 men. But the number of vehicles stolen has increased without a corresponding increase in the motor squad. In 1978 only 9.7 per cent of total recorded thefts resulted in charges being laid. In 1973 the figure was 17.4 per cent. In other words, we have a gross shortage of staff in the police force working on this matter. That is something that we could draw to the attention of the respective State governments.

Another matter touched on by the honourable member for McMillan is penalties. The penalty for breaking and entering a house and thieving something of similar value to a car is a lot higher than the penalty for thieving a car, and I think this is a social attitude that has to be changed a bit. Law enforcement agencies have to realise that we have a similar sized problem in relation to cars and the courts should be persuaded that a similar sort of penalty should be handed out. Of course, the motion draws our attention to the fact that we need a proper national data base for stolen cars, and this is probably one of the most important parts of it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 1.45 p.m. In accordance with standing order 109, as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Hurford) agreed to:
That the time for the discussion of Notice No. 1, General Business, be extended until 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief now. I think the most important advantage of this uniform data base system is that it is going to make it a lot more difficult to dispose of a stolen car. We should not lose sight of that simple fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point touched on before is the effect on insurance premiums. It has been estimated that the cost in increased insurance premiums to every motorist of the large scale theft of cars is about $30 per car per year. If a few more people were made aware of this, they might take a bit more trouble to make it harder to have their cars stolen. What is more, the general community would also insist that there be greater public awareness. In conclusion, I would say that this is a major problem which should be tackled on all fronts. There should be greater public awareness through a proper education program. The motion moved by the honourable member for McMillan is a very important one. The idea to co- ordinate the State data banks and establish a uniform system of recording stolen cars is very worth while and it is with great pleasure that I support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join this debate. It has been a bi- partisan debate on an important issue. I support the motion moved by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) that the Government should establish a uniform system with the States for the rapid exchange of data on stolen vehicles so that the disposal of those vehicles would be made much more difficult. I was very interested in the comments of all the speakers, particularly the earlier comments of the seconder of this motion. He referred to the article in the Age yesterday, Wednesday, 4 April. That article was headed: ' Plenty of debate, but on what . . . and why?' Robert Haupt was basically arguing that this motion was in some sense a waste of the time of the national Parliament and that we should be using our time discussing many more important issues. The issue that he mentioned was the Asianistion of Australia. I just point out that I believe that both issues, of course, are important.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue we are discussing today is a very important one. The dimension of the problem is significant. Some 70,000 vehicles throughout Australia are stolen annually. It is a growth industry; that figure is increasing by more than 20 per cent per annum and it causes severe consequences for many groups in our community. One of those consequences-increased insurance premiums-has a particularly severe effect on our young people, and this motion is particularly important to them. It is virtually impossible now for a young person 18, 19 or 20, in fact in many cases of any age under that cut-off level of 25, to insure a car; it has simply become too expensive. One of the reasons for that, of course, is the accident rate, but another very important reason is the high level of motor vehicle theft. For that reason it is a significant topic for this Parliament.

I would make one more point briefly about the argument of Robert Haupt that we should not be discussing this matter. As I say, he referred to the question of Asianisation and immigration. I would just point out that there are in the Parliament opportunities to debate that issue. Indeed, in just this session of the Parliament there has been such debate on a number of occasions. There is provision through discussions of matters of public importance. Only this week we were discussing the Citizenship Act. There was a very positive opportunity, as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) acknowledges, for an exchange of views on that issue. I just make that point clear.

I would like particularly to point out the extent of this problem in Victoria. March edition of Royalauto, the magazine of the Royal Automobile Club of Victoria, pinpointed the extent of the problem of motor vehicle theft in Victoria. It says that in Victoria last year a vehicle was stolen every 28 minutes, that most of the 18,852 vehicles stolen were recovered but that 13 per cent of them have not been found. The article goes on to say that the Victoria Police in particular have been conscious of the relationship between car theft and other crimes, particularly armed robbery, burglary and insurance fraud. Professional thieves, of course, can steal a car in a matter of seconds and in less than two days a car can be completely different.
