It can be repainted with a different registration number, engine number, chassis number and compliance plate and can be sold again on the market. It is very difficult for police to detect that type of theft. That is the major problem in this area. It is very difficult to know exactly what happens to a stolen vehicle after it has been stolen and where it goes.

That comes, of course, to the point of this motion, that if we can establish with all the States a uniform system of exchanging that data, the disposal of vehicles will be made much more difficult. It is interesting that the RACV mentions in the article that Footscray was the worst hit area in Victoria and that last year 540 vehicles were reported stolen from that area. Another hot spot, of course, was Elizabeth Street, in the city. It is pleasing that the motor vehicle theft rate last year did not rise to perhaps the same extent it has in past years, and I think that is a compliment to the efforts of the Victoria police to reduce the extent of car theft and to catch those who have indulged in it.

The seconder of this motion said that many of our cars had been badly designed in the past and that that was a positive incentive to theft. I note that the Bulletin of 20 September 1983 listed the number of vehicles stolen. The table shows that the vehicle most commonly stolen is the Holden Monaro. The second on the list is the Holden Statesman and the third is the Holden Premier, followed by all models of MGs other Holdens, Datsuns, Mazdas, Holden Kingswood, Holden Sunbird, and so on. That is an interesting comment because I believe motor vehicle manufacturers should be taking extra care to ensure that cars are more difficult to steal. There has been some comment in this debate today about the new Holden Commodore. The advertisements have said that its anti-theft devices have been greatly improved. I am a little distressed to hear from some of the speakers that perhaps they are not as great as they should be. But I think it is a compliment to Holden, and particularly to the Commodore, that the manufacturers themselves are making efforts to improve security.

In summary, with regard to the exchange of information between the States, I think a number of points are relevant. Firstly, in terms of the police and their activities, the police would say, of course, that this exchange of information is an important if not essential part of any package to reduce the incidence of theft. It would assist the police in crime intelligence. It would enable much greater exchange of information on all aspects of their work and, of course, it would greatly assist in the recovery of vehicles. I think there must also be closer co-operation between police and registering authorities. This relates particularly to reregistration. That is only one part of the stolen vehicles problem, but data from New South Wales indicates that each year there are about 124,000 preregistration engine number checks and of those about 140 are found to be stolen vehicles. So we do not really know how many stolen vehicles get through the registration system. Again, this motion before the House today would greatly assist in that.

As has been noted, this issue requires a Premiers Conference, I believe, to give impetus to it on a national basis. The Government will certainly be liaising closely at a Federal level to achieve this. We will also be liaising very closely with motoring organisations and insurance companies and, as the honourable member for Lilley and Chairman of the Road Safety Committee has noted , in this context the Government sees a broad range of policies which could be part of a package to reduce motor vehicle theft. Obviously, we need that national register of stolen vehicles. We need more co-operation between police and registration authorities. We could look at prospective vehicle purchaser checks. There could also be a major publicity effort on the part of motoring organisations. Finally, we should not forget the direct involvement or even possible financial support of the insurance industry.

As I have said, this is a very big issue. It is a $200m industry, if one wants to put it in those terms. Seventy thousand cars are stolen annually. As I said, it has particular consequences for our young people. many of whom now have to pay $600, $700 or $800 to insure a car. One of the main reasons for that high cost is the level of motor vehicle theft. I will conclude there. I believe that my colleague the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) has some constructive remarks to make on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most people would recognise that this is one of those thoroughly bipartisian motions. There is not likely to be any demurring on that fact. The data has been given. It is a very horrific picture. Car theft has now become one of the most nefarious industries. I just want to make a comment. As well as the problem of trying to insure against theft once they have lost their cars, young people have another problem. Many of them put so much into a vehicle; they expend a lot of their pride and their time and effort. The young kids actually keep themselves out of trouble by doing this. But if the stolen car is stripped, they find themselves not able to recoup anywhere near the value of the vehicle. I remember one young fellow who came to see me, a young fellow who really did not have a lot of friends. He had spent a lot of time just doing up his car. It was taken away, stripped and damaged beyond repair; and the young fellow then suffered a loss of some thousands of dollars. There was absolutely no way that he was going to be able to recoup that . It gives me a great deal of pleasure to add my support to this proposition. I think that the House would do well to support it. Certainly I add my support to this motion.

—Order! It is now 2 p.m. In accordance with standing order 104, as amended for this session, the time allotted for precedence to General Business has expired. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day under General Business for the next sitting.

—Can the Minister for Defence advise the House why he said on 1 March there was no policy on the HMS Invincible dry-docking when the document he tabled in this Parliament last Friday referred specifically to the 1957 United States-Australia agreement to which I alerted him and to the former Government's guidelines on visits of nuclear-powered ships in relation to this issue? Did the Minister deliberately mislead the House, or did he just fail to read the document before tabling it?

—I think even the right honourable gentleman would be aware that in 1956, when the document he referred to was negotiated, there were no operational nuclear vessels in any navy. The terms of visits of nuclear ships were in fact negotiated some years after that and would not have been negotiated had it not been found necessary to do so. The right honourable gentleman brought into this Parliament changes in those terms in late 1982. I suggest that the right honourable gentleman is not only clutching at straws but also trying to dig up from the dead agreements to try to substantiate arguments that are incapable of substantiation.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I preface my question by noting that my electorate of Kingston is rapidly becoming the centre of Australia's innovative and expanding orchid culture and export industry. Is the Minister aware of rumours circulating in the orchid industry that the proclamation of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act will result in massive increases in charges on export shipments of orchids to a level of around $56 per shipment? Would charges at that level kill stone dead a promising export-oriented sunrise industry? Can the Minister outline the true position to the House?

—The orchid growers of Australia will be forever indebted to the honourable member for Kingston for his role in this matter. I was not aware of his long term interest in flowers, but he matches the Minister for Territories and Local Government in his concern for the flora of Australia. The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species is an international agreement aimed at regulating trade in endangered and potentially endangered species, including orchids. The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 will give effect to Australian obligations under CITES and will be proclaimed on 1 May 1984. Trade in artificially propagated orchids can assist in the conservation of wild populations by reducing the need to harvest wild plants. Special arrangements have been made to assist growers regularly importing or exporting artificially propagated plants. Rather than requiring permits for individual shipments, an authorisation can be issued covering shipments of artificially propagated plants for six months. A $14 fee will be levied for the six-month period, not on individual shipments. Trade in tissue cultures, seed and cut flowers of artificially propagated orchid species not considered endangered has been exempted from control. Finally, I pay tribute to the honourable member for Kingston, who I suspect may well be known in the House in the future as 'the little flower'.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to his Department's submission last month to the defence sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which stated on page 12 that 'our presently approved surveillance capability is broadly adequate for current needs'. I refer the Minister also to the comments two days ago by the Chief of Defence Force Staff that his greatest concern was 'the fact that we do not know what is going on in our own air space in many parts of Australia'. I ask the Minister: What is the reason for this clear conflict of views? What will the Government be doing to overcome the problems outlined by the Chief of Defence Force Staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, the situation in relation to surveillance is one which has concerned both this Government and the previous Government. We have been investing substantial sums of money in the development of the Jindalee over-the- horizon radar capability and are acquiring additional equipment to rectify deficiencies which have existed for a number of years. Those deficiencies have cumulated because of the neglect of the previous Government, and because of the failure of that Government to meet its obligations under the Defence White Paper , which it brought into this Parliament in 1976 and then completely refused to fund so that the commitments which it made to the defence of Australia could not be met.

ANSWER.PARA: To illustrate to the House just how serious the depletion of funds was when the right honourable member for New England was in charge of the defence policy of this country, I point out that over the last three years, in real terms, defence expenditure increased by slightly over $325m. Fifty per cent of the three-year increase took place in the first Budget of this Government. During the period when the right honourable member for New England was the Minister, he in fact diverted funds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the Invincible; you know that.

—The right honourable member has done a terrible job regarding the defence of Australia; he should not do the same job now with his own Party. The former Minister in fact diverted funds from the defence capital equipment programs to meet ongoing current expenses which are normally met, and should have been met, from the additional estimates provided in that year to meet pay rises which were substantial because of the past neglect of his Government in not dealing with them over a seven-year period. I think that the House should understand that, although the Opposition now knows a lot about the problems of defence, it did little or nothing when it was in government to overcome those problems. Some most ridiculous matters have been raised in this Parliament over the last week in respect of defence policies. The Leader of the National Party has even cited an agreement which came into force before any nuclear ships were operational in the United States Navy as an agreement which supersedes agreements which were made by his Party later and which left out key elements of those relationships. We have also had honourable members opposite-and the honourable member for McPherson in particular-complain about the lack of helicopters available to the Operational Deployment Force.
—That's right.

—I will tell the honourable member what the score was on that. The Operational Deployment Force had four helicopters in 1982 and the previous Government reduced the number by one. In November last year we increased the number by one, back to four. We are currently planning to put another two helicopters into that area in order to provide some more operational capacity. The previous Government's contribution was to reduce the number, not to increase it.

—I draw the attention of the Special Minister of State to the fact that submissions are being received by the Australian Electoral Commission relating to a proposed Federal electoral redistribution. Can the Minister inform the House of the progress of this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Australian Electoral Commission that everything is going smoothly. The only hitch to its original plans was the election in New South Wales which held up the submission phase. The following dates have been set for the close of submissions for the electoral redistribution: In the Australian Capital Territory they are already closed. My colleague the honourable member for Canberra tells me that the maps and the submissions that have come in are already being viewed by the public. In New South Wales it is hoped that submissions will close by 30 April; in Victoria, today, 5 April; in Queensland, 5 April; in Western Australia, 12 April; in South Australia, 13 April; and in Tasmania, also 12 April. All these submissions will be available to the public on the day after the closing of those submissions in each of the States. The comments by the public, which will be available on those submissions , would then run for another two weeks, making the close off dates for the comments on the submissions as follows: New South Wales, 14 May; Victoria, 19 April; Queensland, 19 April; Western Australia, 26 April; South Australia, 27 April; Tasmania, 26 April; and in the Australian Capital Territory, Monday, 16 April. Everything is going as I told the Parliament earlier.
—Only 14 days!

—These are not the final comments to be made; these are the comments to be made on the first submissions. There is another opportunity down the road for final comments to be made when the commissioners put up their maps in June or July. Although the Electoral Commission has said that perhaps we should be guarded in some ways about the timetable I gave the Parliament earlier and about the completion time, there is no reason to believe that all the final redistribution will not have taken place by the end of September this year.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question of the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister aware that the exchange of notes of 1957 was reaffirmed in 1963 to take account of the launching of the nuclear powered vessels the USS Long Beach in 1959 and the USS Enterprise in 1960? Why did he assert that the exchange of notes did not take account of nuclear powered vessels and provide for suitable docking facilities in Australia?

—I am aware that the right honourable gentleman's experience in matters legal is far greater than mine. I suggest that, even with my knowledge of legal matters, an agreement which was subsequently negotiated and which has been presented to this House since that date has a force of law which supersedes that of an earlier agreement which it replaced.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations been drawn to recent criticisms of the Government's progress in implementing the community employment program? Can he inform the House of the Government's job creation objectives under this community employment program for 1983-84 with particular reference to whether these criticisms are justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of criticisms that have been made by the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the National Party that the community employment program will fall short by some 30,000 in the number of jobs that will be created in 1983-84 and that the Government, therefore, is ignoring the unemployed. These comments demonstrate an appalling ignorance of the way in which the community employment program is being introduced and a remarkable inability to understand plain English. Contrary to the uninformed remarks of the Leader of the National Party, 40,000 jobs has always been the target in 1983-84-the first year of operation of the program. It has been made quite clear that 70,000 jobs was the target for CEP during an entire year of the program functioning at a fully operational level-I ask the right honourable member for New England to take note of the words 'at a fully operational level'-not the number of jobs we would achieve in the first year of operation when the program had just been put into place. We always planned to build up gradually to a fully operational level by the last quarter of this financial year and that is what is happening.

ANSWER.PARA: All this was made quite clear in a Press statement by me on 1 August last year when the program was formally launched. Indeed, it is remarkable that the Deputy Leader of the National Party quoted from that Press release when making his criticisms of me recently. He quoted this part of the Press statement:
Federal allocations under CEP will begin gradually during 1983-84 until the program becomes fully operational in the latter half of the financial year.
When it is fully operational, CEP is expected to create up to 70,000 new jobs nationally in a year on worthwhile community projects.

I would have thought that it was fairly obvious from that statement, quoted by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, that it was not our intention in 1983- 84 to create 70,000 jobs, but rather that that was what we would create when the program ran for a full year at a fully operational level. Just in case that was not entirely clear to the Deputy Leader of the National Party, if he had bothered to turn the page of this Press statement and look at what was on the next page he would have found that this was there to be seen:
This would mean that, in total, up to 40,000 new employment opportunities would be created under CEP during 1983-84.

I think it is quite clear from that that the criticisms from the National Party are hopelessly misinformed. There has never been any doubt what the reality is. The reality is that we would create 40,000 jobs this year. As we said in that Press statement, from which the Deputy Leader of the National Party quoted, 70, 000 jobs is what we would create in a full year when the scheme was fully operational.

I would like to inform the House that, as at 16 March, over 5,830 projects have been approved or recommended involving more than 36,500 jobs. The community employment program is going very well and on target. I suggest to the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the National Party that they take a remedial course in English.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Finance, relates to the apparent allowance in the 1984-85 Estimates for a tax cut. I refer to the fact that by mid-1984 the average wage earner will be over $17 a week worse off because of the Government's high tax policies. Is it a fact that this year's long promised tax cuts will give back to the average wage earner no more than $5 of the $17 already taken away? Is it a fact that the allowance in the Estimates for a tax cut is less than the increase in Government revenue from yesterday's 4 .1 per cent national wage increase?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get this matter straight. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition were saying that there should be no wage increase. They were saying that the 4.1 per cent wage increase is an atrocity. Let us just get this straight. Yesterday they were saying that there should be no increase in wages but today they are complaining about the tax take . Is that right? Is that what they are on about? Yesterday they were saying that there should be no increase in wages and today they are crying crocodile tears for the wage and salary earners of Australia. I will let the members of the public make their judgment about all that.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the tax take goes, let me just make this point: Of course, if there is an increase in wages the incomes of some people will be inflated into other brackets of the tax scales. However, I have been advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that, as a result of yesterday's increase, that figure will be of the order of 210,000. Six million wage and salary earners will not be affected by the change but 210,000 will, which is very much a minority of people. Of course, only a part of their incomes will be taxed at the 46 per cent rate.

As the Government has said on a number of occasions, to the extent that we have the appropriate degree of Budget flexibility the Government will be doing its best to provide meaningful tax relief in the forthcoming Budget. That will, of course, look at the repair of the situation which we have seen as a result of yesterday's increase.

I will now deal with the nonsense figure of $17, the banality which the Leader of the Opposition has been throwing around for some weeks now. There is a revenue implication in that of about $4 billion per annum. I wonder how the Opposition justifies its call for a tax cut of that order of magnitude. If the Leader of the Opposition believes that there is a $17 disparity, is he advocating a tax cut of $4 billion, which is what the $17 would equate to? Does he want to increase the deficit by $4 billion? Does he want to cut pensions by $ 4 billion? Is the Opposition willing to admit that its tax claims are total nonsense, which of course they are. We often see misrepresentation of tax changes. Indeed, Mr Risstrom yesterday did his usual number of getting it wrong. In the Melbourne Herald in particular yesterday all those tax scales were wrong. I say to the newspapers advisedly that, before they take Mr Risstrom's tax scales aboard again, they should pay some attention to their accuracy.
I conclude by saying that the Government's economic policy is running very much on track. As to the 4.1 per cent increase granted yesterday, the Arbitration Commission said:

The granting of the 4.1 per cent claim in the context of the principle is consistent with a continued fall in the inflation rate in 1984 and a continued improvement in Australia's relative inflation rate, as predicted by the OECD.
I have nothing to add to that. The tax consequences of some people moving into the 46 per cent bracket will be addressed by the Government in the course of the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of the Amnesty International report entitled 'Torture in the Eighties'? Amongst the countries investigated, the report deals explicitly with our near neighbours, the Philippines and Indonesia. What positive policies is the Government pursuing to help alleviate the state of affairs mentioned in the report and what further action is likely to be taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of Amnesty International, 'Torture in the Eighties', illustrates the extent of resort to torture in many countries in the world. In fact, more than 90 countries are covered by the report. The report was released even date, and a covering Press statement outlining the Australian Government's responses generally to this matter has also been released to coincide with the release of the report.

ANSWER.PARA: It is correct that in our region a number of countries have been identified as countries which have resorted to torture in certain circumstances, for instance, Indonesia. A condensation of the report points out that there have been ' persistent reports of torture and ill-treatment of people arrested on suspicion of belonging to groups opposed to the Government and occasional reports relating to ordinary criminal suspects despite introduction of a new code of criminal procedure'. The summary says much more than that but time does not permit me to go through those matters. In respect of the Philippines, it refers to 'credible reports of systematic torture received by Amnesty, particularly since increased involvement of armed forces in counter insurgency operations'. Amnesty criticises the use of undisclosed and unauthorised interrogation centres known euphemistically as 'safe houses' in which torture and ill-treatment have occurred. A number of other countries in our region are addressed in this report .

This Government, as with previous governments of various political complexion, wherever cases of abuse of human rights have been brought to its notice has raised such matters with the respective governments concerned. We have done this on many occasions and we will continue to do so. To the extent that we maintain a credible and influential relationship with countries in our region, we are in a position to use that credibility and that influence positively, where appropriate, on such matters. Yesterday I gave an indication of some such instances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the expressed view of the present Attorney-General that politicians should be slow to take private defamation actions, and also to the widely held view that the proposed uniform libel laws should protect the media from the indiscriminate use of writs aimed at stopping proper discussion of matters of public interest. I refer the Prime Minister also to the view of the Western Australian Labor Premier, Mr Burke, that politicians should not use libel actions as a means of bolstering their bank accounts. I ask the Prime Minister how many writs he has issued against the media since assuming office, leaving aside his legion of prior writs? How many writs have been subsequently withdrawn or settled and how many writs are still hanging over the media outlets or journalists concerned?
—I think the current position is that I have one alive.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNIVERSITY AND SCHOOLS CLUB: NATIONAL ESTATE

TALK.START.PARA: —What action does the Minister for Administrative Services intend to take in relation to the Australian Heritage Commission's inclusion of the University and Schools Club building in Phillip Street, Sydney, on the register of the National Estate? How would the listing affect the proposed joint Commonwealth Club development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is one area of life where this Government can hold its head up very high it is in the preservation of anything that is worth while, be it environmental or historical. I point out as instances of our concern the absolutely splendid work done by our Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in the preservation of the south west wilderness area in Tasmania and his great work in the preservation of the Great Barrier Reef, to say nothing of the Kakadu National Park. I inform the House that consideration is presently being given by the Government to the restoration of a very ancient and historic building in Fremantle. It is the Government's intention to preserve the historic portscape of Fremantle and to make a Customs house.
—Tell us about the University Club.

—I will tell the honourable member about the University and Schools Club building if he will just be quiet for a minute. There was a proposition before the previous Government to build a Commonwealth building in Phillip Street including the old building which belonged to the University and Schools Club. One of the reasons it was not built was that it would have been extraordinarily profitable to the Government. That was a pretty good reason for the then Government not to do it. The Opposition does not believe that governments should ever do anything that is profitable or saves taxpayers' funds .

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps I should tell honourable members that the plan involves the Commonwealth, with a developer, turning a two-storey government garage in Phillip Street and an old building next door into a 14-storey building. The top four floors of that building would be leased by the Government for 10 years at half commercial rent, which would be about $5m. It will cost the Government $2. 5m for the block of land, which is now useless. That involves $7.5m of taxpayers ' funds. At the end of those 10 years we will own the four floors, strata title, self-contained and with security lifts. It will contain a Cabinet office and ministerial suites. The value of those four floors is estimated by the Taxation Office to be $25m at the end of those 10 years. Opposition geniuses could not have worked out that spending $7.5m over 10 years to get back $25m was a pretty good idea.

Let us get to the University Club. The University Club is a building which was built in about 1923 and has sat there for all of those years without attracting one iota of interest from the Heritage Commission. But, as always, as soon as there is a proposition to do something about it the Commission jumps in. The Heritage Council of New South Wales has a very responsible attitude. I point to the preservation of The Rocks area and the balance of Sydney's centre as proof of its responsible attitude. It looked at the building and said that it was worthy of no consideration whatsoever, that it was of no significance. But the National Heritage Commission, having looked at the building, decided that it deserved to be placed at the highest level and put it on the National Estate list. That is a nonsense. The building is of no significance whatsoever.

The present Government has complied with every requirement of the Australian Heritage Commission Act. We have looked for alternatives. They do not exist. My recommendation to the Government will be in line with that of the Heritage Council of New South Wales, the New South Wales Government Planning and Environment Commission and the Sydney City Council, which is that the building is of no use whatsoever and that the sooner it is removed and replaced by a decent building, which will enable us to provide a significant building to house Cabinet Ministers in proper, secure circumstances at a great saving to the Commonwealth, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, who will recall that, in a letter to the South Australian Minister of Mines and Energy last week, Senator Walsh evidently gave 'development approval' for Roxby Downs and that the South Australian Minister approved it this morning. In view of that, what has happened to the independent inquiry?

—I have not seen a copy of the letter which my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy sent to the South Australian Government. But on the face of it I see no inconsistency between the inquiry of Professor Ralph Slatyer, whose terms of reference are ancillary to the development of Roxby Downs, and the development of Roxby Downs at this early stage. If the honourable member has correctly read the nature of the Government decision I am quite confident that when he reads the letter which the Minister sent to the South Australian Government and the terms of reference which were presented to Professor Slatyer for his inquiry he will find that there is no inconsistency. They are absolutely complementary.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TASMANIA: DISPOSAL OF ABORIGINAL HUMAN REMAINS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to recent Press reports of the Tasmanian Government's intention to pass legislation which would effectively authorise that Government to dispose of Aboriginal human remains by cremation in a way opposed by Tasmanian Aboriginals. Can the Minister advise the House what action he intends taking in respect of this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already spoken to the Tasmanian Government about this matter. Let me say that in Australia in 1984 no State Government of any political complexion, when it comes to disposing of mortal remains, should choose to ignore the attitude of the descendants of those people. We are not talking about the mortal remains of unnamed people; we are talking about the mortal remains of three identified Aboriginal persons whose bodies were taken illegally as a result of grave robbery. It is highly insensitive for the Tasmanian Government simply to disregard the attitude of the Aboriginal people of Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: I propose to continue to try to persuade the Tasmanian Government-and in this I hope I will have the support of members of this House-that it is not an issue which can do anything other than grave damage to Australia and to any government to choose simply to say: 'We will disregard the viewpoint of a section of our community when it comes to disposing of the remains of those people's predecessors'. I understand the difference between the Government of Tasmania and the Aboriginal people. It is fairly narrow. The Aboriginal people want these remains to be disposed of in accordance with Aboriginal tradition and the ashes placed at Oyster Cove, whence the bodies were originally stolen. Negotiations broke down on the question of funding. As an endeavour in good faith to bring the parties together and to assist in the reconciliation of this matter, I am perfectly happy to use Commonwealth resources and funding. I propose to continue to press the Tasmanian Government. I will seek the assistance of the Tasmanian members of this Parliament to produce what I believe ought to be a sensitive response to the needs of an important section of the Aboriginal community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Health, his Department, or the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, for which he has ministerial responsibility, had any discussions relating to the purchase, or entered into any negotiations for the purchase, of David Bull Laboratories Pty Ltd, a supplier of generic ethical pharmaceuticals? Is this the first step in the Government's progressive nationalisation of the Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing industry?

—The CSL is a statutory authority. As I understand it, it has had discussions in relation to the purchase of the laboratory mentioned. This is in no sense a part of any overall Government policy in relation to nationalisation in this area. It is an extension of the effective commercial basis of CSL, built up as much by the previous Government as by this Government.

—I address my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. I hope his response equals his excellent answer to the last question directed to him. Will the Minister expedite access to tents for the Aboriginal people at Cundeelee? Will he direct that 50 of these tents be set aside for the community and that people of that community be charged at the average price realised for the other tents?

—I thank the honourable member for his question, which was absolutely without notice! I assure him that the Department is taking a very sympathetic view of the problem which the honourable member raised. With the winter coming on, the Aboriginal community he mentioned is faced with extreme hardship and a lack of adequate housing. He asked me to see whether the Department could set aside some surplus Army tents. Those investigations are being undertaken. I assure the honourable member that whatever can be done to alleviate the difficulties which face this Aboriginal group, for whom the honourable member has great concern, will be done.

—I address my question to the Treasurer and ask him to recall the two questions I put to the Prime Minister this week. Was Robert J. L. Hawke a Board member of the Reserve Bank of Australia for eight years until his resignation on 17 September 1980? Is the bank referred to in the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations that same Reserve Bank? Is it a fact that section 42 of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations imposes penalties of up to $100,000 or five years ' imprisonment? As the Prime Minister has already admitted to reporting on 21 February 1982 to the New South Wales police his losing $1,000 in United States currency previously in his possession, can the Treasurer advise the Parliament whether, during the period prior to and on 21 February 1982, Robert J. L. Hawke was an agent or otherwise authorised by the Reserve Bank to deal in foreign currency within Australia?

—As I remember it, the Prime Minister attended to this question. Of course, I am not riveted to my seat whenever the honourable member for O'Connor asks a question; but, as far as I understand, the Prime Minister dealt adequately with that issue in his previous answers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gorman Mr R.N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Territories and Local Government been drawn to an article in this morning's Age newspaper headed ' Cocos Islanders want watch on Australians'? In this article Mr John Clunies-Ross is quoted as saying during an interview with the Age:

QUESTION.PARA: There isn't any information from the Australian Government on just what would happen to the islands under each alternative they are being offered.
Can the Minister say whether there is any basis to this allegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that article and I want to state that it is completely false. In November of last year, the Australian Government, through its officials on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, made available to the Cocos people, and translated into Malay, full details of the three options-independence, free association with Australia, and integration with Australia. They went to great lengths because it is a matter of great sensitivity. Any Minister or any member of this House who has had association with them is aware of their strong desire to understand all aspects of their future. I want to nail the statement made by Mr Clunies-Ross. It is a completely false statement on his part.

ANSWER.PARA: I also note that in the interview Mr Clunies-Ross stated that he did not believe that the islanders were ready for self-determination. I do not know of any patriarch or colonial ruler in the past who thought that people who were under-dogs were ready for self-determination. Finally, I notice that Mr Clunies- Ross said that he now believed that he would vote for integration. I want to state quite clearly that Mr Clunies-Ross and his agents have been making it quite clear that they want 'Merdeka', that is, that they want independence. Mr Clunies-Ross wants to maintain the Cocos Islands as a tax haven. He wants to continue to influence those people on the Islands by means of the huge sums that were paid to him by the Australian Government. I am quite sure that the people of Cocos will make a decision, and I hope that that decision is integration with Australia. I think that will be best for the Cocos Malay people and I think it will be strategically the best thing for the Australian nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my maiden question.
—Scarcely.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the decision of his Government to lift the barriers to the importation of hard core pornography and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs. Did the Government gather evidence that proves the availability of literature promoting and inciting the use of hard drugs has no harmful effect upon the thinking of young people? If so, can this evidence be made available for public examination? If not, why has the Prime Minister's Government been so reckless and irresponsible in its approach to censorship?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as tempting as it is to resort to this sort of material to reply to the honourable member's question, I will not do that.
—I ask the Prime Minister to resist the temptation.

—Mr Speaker, you know I would not do that. I will resist it. I congratulate the re-appearing member on his first question and wish it had been of somewhat better quality. The facts are very simple. In regard to the position of young people in this country, this Government, in its brief period of office, has done more constructively to create a better environment for the young people of this country than was done in seven years of deliberate neglect by the Opposition. The major consideration affecting the welfare of the young people of this country is whether they will have a greater opportunity of employment. In our period of office we have turned the situation around. Previously, in the Opposition's last year in office, an additional quarter of a million Australians were unemployed. In the Opposition's last year it put another quarter of a million people out of work and that sector of the Australian population which suffered most was the young people. In just over 12 months in office we have turned that around. We will be creating well over 150,000 jobs in the equivalent period. That is the sort of thing we are doing to create a better environment for the young people of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: While people like the honourable member think that they are really addressing themselves to basic issues concerning young people by asking stupid questions like that, young people will continue to show their contempt for that side of politics and their increasing support for this side of politics. We are not concerned. This Government will continue to address itself to those issues which basically affect the welfare of the young people of this country. As we continue to do that we will continue increasingly to receive the support of the Australian people, and increasingly this pathetically ill-equipped and incompetent Opposition will go further and further down the drain, as it does each day, in the politics of this country.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 38 of the Australia Council Act 1975, I present the Australia Council annual report for 1982-83.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 1 December 1983 the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) presented on behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence the Committee's report entitled ' Australian-United States' Relations: The Extraterritorial Application of United States Laws'. It was a report the Government welcomed, and one which it has acted on decisively and swiftly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee examined thoroughly the problems experienced in Australia over the past few years and concluded that there was a need for Australian residents and those doing business in Australia to be protected from the extraterritorial application of United States laws. The Committee recommended that legislation be introduced to deal with the problem. A week after the Committee's report had been tabled, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) introduced in the other place the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill 1983 and, in welcoming the report on behalf of the Government, noted that the Bill was consistent with the major recommendations of the report. The Bill completed its passage through this House on 7 March and will shortly come into force.

The Government agrees with the Committee's conclusion that the agreement between Australia and the United States relating to co-operation on anti-trust matters is a significant step towards resolving numerous difficulties that have arisen between the Australian and United States governments in the enforcement of the United States anti-trust laws. In his second reading speech, the Attorney -General reaffirmed Australia's commitment to the consultative approach of the agreement, and stated that it was the Government's firm belief that jurisdictional conflicts between the laws and polities of sovereign governments should be resolved if at all possible by consultation and not by unilateral legal or executive action. However, the Committee noted that the agreement did not deal with a number of important issues, including laws such as the United States Export Administration Act, and indicated its concern that the agreement could not provide a complete answer to the problem of private treble damages proceedings. It was against that background that the Committee decided to recommend the introduction of the legislation referred to.

I will not take the time of the House by going through the provisions of the legislation again. I am pleased to note that when it was passed, it did so with the support of honourable members on both sides of the House. Let me only stress that the enactment of this legislation as a defensive measure is not inconsistent with the Government's policy of consultation, co-operation and negotiation on anti-trust problems. This method of settling jurisdictional conflicts has always been foremost in the Government's approach. The Government is satisfied, however, that the legislation will ensure the stable climate necessary for the development of fruitful trading relations which exist, and which I hope will continue to exist, with one of our major trading partners, on the basis of equality and mutual respect.

The Committee also recommended that the Government give high priority to ensuring active Australian participation in international attempts, such as those within the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, to reach broadly acceptable arrangements to avoid or resolve conflicts in the application of national trading laws. We shall certainly be doing this. Finally, I would like to thank the Committee for its thorough examination of the problem, and for its lucid, comprehensive and constructive report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The embarrassment which accompanied the Westinghouse case is of joint interest to Australian-American relations. It is to be recalled that the executive heads of four major Australian companies were under threat of arrest at ports of entry into the United States. The matter was of such high concern to both governments that it was placed on the agenda for discussion between the Prime Minister and the President. The threat of imprisonment lasted from 1979 until 1981, when it was resolved by the payment of $11m to Westinghouse.

SPEECH.PARA: As the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence points out, when the price of uranium escalated in the 1970s it became apparent that Westinghouse was winning contracts for its reactors by an offer of fuel at knock -down prices. When the world market price rose, Westinghouse faced losses, and its lawyers decided to use the extra-territorial provisions of United States Law to take anti-trust action against a number of companies. Westinghouse declined to meet its promises to its clients the companies, and blamed the Western suppliers group, a group set up for safeguard purposes. Westinghouse claimed damages amounting to $6 billion.

It is the immensity of the Westinghouse issue and the duration of the litigation which lead me to feel that it was for the good of commercial relations between the United States and Australia for action to have been taken in this Parliament to remove the prospect of such an incident ever occurring again. The then Attorney-General, Senator Durack, impressed upon us the gravity of the problem when he said:
Australia's national interest was jeopardised by the Westinghouse proceedings in that:

In essence these proceedings, although privately instituted, represented a challenge to the Australian Government's sovereign authority to control and regulate the export of uranium from this country.

The enforcement against Australian companies of a judgment would have a seriously detrimental effect on Australia's trade and development, having regard to the large amount claimed. The threat of enforcement is already having a detrimental effect.
The report of the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee made these important observations:

The Westinghouse case brought forcefully to Australia's attention the impact to both Government and business of the extraterritorial application of US trading laws, especially in treble damages suits under the antitrust laws. Despite firm Australian representations to the US Administration opposing US attempts to regulate the legitimate activities of Australian companies, the US Administration and courts showed no serious concern for Australia's expressed intrests. It was not until after the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restrictions of Enforcement) Act was enacted in 1979 that the Westinghouse case was settled out-of-court, even then involving over $11,000,000 payable by the Australian defendants (together with their extremely high legal costs). Future cases could involve even higher and equally unwarranted costs to Australian business.

Australian governmental concern should not be limited to the direct financial impact on Australian business (though that is of primary concern). The Westinghouse case showed that Australia's export trade, and the Government's own preference for orderly marketing arrangements for primary products, could be hindered by the unjustified extension abroad of US policies and laws. The continuing absence, despite the helpful but limited antitrust Agreement reached by the two governments in 1982, of any formal US governmental or judicial procedures for giving proper consideration to legitimate Australian interests before invoking or enforcing US laws, is a major reason why further Australian legislative responses need be considered.

Following the Westinghouse case, there have been other developments which demonstrate the need for Australian law to negate the force of United States law applying to Australia in like situations to the Westinghouse case. It remains for me to point out that, even when action is not upheld by US courts, huge legal costs can be built up merely to secure that kind of decision. Legislation on this matter was, therefore, both necessary and unavoidable.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ASSISTANCE FOR SPORT AND RECREATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, 'The Way We P(l)ay: Commonwealth Assistance for Sport and Recreation', was tabled in Parliament on 8 December 1983. I am pleased to be able to thank the Committee for the long hours its members worked to prepare a comprensive and detailed report and for the thoughtful and helpful comments made in the report. I am particularly pleased to note the Committee's support for the Government's policy goals in sport and recreation. If some members of the Committee are present, I would like them to know that I mean exactly what I said. It is an absolutely splendid report and I am sorry that we cannot reply to it immediately. Such a detailed report warrants a considered response from the Government. This has proved to be time consuming and will necessitate a delay in preparing a full response by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The report covers a diffuse and complex area. It contains 60 recommendations, some of which are addressed directly to Ministers other than me, and others which affect the operations of a number of departments. Consultation with these Ministers and their departments has been required in preparing the Government's response. The length and complexity of the task has meant that my initial objective of responding to this report in early March has now been overtaken. However, I will present the Government's response to the report at the earliest date at which I am able to integrate the responses of all those Ministers affected by its recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I acknowledge the statement of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) but I am disappointed that he has not lived up to the commitment that he gave to respond to this report by March. I do acknowledge that the report is a complex and detailed one and the importance of the Government's response could well determine the future direction that Commonwealth involvement in sport and recreation will take for a number of years. To me it is simply not good enough to give the reasons such as the Minister has given as an excuse for not responding to this report. The facts are simply these: Of the 60 recommendations only three relate to the Department of Education and Youth Affairs, only four to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, many of these have already been acted upon and one relates to the Department of Territories and Local Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that 52 of the recommendations made in the report are the direct responsibility of the Minister. I am disappointed that they have not been made for one very simple reason: At the moment I understand that a report is before the Government from the interim committee looking at the establishment of an Australian Sports Commission. I believe it is essential that the Government responds to the recommendations in this report before it make decisions that determine the make-up and structure of the Australian Sports Commission. I simply ask the Minister for this to occur. The type of response that we have seen today is, I believe, comparable to the excuses that were given to this House following the Government's decision not to support the wishes of the Paraplegic and Quadriplegic Association of New South Wales when the Government failed to give that Association a commitment to underwrite the 1988 Disabled Olympic Games in Canberra. I request the Minister to ensure that a government response to this report is given before long term decisions are taken in relation to the final structure and make-up of the Australian Sports Commission.
