DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Federal Government's dereliction of duty to the nation's dairy industry and in particular the mounting cost to dairy farmers of the Government's failure to resolve the PT Indomilk scandal.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with sorrow and considerable anger that I report that Australia's dairy industry is being sold down the drain. Honourable members will recall that last year, in this very House, I warned the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) about the worsening financial situation facing our dairy farmers. This was because of their compulsory involvement in the Australian Dairy Corporation's ill-fated marketing venture in Indonesia, PT Indomilk. My warning went unheeded and my worst fears are now being realised. Today Australia's dairy industry is owed more than $13m which will probably never be repaid.

SPEECH.PARA: Our dairy farmers are the innocent victims of a bizarre web of dishonesty, incompetence, bureaucratic bungling and commercial naivety. They are very angry at the incompetence of the Australian Dairy Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, and who would blame them? It is a scandal, which the present Government has sat on for more than a year. The Minister has known the facts from the day he was sworn in but still he does nothing.

I would like to take just a few minutes to document the background to this sorry story. PT Indomilk is a joint venture re-processing and marketing enterprise operated from Jakarta by the Australian Dairy Corporation's subsidiary, Asia Dairy Industries, and an Indonesian company, known locally as Marison. Because of the dishonesty and incompetence I have just referred to, PT Indomilk is suffering substantial losses. The point has been reached where Australian dairy farmers who supply PT Indomilk are more than feeling the pinch because payments from butter and skim milk powder export pools have been halted since last June, leaving dairy farmers with $4m in undisbursed funds and a total of $13m in overall debts to the beginning of this year.

This very complex situation has arisen primarily because of the following factors: First, an inexplicable decision by the Australian Dairy Corporation to relinquish management control of PT Indomilk to Marison in December 1980; second , a further agreement concluded in September 1981 under which the Australian Dairy Corporation was to sell its 50 per cent shareholding in PT Indomilk to a third party, PT Kebun Bunga, for $US10m; third, the intervention of certain Indonesian Government Ministers which aimed at preventing the sale of PT Indomilk to PT Kebun Bunga; fourth, a further agreement concluded by the Australian Dairy Corporation in June 1982 to sell the same 50 per cent shareholding to Marison for $US4.5m, that is, about $US5.5 less than the first agreement for the same shareholding; fifth, a dramatic fall in PT Indomilk's share of the Indonesian retail market for processed milk products immediately before and during this period; sixth, the associated change in PT Indomilk's financial position under Indonesian management in the past three years, a sudden transition from a profitable enterprise to a company owing $13m to Australian dairy farmers, and seventh, a decision which has only just come to light-it was announced by President Suharto on 25 March-to issue permits for three new Indonesian factories to process local milk production.

Something went terribly wrong with PT Indomilk during and after all those share dealings. Whatever the reason-one is drawn inescapably to the conclusion that dishonesty is involved-one thing is certain: Despite the Minister's optimism in this Parliament on 5 October last year, when he said there was a real possibility that PT Indomilk would trade out of its difficulties, there is absolutely no possibility of the Australian Dairy Corporation being able to trade out of its present situation without having the management control of PT Indomilk which it so mysteriously relinquished in 1980.

I have said that the dairy industry is angry, and this is true. The industry's dissatisfaction and lack of confidence in the Australian Dairy Corporation is vividly illustrated by the decisions made by the Australian Dairy Industry Conference on 8 February and 15 March this year. The ADIC has said, inter alia, that the present board of directors of Asia Dairy Industries is totally unacceptable to dairy farmers and must be dismissed; the dairy industry in future cannot be held responsible for the company Asia Dairy Industries unless it is given full access to details of ADI's operations; Asia Dairy Industries must be brought under the control of the ADIC; the trading, investment and technical roles of the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries must be separately organised; the export pools should not be used to recoup the moneys lost by PT Indomilk.

These decisions, coming as they do from the dairy industry's most important and influential producers' council, are a serious reflection on the Minister for Primary Industry, who is responsible for the operations of the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiary.

The Minister has clearly failed to heed my warning last year that he must take positive action on PT Indomilk and the role of Asia Dairy Industries. He has clearly failed to reach a consensus with the dairy industry on the question of whether or not the trading losses of PT Indomilk should be met from the export pools, despite his assertion in this Parliament last October that, in general terms, any loss by the dairy industry would involve the whole dairy industry. Furthermore, this Minister for lame excuses will probably turn around and say that it is the previous Government's fault that he has done nothing on PT Indomilk for more than 12 months and has made no attempt to overcome the problems associated with the irrregular commercial arrangements concluded by the Australian Dairy Corporation and ADI. This is the root of the problem.

The Minister has known since March 1983 that trouble was brewing. He knows, as we all do now, although it was not widely known at the time, that the matter goes back to 1976, when Marison sought to increase its shareholding in PT Indomilk from 40 per cent to 50 per cent, and a cheque for $75,000 was received by the Australian Dairy Corporation for the transfer of the extra 10 per cent of shares. Neither Asia Dairy Industries nor the Australian Dairy Corporation had discussed or approved this move. It was subsequently disclosed to the Australian Dairy Corporation management that the then Chairman of the Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries, Mr Tony Webster, had agreed to the transfer of shares at an extraordinary meeting of shareholders in Indonesia in September 1976. We do not know who attended that meeting. The then Minister for Primary Industry should have been told and his approval should have been sought. He was not told, nor was he asked.

Following this 10 per cent share transfer, the history of PT Indomilk was characterised by a serious decline in the relationships between the partners and by a running down of the business. The net result of this was that the Australian Dairy Corporation, instead of having a majority on the board of directors and a minority on the board of commissioners, had its position reversed, losing control of the board of directors and gaining control of the board of commissioners. The prestigious position of president-director was transferred to Marison and its powers increased to provide full rights to bind the company in management affairs. The end result was that the Indonesian partner became the effective controller of the company, whereas the intention of the joint venture was that the ADC should, at all times, maintain control of PT Indomilk. Australian dairy farmers were literally thrown to the winds. They were not referred to, and it was done without notification to the Minister for Primary Industry or to this Parliament. The actions of the people in the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries are incomprehensible in commercial terms and irresponsible and inexcusable in regard to their responsibility to the Australian dairy industry and this Parliament.

We come next to the decision taken by the Australian Dairy Corporation during 1981 to dispose of all its interests in PT Indomilk because of the declining profitability of the company, the management takeover by the Indonesians, and a serious breakdown in partnership relations. On 20 September 1981, a heads of agreement deal was concluded between the Australian Dairy Corporation and the third party I mentioned at the start, PT Kebun Bunga, for the purchase of the Corporation's remaining shareholding of PT Indomilk. The price was $US10m. To quote another Minister in another place, apparently it seemed like a good idea at the time. I have to say that the Minister for Primary Industry received some very heavy representations from certain Ministers of the Indonesian Government. As a result, the then Minister made it quite clear to the Australian Dairy Corporation that, while he did not oppose the sale, it would need the approval of the Indonesian Government before it could go ahead.

Mr Nixon clarified his position further in a letter to the Australian Dairy Corporation on 2 June 1982 which authorised the Australian Dairy Corporation to proceed in accordance with the process laid down in Indonesian law. The new chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, Mr Malcolm Vawser, elected instead , however, to withhold this letter from the Corporation. Mr Vawser visited Jakarta with two representatives of the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries, Mr Saulwick and Mr Bruce, and had an informal meeting with representatives from PT Kebun Bunga in June 1982. At this meeting, Mr Vawser quite erroneously-that is the kindest word I can use-maintained that the Australian Dairy Corporation could not move under the heads of agreement document because of what he claimed was the attitude of the Minister for Primary Industry.

That is just incredible, and what happened two days later is perhaps the most bizarre episode in the entire PT Indomilk saga. On 9 June 1982 Mr Vawser entered into a further heads of agreement to sell the very same shares to the Corporation's partner, Marison, for $US4.5m. Mr Nixon subsequently learned late in July-it was no thanks to Mr Vawser-that his letter of 2 June had not been circulated to Australian Dairy Corporation members. He directed Mr Vawser to do this forthwith, but Nixon, when he issued this instruction, still had not been told that a second heads of agreement had been concluded.

When PT Kebun Bunga learned about the second heads of agreement it commenced legal action in both Indonesia and Australia, and I can understand why. In Indonesia, the district court of East Jakarta and the Indonesian High Court have both declared the 1981 heads of agreement to be valid and legally binding under Indonesian law, and the Australian Dairy Corporation has been ordered there to comply with the terms of the agreement. Legal costs incurred by the Australian Dairy Corporation now add up to $300,000 and industry leaders are concerned that the court actions initiated by the Corporation with Marison as an intervening plaintiff to a large extent have been encouraged by the Indonesian partner's apparent belief that PT Kebun Bunga can be knocked out of the ring by executive action.

A further matter of concern regarding the 1981 heads of agreement is that PTKB did not learn of the changes to the articles of association involving management control until March 1983. In effect, despite all the admonitions of the Rae Committee report on the need for statutory authorities to act with propriety in their overseas transactions, we have the situation where the Australian Dairy Corporation knowingly proceeded to conclude an agreement to sell its shareholding in a company in which it purported to have full control.

I turn now to the financial position of PT Indomilk. Despite this company's early entry into the Indonesian market, its share of retail sales for processed milk products has fallen from 81 per cent in 1973 to 18.3 per cent in 1981. In the past three years it has changed from a profitable enterprise into a company with a probable $13m debt to the Australian dairy industry. PT Indomilk sustained a net operating loss of $2.5m in 1981 and $2m in 1982, and when devaluation losses are taken into account the operating loss for 1983 is expected to be around $3.5m.

At the end of November 1983, PT Indomilk owed Asia Dairy Industries, and that means Australia's dairy farmers, no less than $13m. This comprised about $10.5m in respect of raw material purchases and about $2.5m for royalties, technical fees and other items. Not all supplies come from Australia but other countries' goods have been paid for in full, and Australians are left to carry the bucket. Faced with liquidity problems in Februry 1982, the Indonesian non-bank financial institutions issued promissory notes with security over all the tangible assets of PT Indomilk, with an acknowledgment by Asia Dairy Industries that all amounts owing for purchase of materials were unsecured.

The Minister, in correspondence with me on 11 July 1983, and I am prepared to table it, advised that Asia Dairy Industries did not-I repeat, not-make arrangements to borrow any moneys on behalf of PT Indomilk during 1982. The ratio of money due to Asia Dairy Industries as compared to non-bank financial institutions was very high and grew higher. Why did the Minister mislead me? Was this borrowing an offence against section 23 of the Dairy Produce Act? Will the Minister explain how the Chairman of ADC would provide a lien in these circumstances over the tangible assets of PT Indomilk?

The disaster has become further compounded. The draft balance sheet shows that $5m is owed to PT Indomilk by the Marison distributor company and $600,000 by PT Dairyville, another Marison company. Mr Nahar Zahiruddin, the president of PT Indomilk, is also on the board of Ficorinvest, which is one of the principal finance lenders to PT Indomilk. One does not need any imagination to visualise the web of intrigue.

A business arrangement was suggested by the Australian Dairy Industry Conference to inject funds into PT Indomilk or equal shares with Marison receiving a reduction in its 15 per cent distribution rate-about three times the normal allowance. Marison refused. It obviously thought the goose that lays the golden eggs should continue to be fed by Australian dairy farmers. I am going to ensure that that does not happen. Marison has continued its activities. Marison, notwithstanding its enormous debt to PT Indomilk, has sold 20,000 cartons of sweetened condensed milk at 36 per cent of the usual wholesale price on the pretence that it is below standard. But it is being sold. The loss to Australian diary farmers is $350,000. We realise why the main Federal dairy industry bodies are angry and worried about their current predicament in relation to PT Indomilk . The ADIC recently contacted the Minister, telling him all about it. He replied to the telex. (Extension of time granted.)

The Minister for Primary Industry has been in office for more than a year but he has clearly failed in his responsibility to ensure that the interests of Australian dairy farmers are adequately protected. It is just not good enough for him to reply to the telex sent last week by saying that he wants more time to consider the matter. Under this Labor Government, Australian dairy farmers have been left to fend for themselves. I put it to this House that there is a requirement for this Minister to advise the dairy industry just how the pooling situation is to be handled. This involves his making a decision on how the PT Indomilk debt will be met and how the release of further pool moneys is to be made. At the Indonesian end, the situation calls for an independent assessment of all the options, including the possible winding up of PT Indomilk. If people are asked to resign, if leaders of the ADC are to be sacked, so be it.

Finally, there is a requirement for the Minister to explain to this House why the last two reports of the Australian Dairy Corporation have failed to report properly on the situation in relation to PT Indomilk and the irregular and secretive restructuring of the company in 1980. If heads have to roll, so be it. If the Minister has any sense, any concern for Australian dairy farmers, he will act now, to make sure that one of these heads is not his own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I tabled the report of the Australian Dairy Corporation for 1982-83. That report sets out quite clearly that the Australian Dairy Corporation has a subsidiary called Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, and one of the companies with which it is related is PT Australia Indonesian Milk Industries Inc., or PT Indomilk, an Indonesian company. Asia Dairy Industries, acting on behalf of the dairy industry-that is, the producers and processors-has largely been a successful operation. There is potential in other countries in the Asian areas. The rationale behind the dairy industry's setting up the Asia Dairy Industries subsidiary is that it allows surplus products to be put into Asian markets for recombination and for manufacturing purposes, it provides an outlet for the technology and the product of industry, and it develops in the people of the region a taste for dairy products.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation that the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) related to the House pretty accurately is something that this Government has been grappling with and the previous Government grappled with for quite a while. I stress that the Asia Dairy Industries subsidiary of the Australian Dairy Corporation is largely a successful operation. The problems it has with PT Indomilk largely concentrate on the fact that bad business decisions have been taken. As the honourable gentleman has said, some disastrous decisions have been taken by the Australian Dairy Corporation.

Asia Dairy Industries handles something like $40m worth of product. I do not think the honourable gentleman suggests that we should collapse Asia Dairy Industries, but I think he suggests that we should collapse PT Indomilk. If he is saying that the Government should decide to collapse Asia Dairy Industries he is saying that we should do something which probably would imperil the subsidiary and the Government probably would have to pay out something like $13m or $14m. That would guarantee that no funds would be saved from the subsidiary, that there would never be a chance of this business coming out of the red. All the advice I have got, until quite recently, from Mr Vawser of the Australian Dairy Corporation is that by and large-some of this is on the basis of a report by Coopers and Lybrand-there is a chance that this subsidiary will trade its way out of trouble.

I wish to make one very fundamental point clear. The Australian Dairy Corporation acts in a commercial way. That is its charter. It facilitates exports and through its financial arrangements and the levy disbursement scheme it underpins the manufacturing sector of the Australian dairy industry. I am rather amazed that all of the blame can be heaped on the Government when it is the view of this Government and was the view of the past Government that in all things the Australian Dairy Corporation should take commercial decisions. The Australian Dairy Corporation's Board consists of three producers, three manufacturers, two people with special qualifications, a government nominee, a union nominee and the Chairman. They take commercial decisions. When they made the October 1981 decision my predecessor as Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, advised that they should continue to take commercial decisions. At the time I made the claim that on the evidence available to me he had interfered in one of their commercial decisions. On examining the evidence since becoming Minister-I have not gone back into his correspondence-I find that there is some ambiguity about it. People have told me other things about what occurred in relation to that crucial October 1981 board decision.

As the honourable gentleman rightly said, the ADC took a decision to let its controlling interest slip out of its hands. That was negotiated or arranged by the then Chairman, Mr Webster, but on my information-this is only the information of one of the Board members-it was later ratified by the ADC or ADI. I point out that the ADI has a different board structure-it is certainly a more commercial structure-from that of the ADC. In other words, it has a smaller board which has more members with commercial expertise. I am informed that the Board of the ADC agreed to let the controlling interest slip from its hands.

As the honourable member for Darling Downs pointed out quite rightly, two crucial decisions were taken. One was to sell it to PT Kebun Bunga and the other -I will not add all the qualifications-was later to sell it to Marisons. But there were reasons for its being sold to the two companies. That is what has got the whole situation into such a complex state. The legal ramifications of the fact that two heads of agreement have been signed are such that this Government is effectively stymied from assisting the Australian Dairy Corporation to resolve the problems that it has created. There has been a drop in the share of the market, there has been poor management in the past-long before this Government took office-and some of the other things to which the honourable gentleman has referred have taken place.

I fail to understand why the honourable gentleman cannot really say what he believes we should do about it. Is he really saying that the Government should take a decision to collapse Asia Dairy Industries and thereby guarantee that the subsidiary will collapse and that there will be no chance of any money being saved from the subsidiary? He has referred to a resolution by the Australian Dairy Industry Conference, the ADIC, which includes both producers and processors. It took a decision a few Fridays back to write to the ADC advising it that it no longer approved of the ADI Board and making a new suggestion with respect to the membership of that Board.

The ADC has to advise me. It has not advised me of its reaction to the suggestion. It does not have to act on the suggestion, as far as I understand. The view of one organisation on what should be done has simply been put to a statutory board. The ADC, as I understand it, is examining this. But changing the people on the ADI Board will not change the very basic problem. If people want to do anything about this problem they have to focus on what they are really saying and on the implications of that. I take the advice of the ADC and I insist, as did Mr Peter Nixon, that the ADC proceed to take commercial decisions on its own bat, as long as it does not break the law or audit requirements. As I have said, this problem is locked in the courts. Until the courts resolve the situation we cannot effectively sell the PTI. We have two offers, in a way, but we have two heads of agreement. The matter is locked inextricably in the courts.

I think the honourable member for Darling Downs has a fair amount of gall in trying to blame me for the whole of this problem when it was all of the previous Government's making. Certainly all of these things occurred during the time of that Government's administration of the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asia Dairy Industries subsidiary.

We have not done some of the things the previous Government did. I will not go into the history of the administration of this Corporation by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). We have been trying to grapple with the mess that we very clearly inherited. If the Government takes the decision that it will collapse the PT Indomilk subsidiary, it then has to stand behind that decision. But how can we take that decision unless the industry tells us that that is what it wants us to do? I have constantly been putting this question back to the industry. Only recently, when I clearly advised it that at the end of the day it would have to pay for its own decisions, has it even really focused on the problem.

Most of the material that the honourable gentleman quoted from was by way of a report by Mr Peter Lavery and Mr Jim Saunders. They compiled a report on the whole mess at the urging of the ADIC. Only since that report has become available has the industry focused on the problem. It is now starting to take some decisions. Quite frankly, the producers have been well aware of it. The producer representatives on the board and ADI have been swapping hats for a long time and they are key people in the dairy industry. They have known what has been there all along. They have known of the problem and they, too, have been grappling with it and have been unable to find a solution.

As I said, this scandal occurred during the time of the previous Government, even if it was not entirely of its making. The honourable member for Darling Downs is criticising equally his former colleagues as well as this Government. As we all know, the right honourable member for New England at one stage even disowned the then honourable member for Gippsland. I ask Opposition members: What did they do when in government to resolve or reduce the proportions of this scandal once it had been set rolling?

As I have said, the problem of PTI is twofold. Firstly, PTI has been unprofitable in recent years; secondly, a number of options available to the Australian Dairy Corporation to remedy this situation were closed by the ADC's decision to sell its shares to an Indonesian company unacceptable to the other partner in PTI. Both problems emerged under the previous Government. One of the consequences of PTI's continuing unprofitability is that amounts have become overdue to ADI and ADC for Australian dairy produce supplied to PTI. Unless PTI pays for this product eventually the dairy product bills will bear the loss.

As the industry knows, I have been willing to listen to the views of all groups on how any losses should be shared within the industry. Surely the Opposition is not suggesting that this Government should intervene to turn about the prospects of an Indonesian business. The ADC needs to work towards restoring PTI's profitability and underwriting any increase in the pool exposure. I have been advised by the ADC that it is pursuing both these objectives. In particular I understand that shipments of Australian products to PTI are now being made on a cash on delivery basis. What did the previous Government do about the sale of the ADC shares? Industry representatives have told me that the previous Minister 's attitude to the ADC was confused. I have already referred to that. He sent two ambiguous letters to the ADC. In the end he just tried to duck out from under by claiming that the ADC should act according to its commercial judgment. That is my advice to the ADC. I have been asking it for its advice on this question constantly.

I will turn to what this Government has done about it. Almost immediately on coming to office I initiated a full review, involving the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Trade, the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Finance, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Attorney- General's Department, to determine whether there was any action the Government could take that would resolve the matter. The review confirmed that there is little that the Government can do. We inherited this scandal made by the previous governments. It was a scandal from the beginning. Now the honourable member for Darling Downs has the nerve to ask what this Government is doing to extricate the industry from the situation. At the start of my statement I set out the problem. The whole matter is locked in the law. The dairy industry, through its own activities, got itself into this problem. I have tried to find ways and means by which the Government can do anything to assist the dairy industry in its problem. Every time I go through that exercise I am told the problem is one of law. If the honourable gentleman opposite is saying quite clearly that we should collapse the PTI subsidiary, I would first wish for the dairy industry to tell me that rather than he.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the official report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Japan and seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Japan has been presented today and, as the leader of the delegation, I would like to place on record my thanks to all members of the delegation for their support, dedication and enthusiasm during the visit to Japan. The delegation, made up of Australian Labor Party members of the Government, members of the Liberal Party of Australia, members of the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats, worked extremely well. I thank them for their support.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to thank the various government departments which assisted in the preparation-the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Special Minister of State. I also thank members of the Australian Embassy in Japan, particularly Mr Stephen Kentwell and Mr Kym Jones, the charge-d'affaires. Special thanks must go to our former Senior Parliamentary Officer, Mr Jim Pender . I say 'former' because Jim has recently taken up a senior position with the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. Our loss is its gain. Jim Pender was the perfect secretary to the delegation and a total credit to the Australian Public Service. His qualities in the diplomatic field came to the fore during the visit to Japan.

The importance of the continuation of reciprocal visits between the parliaments of Australia and Japan needs to be stressed again and again. I know that all members of the delegation support the need to build on better understandings, better relations, more trade and more visits by Australians to Japan and visits by Japanese to Australia. The status and prestige of these parliamentary exchange visits was certainly enhanced when the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, entertained a Japanese delegation in Australia in February 1984. If that action by our Prime Minister set a new standard, and I believe that it did, Japanese hosts built on that new standard and established a strong and lasting foundation for ongoing relations between Australia and Japan.

I am sure that all members of the delegation will join me in recording our sincere thanks to our hosts who ensured that our visit was as informative as possible. They met our every wish and worked tirelessly to ensure a fruitful visit. We were very fortunate indeed in meeting with Prime Minister Nakasone, or Yasu as he is known to Bob. He gave us half an hour of his very valuable time, which is all the more important when it is known that his Government was in the midst of the Tanaka affair. The President of the House of Councillors, Mr Kimura , and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Fukuda, did likewise.

We had the fortunate experience of a very formal, large reception held at the residence of the President of the House of Councillors. There was a very large turnout. I think this was partly due to the importance placed on the visit and also because a great deal of lobbying was going on by the various factions. While we were in the Parliament meeting with the House of Councillors committee we raised a number of issues, one of which was the question of sex discrimination. It was somewhat fortuitous that, in the English version of the Japan Times that evening, there was an editorial dealing with the very question of sex discrimination in Japan.

In our discussions with our Japanese hosts we adopted a two-pronged approach- trade and tourism. On the first issue we were somewhat fortunate in that our visit was a few days before the visit of President Reagan. It was clear that the United States of America was all geared up to make inroads into the Japanese markets and that these inroads would be to the disadvantage of Australia. At every opportunity members of the delegation stressed to their Japanese hosts their concern that Australia's trade with Japan should not be disadvantaged by any talks with the United States of America.

The tours that the delegation was taken on ranged from meetings with the Nuclear Safety Bureau to visits to Hiroshima, the Tokyo police headquarters, one of the large factories of the Nippon Electric Company and the Australian Embassy . I want to touch briefly on the visit to the Australian Embassy. It is a credit to Australia that we have chosen such a magnificent position for the Embassy in Japan. I am sure that those honourable members who have been there will agree with me. It consists of a very ancient garden that means a great deal to the Japanese people. People at the Embassy told us that during cherry blossom time and various festivals they receive far more visitors than any other embassy. Gardens mean a great deal to the Japanese people. In this garden in particular there was a pine tree that was over 400 years old. I was proud to find that Australia was looking after that place in trust for the Japanese people. We also paid a visit to the Ministry of Transport where we discussed tourism.

I want to touch on a couple of aspects concerning what happened when the delegation split up. A number of us went to discuss the nuclear industry. During the briefing at the Australian Embassy prior to that and in discussions with the Nuclear Safety Bureau we were advised of Japan's problems with nuclear waste disposal and of its plans to dump nuclear waste in the Pacific Ocean. There is a Government publicity campaign aimed at winning public support for the dumping of nuclear waste in the Pacific. Officials at the Nuclear Safety Bureau provided members of the delegation with publications and facts on the very serious problem of nuclear waste disposal, including a detailed account of the method proposed to be used in dumping nuclear waste in the Pacific. We were able to bring these publications back with us.

In a Press release dated December 1982 the Japanese Atomic Energy Commission recorded that, as at 31 March 1982, there were approximately 410,000 units of low level radioactive waste, each unit equivalent to 200-litre drums, stored in Japanese nuclear power station sites. It was forecast that, at the current rate of waste accumulation, 1.1 million units would be stored for disposal in 1990. Two days after our visit to the Nuclear Safety Bureau the editorial of the Asahi Evening News, the English version, covered the question of nuclear waste disposal. The editorial stated:

Even more serious is the problem of disposing of the nuclear power reactor after it completes its effective life. This will become a realistic problem in Japan in about 10 years from now. If nothing is done to resolve this, 'nuclear reactor graves' which require supervisors will spring up here and there.
The editorial continued:

If they are to be dismantled and removed, there are the problems of what to do about the radioactive waste which comes to about 10,000 tons per reactor and who will foot the cost which will come to 20 per cent of the construction cost.

The official report of the delegation has included this revealing editorial. The discussions with the Japanese Nuclear Safety Bureau canvassed all these matters, including the very serious problem of radioactive obsolete nuclear power stations which may well have to be entombed in concrete to stand as radioactive monuments for many generations. These generations will look to them and wonder what madness prevailed before we created these radioactive graveyards.

During the visit we were able to go to Hiroshima. That is the home town of my wife, so I have been there on a number of occasions. In a way, it was a return home. The delegation visited the Hiroshima peace memorial museum and park and was able to view a very recent film entitled Hiroshima and Nagasaki-The harvest of nuclear war. This film graphically illustrated the horror and madness of atomic war. The impact of this film on the members of the delegation was quite profound. Later that day we paid a visit to the Mayor of Hiroshima, who had been advised of our deep interest in the film. The Mayor made a presentation of a copy of the film, which was later presented to Mr Speaker and the President of the Senate. This film is now available through the Parliamentary Library. I understand that video copies are being made so that there will be a wider distribution.

In the short period which I have to speak to this report I do not have time to thank all those people who assisted us, both in Australia and in Japan, but once again I want to place on record our sincere thanks to Jim Pender, who was tireless in his efforts to make sure that the delegation worked well and that the timetables in particular set by our Japanese hosts were met. As leader of the delegation, I thank my friends and colleagues on the other side of the House for their support. It was very important. I think on this occasion we certainly showed a united front to the Japanese people in the very important areas of tourism and trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise to support the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) and to endorse the comments that he made about the very successful delegation to Japan between 23 October and 29 October last year. As a new member of this House I consider myself exceedingly fortunate to have been a part of that delegation. I freely acknowledge that it was due only to the temporary misfortune suffered by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom), who was to have been part of that delegation, that I was able to go. I must say, in referring to the delegation's report and in supporting the honourable member for Hindmarsh, that the trip to Japan and the participation with other members of the delegation gave us all a valuable opportunity not only to meet our counterparts in the Japanese Parliament but also to meet the Japanese people who are major trading partners of Australia and the voters of Japan-the people of Japan who, after all, are the ones who ultimately determine which of our products will be bought and which will be rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse what the honourable member for Hindmarsh has said and pay a tribute to the Japanese Government and the Presiding Officers of the Diet, firstly, for their invitation to go to Japan and, secondly, for their hospitality. Nothing was too much trouble for the people of Japan. I think that is evidenced, as the honourable member for Hindmarsh has intimated, by the willingness of the Japanese people not only to host our visit but also to see that time was made available for their Prime Minister, Mr Nakasone, to spend time with this delegation in spite of his program. I was very grateful for that. I also endorse the sentiments of the honourable member for Hindmarsh in paying a tribute to the work done by the Australian Embassy.

I agree also that the role of the charge d'affaires, Mr Kym Jones, and the role of the language officer, Mr Stephen Kentwell, deserves particular mention. The role of the Japanese Diet, the Japanese Parliament, and the efforts of the officers of the Japanese Embassy who went out of their way to make us feel at home in Japan must also be acknowledged.

I found the hospitality of our Japanese hosts almost embarrassing. It was only embarrassing in the sense that I wondered how we would reciprocate if ever they were to be our guests in Australia. I add as an aside that the weather throughout the trip was idyllic. As the program was arranged it gave all of us an opportunity to attend official receptions organised by the House of Representatives and House of Councillors, the Diet of the Japanese Parliament, and other receptions, as outlined by the honourable member for Hindmarsh, hosted by the Australian Embassy.

I think it is useful to remember that the Japanese standard of living-accepted by the Japanese people as normal-and the cost of living in Japan are very much like those in Australia. As a consequence members of the delegation found themselves very much at home in the Japanese environment. It was also significant for us, as members of the deputation, to have the opportunity to talk to those people in Japan who are for us potential trading partners. The honourable member for Hindmarsh has outlined the emphasis on trade and tourism that was part of the delegation's function. I endorse these sentiments by adding that the program allowed those of us with an agricultural bias to spend some time talking to people likely to be our potential traders in Japan. There was an opportunity in discussions with the Japanese Department of Agriculture to talk about the all important questions of beef quotas.

I guess we are all well aware of the situation of beef quotas in Japan. The briefing the Embassy staff had given us prior to meeting the representatives of the Japanese Department was entirely accurate. As the Embassy staff intimated, the Japanese people said they were keen to have Australian beef but the volume coming into Japan would be constant rather than increasing. It was then that the question was raised about further exports of mutton from Australia to Japan. The staff pointed out that one of the difficulties with mutton was that Japanese really have not developed a taste for sheep meat and that even promotion of sheep meat in Japan would be difficult because it would involve a change in traditional Japanese cooking habits.

A fellow member of the delegation, the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron), pursued the question of grain imports into Japan. He raised what was, for the Japanese, a very interesting aside when he suggested there might be opportunities for trade in buckwheat. The Japanese certainly agreed there were opportunities in the noodle and pancake market for expansion to accommodate more Australian buckwheat. They pointed out that another area of expansion related to lucerne hay and chaff for stock feed. Sadly our trade in wheat grain is likely to be static.

The interview with trading partners in Japan also gave us an opportunity to pursue the question of horticultural crops. The requirement for ethylene dibromide fumigation that has currently become unpopular in Japan for health reasons gave us a chance to point out to Japanese counterparts that there could be opportunities to open up trade in Japan in view of the fact that there are fruit fly free areas in Australia that would not require the same elaborate levels of quarantine. I stress by way of these remarks the extraordinary opportunity that this tour gave the delegation to meet face to face with trading partners. I also say how much I appreciate the direct interest shown by Mr David Spencer, the Acting Senior Trade Commissioner, in precisely what was happening in Australian agriculture and the opportunities for Australian agriculture to expand into the Japanese market.

I now refer to another major area touched on by the honourable member for Hindmarsh which I would like to elaborate on a little further. This is the area of defence, a very sensitive area to Japanese people because of their very unhappy experience in the Second World War. Honourable members will appreciate the importance of the question of defence to the Japanese community and the strategic importance of Japan to the Australian community. I quote from the delegation's report two paragraphs that relate to defence:
The Japanese basic defence concept described in Defence of Japan 1983, a Defence Agency publication, is in two parts-

(1) Prevention of Armed Invasion Japan's basic defence policy is to possess a defence capability of appropriate scale, to organise a system for the most efficient operation of such defence capability and to keep the credibility of the security arrangements with the United States and ensure their smooth implementation with a view to reinforcing a defence system proficient in coping with any type of aggression and thereby deterring aggression. And, Japan relies on the U.S. nuclear deterrent power to counter nuclear threat.

(2) Countering aggression In the event of indirect aggression or an unlawful act using military power that could lead to aggression, Japan will take responsive action immediately to bring the situation under control at an early stage.

In the event of direct aggression, Japan will take responsive action immediately to force back such aggression at the earliest possible stage through the comprehensive and organic operation of defence capability. In this case, Japan will drive away limited and small-scale aggression without outside help in principle. Even in case the scale and type of aggression makes it hard for Japan to deal with alone, Japan will continue strong resistance by every possible means until it gains co-operation from the United States in repulsing the enemy.

I think we all appreciate the importance of defence treaties with Japan not only to the Japanese but also to Australian citizens. As the honourable member for Hindmarsh outlined, the visit gave us opportunities to talk with people of the Defence Agency, the Traffic Administration Centre and the Nippon Electric Co. and, for one member of the delegation, the opportunity to talk to peace classes in schools. Other members of the delegation spoke with people particularly concerned with the question of nuclear arms and nuclear power. There were opportunities for others of us in the delegation to speak with departments of agriculture, trade and industry and to see the Sakai factory of Nippon Steel.

In the tourism area already outlined by the honourable member for Hindmarsh there were opportunities to see the shrines, temples and castles so unique to the Japanese community. The trip provided also an opportunity to meet the Japanese people themselves. The hospitality and very gregarious nature of the Japanese people was something I found pleasantly surprising. Whether it was in the foyer of the hotel or in the bullet train, no task and no request for directions was met with other than a friendly smile and assistance. I pay a tribute to the Japan-Australia Association, so much a part of hosting us when we were in regional parts of Japan. I also say how much I appreciated the role played, in a very low-key manner, by Mrs Scott, the wife of the leader of the delegation. Mrs Scott, who is a guest in the gallery, certainly proved to be a key that opened a number of doors in Japan that otherwise would not have been as easily opened. I thank the leader of the delegation for his consideration in allowing Mrs Scott to accompany the delegation. I am sure all members of the delegation will agree that, because of Mrs Scott's Japanese background, we were even more warmly received when she came with us to a number of civic functions.

Finally, the delegation was an opportunity to get to know honourable members on the other side of the House and members of other political parties. I think it is worth placing on the record that some time in this House, some time working on parliamentary committees and, I trust, some time in delegations such as this, helps us to discover that this House, the Parliament and Australia are not really a community of them and us. There are a number of things we have in common. We realise there are a number of objectives and interests common to all Australians which we are endeavouring to pursue. The week away with this delegation only served to reinforce those ideas.

I too thank Mr Pender for his function in keeping the delegation on time and seeing that the various needs of members of the delgation were met. I have to say that there were parts of the draft report about which I was unhappy. These were areas relating to defence, sex discrimination and nuclear power generation. I acknowledge that in those areas the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Hindmarsh, has not allowed his ideas to dominate in the final report. I am grateful for that consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Mrs H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I should like to pay a very deeply felt tribute to the leadership of the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) on the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Japan. It was a very difficult job because none of us had very much experience on delegations, particularly of the very formal type of the delegation to Japan. The honourable member for Hindmarsh was an excellent leader who was of great assistance to all of us and gave the Australian delegation a very good name in Japan. I thank him for his assistance. It was certainly delightful that he was able to be accompanied by Mrs Scott.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to mention three things which were of importance to me. One was the opportunity to speak with Mrs Tamako Nakanishi, a member of the House of Councillors in Japan and one of the 27 women members of the Japanese Parliament. The contact I was able to make with her and the continuing correspondence we have had gives us a point of contact in sharing news of importance to women, both in Australia and in Japan. In Japan the issue of sex discrimination legislation is important and is an area in which Japanese women are encountering some difficulties. It is of very great interest to me and to Mrs Nakanishi that we are able to share information about the progress of sex discrimination legislation and its reception in our respective countries.

The discussion of nuclear safety issues was very instructive in one unusual aspect, that is, that it was completely open. One of the great difficulties about the discussion of nuclear power generation and uranium mining is that a great deal of the discussion is based on mystification, misleading statements, optimistic statements and-not to put too fine a point on it-lies. One gets the uneasy feeling that if that is going on there has to be something to hide. In Japan the discussion we had was very straightforward and open. The problems of nuclear power generation were stated quite openly and straightforwardly. It was of very great assistance to us to have that sort of discussion, honest and open as it was, to discuss problems such as nuclear waste disposal. For a nation which regards technological solutions to technological problems as something that is possible, and possible within a reasonably short time, it was instructive to know that the Japanese have not found that there is a technological solution to the storage of high level wastes which is practical in the future or even in the distant future. I might say that they were able to say that while they continued to stress the importance to them of nuclear power generation.

One of the things they discovered about Australian uranium mining that had not really been brought to their attention before was the ecological problems we encounter here, particularly the risk of water pollution, which the Japanese regard as being very serious indeed. It is something about which we as Australians should be particularly careful.

All the high schools and primary schools in Hiroshima have peace education syllabuses. I was able to visit a junior high school which has a particular interest in peace education as it was virtually totally destroyed by the atomic bomb in 1945. Part of its curriculum stresses the always poor results of aggressive behaviour on the part of nations. The Japanese are not afraid to blame themselves for their own actions and they are not afraid to accept consequences of those actions. They have suffered consequences from aggressive acts which no other nation has suffered. They are quick and consistent in making it perfectly plain that they know about the effects of nuclear war, that their children will know about its effects, and that nobody in Japan will be allowed to forget, or to put aside as unimportant, those effects. The school is engaged in a very carefully organised peace curriculum which goes into Japanese history as well as the events of the Second World War and following the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima. One of the things the school does is attempt to trace the names of the children and teachers who were destroyed at that school in that blast. So far they have not been able to find the names of more than 100 of the 210 people who were lost on that day.

I thank the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells) and his sister, Miss Marguerite Wells, who assisted me in making contact with the school I visited- the Midorimachi Junior High School. I am grateful also for the efforts of the Foreign Affairs Department and the House of Representatives Department, which formalised the arrangements for that visit. It was very interesting to find that Japanese and Australian school children have far more in common than they have separating them, that they behave in much the same way, that they enjoy the same sorts of things, and that they find foreign visitors just as curious a phenomenon.

I finish by saying that, although the Australian Ambassador was not in Japan at the time we were there, his wife, Lady Currie, is a superb ambassadress for Australia. I thank her for her hospitality and help. I add my thanks to those of the other members of the delegation to all the people who assisted us and for the very warm and courteous hospitality of the Japanese people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join with the previous speakers in recording my appreciation to this Parliament for the opportunity to be a member of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation which visited Japan in October 1983. It was a great honour for me to visit one of the great democratic countries of the free world. It was an honour to be a visitor to many cities in Japan. It was a great honour to have the opportunity of meeting the Prime Minister of Japan, Mr Nakasone. As the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) rightly said, the Prime Minister of Japan made his time available to speak with us, notwithstanding his extremely busy schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: I was made aware forcefully during my visit to Japan that the destinies of Japan, Australia and New Zealand are inextricably linked. The fortunes of each of those three countries will continue to work in tandem and, hopefully, in harmony during the ages ahead. To that end, I was pleased to ascertain that the Japanese tourist industry is extremely keen to develop in the Japanese people an interest in visiting Australia and New Zealand. It was pointed out that some four million Japanese travel overseas each year but that only some 40,000 visit Australia each year.

We constantly came up against a sense of inquiry in the Japanese people. Conditions in Australia, our wide open spaces, our flora and fauna, whether we had potable drinking water, whether we had interpreters at our hotels, were questions that were constantly put to us in the cities and places which we visited in Japan. To that end, discussions have continued here in Canberra with officials from the Japanese Embassy to develop a program whereby Japanese visitors can be encouraged to visit Australia through the north Queensland gateways of Townsville and Cairns.

As I have mentioned in this House, later this year Air Pacific Ltd will establish a new air link between Fiji and Townsville. This will enable Japanese visitors to Fiji to connect through Townsville and thereby establish a lasting acquaintance with Australia.

Japan is also Australia's greatest trading partner. Many discussions were held with various officials on developing new trade links. Trade between north Queensland and Japan was a topic of conversation at meetings that I had with trade officials in Tokyo. The hospitality of the Australian Embassy in Japan should be recorded as being unstinting. The courtesy and assistance rendered to the delegation by Mr Jim Pender, Mr Jones and Mr Kentwell of the Australian Embassy in Japan and by the wife of the Australian Ambassador must be recorded.

To sum up, it was clear to me from my visit to Japan that not only will tourism links and additional trade links be developed between Australia and Japan, but inevitably-I should touch on this subject-in time we will see immigration from Japan to Australia. During my visit it was expressed to me that there were a number of suitably qualified, indeed I might say eminently qualified, Japanese who would seek to emigrate to Australia to participate in the great work in this country of building a bigger and better nation. I refer to that continuing work which is the destiny of us all. So to this Parliament I say: 'Thank you for allowing me the opportunity to participate in what I consider to be an historic delegation to Japan'. I record my gratitude for the excellent company and courtesy extended to me by my co-delegates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the sixth report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENGINE RUN-UP FACILITY, RAAF BASE, DARWIN

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of facilities for a tactical fighter squadron, RAAF Base, Darwin, Northern Territory-Engine run-up facility.

The proposal is for the construction of an interim engine run-up facility for the period that No. 75 Squadron, Royal Australian Air Force, is based at Darwin and a noise barrier between the facility and a new maintenance hangar. The work is an element of a major proposal referred to the Public Works Committee on 21 December 1981 for the provision of facilities for the permanent basing of a fighter squadron at RAAF Base, Darwin. The Committee's third report of 1982 recommended construction of the work with the exception of the engine run-up facility. At that time the Committee was not satisfied that the design and siting of the facility would reduce noise emissions from aircraft engines to acceptable levels during testing. The Committee called for further investigation and advice to enable a further report to Parliament on this component.

Honourable members will recall that last year the Hawke Government decided to proceed with interim works only at Darwin and that the permanent fighter base should be at the Tindal Base near Katherine. A $167m proposal for the Tindal Base was referred to the Committee in December 1983 and its report is expected to be tabled later during the autumn sittings.

Details of a revised engine run-up facility on a new site at RAAF Base, Darwin, to provide interim facilities for No. 75 Squadron were provided to the Committee late in 1983 and in February 1984. The Committee has reported that there is a need for engine run-up facilities, that the site chosen is suitable and that the design of the facility is adequate. The Committee concluded that the proposed noise barrier should reduce to acceptable levels noise levels in a new RAAF maintenance hangar nearby. In recommending construction of the work, the Committee recommended that hours of operation of the engine run-up facility should be restricted to those permitted under noise pollution legislation and that all practicable measures be undertaken to minimise the impact of engine testing on personnel working in or around the maintenance hangar.

The Department of Defence has already advised the Committee as to measures which can be taken to ensure that the facility will be operated at times and in a manner, designed to minimise noise nuisance, and I do not envisage that ther will be insurmountable problems for the period that the facility will be used. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $380,000 at January 1984 prices. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning and construction can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate to the House, both in my capacity as Vice-Chairman of the Public Works Committee and as shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, my support for the motion moved by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). The Minister is to move three other similar motions: One is in connection with the munitions filling factory at St Marys, another is connected with facilities for the Australian frigate project at the Williamstown Naval Dockyard and the third is in respect of the construction of a new building for the Australian Film and Television School at North Ryde. While on my feet I take the opportunity also to indicate the support of the Opposition for the motions which will be moved shortly. I point out to the House that in the main the projects were initiated during the period of the former Government and some planning work was carried out during that period. I am pleased, therefore, that the present Government has decided to proceed with the projects as part of the Commonwealth works program.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MUNITIONS FILLING FACTORY, ST MARYS, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford)-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Reconstruction of the pyrotechnic section at the Munitions Filling Factory, St Marys, New South Wales.

The proposal is for the construction of six industrial-type single storey production buildings and associated engineering works and amenities buildings to accommodate improved and updated munitions filling equipment being acquired by the Department of Defence Support. The Committee has reported that there is a need to redevelop the pyrotechnic section of the factory, that the designs of the proposed buildings are satisfactory and that the sites selected for the proposed buildings are suitable. The Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference at the estimated cost of $13m, at August 1983 prices. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning and reconstruction can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated to the House a few minutes ago, the Opposition supports this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FRIGATE PROJECT, WILLIAMSTOWN NAVAL DOCKYARD, VICTORIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of facilities for the Australian Frigate Project, Williamstown, Naval Dockyard, Victoria, Phase A.

The proposal is for the construction of facilities essential for the construction of FFG-type frigates, and covers those initial works necessary for the efficient construction of the frigates. The major elements of the proposed work are as follows: Unit blasting facility, shipbuilding platens, upgrading of cranage, kevlar and painters' workshops, covering of parts marshalling area, modifications to dockyard store and miscellaneous engineering services. The Committee has reported that there is a need to provide additional facilities indentified to augment existing facilities for the construction of FFG-7 type frigates at the dockyard, that this work appears adequate and will supplement existing facilities, and that improvements in productivity should result.

In recommending construction of the work, the Committee recommended that interim measures designed to optimise the utilisation of existing off-street car parks, including the provision of additional entry points, should be implemented . The estimated cost of the work if $6.1m at December 1983 prices. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning and construction can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion also has the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FILM AND TELEVISION SCHOOL, NORTH RYDE, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of a new building for the Australian Film and Television School, North Ryde, New South Wales.

The proposal is for the construction of new facilities on a site of 3.6 hectares of land at Macquarie University, North Ryde. The elements of the work comprise: Three television and film studios; seating for 250 in two small theatres; a dubbing theatre; two radio studios; an administrative library; training areas; workshops and research and technical support areas; landscaping and car parking.

The Committee has reported that there is a need to provide new accommodation for the Australian Film and Television School, that the design of the proposed building is satisfactory and that the site selected for the proposed building is suitable. The Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference at the estimated cost of $13m at August 1983 prices, provided that every effort is made to obtain financial support from film and television industry sources. The Committee asked that the government should review funding policies which do not enable organisations such as the Australian Film and Television School to experience real benefit from any external financial support .

With regard to the school seeking cost recoveries from film and television industry bodies, I have been advised that a significant level of cost recovery has already been achieved through fees in the School's open program. In levying fees the School is seeking to maintain a balance between the users' capacity to pay for the courses and the meeting of its statutory obligations to provide training in film, television and radio broadcasting. As regards the wider issues canvassed in the report on the seeking of financial assistance from the Australian film and television industries, I am advised that these will be further explored by the School and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). These issues will obviously take some time to resolve and in the meantime it would be appropriate for the House to consider the matter of proceeding with the building proposal. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning and construction can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Commitee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am again pleased to have the opportunity of indicating the Opposition's support for this motion to construct a new building for the Australian Film and Television School.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the terms of the printed proposals which are now being circulated to honourable members, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 5 (1984).

I do so on behalf of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown). The proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 5 (1984 ) operate on and from 6 April 1984 and contain a variety of amendments. The developing country margin of preference applicable to imports of fireworks for the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong and Taiwan Province is being modified. In its report on Miscellaneous Manufacturing (Groups D, F and H) the Industries Assistance Commission had found that imports of fireworks from China which accounted for a major part of the Australian market had injured the local industry. Imports from Hong Kong and Taiwan Province had also been substantial. In view of this, the Government has decided that the duty on imports from all three sources should be increased from free to 15 per cent. The Canadian preference margin currently applicable to certain steel products will be continued beyond 8 Aprial 1984. The Current Margin of preference will be maintained throughout the phasing period applicable to the general tariff rates for these goods.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 5 also insert a new legal note to chapter 97 of the Customs Tariff Act. This note ensures that gymnasium equipment remains classified in that chapter and maintains levels of protection applicable to such goods. It also ensures that their classification is in accord with the views of the Customs Co-operation Council. The amendment to item 58.09 in schedule 3 is in a similar vein to the amendment to chapter 97. The Customs Co-operation Council has ruled that knitted lace is not classified in 58.09 and this amendment gives that ruling legal force in the Australian Tariff.

Provision is being made in the tariff for imports of wooden furniture components from South Pacific Forum island countries to be granted duty free entry, subject to quota limitations. This is being done following requests from concessional admission for such goods from those countries. The wording of sub- item 39.01.5 in schedule 3 is being amended to remove an ambiguity which has been detected in it. Amendments are being made to the designation of certain countries and places eligible for declared preference country and developing country preferences. These changes are necessary following the granting of independence or the changing of the names of the countries or places in question .

The final amendment contained in the proposals is an administrative one to correctly express two New Zealand rate references in schedule 5 in terms of the relevant tariff classifications set out in schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act. A summary of the alterations contained in these proposals has been prepared and is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned earlier this afternoon I was referring to the important priority that this Government attaches to roads. I pointed out that this year $1,233m is being made available for work on national highways, urban and rural arterial roads and local roads and that that amount represents a 45 per cent increase in Federal expenditure on roads last year. With reference to the detail of the amendment, which refers to the indexation of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund surcharge, let me repeat what I said earlier. It is clearly inappropriate for the Government to respond definitively to this issue at this time. SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on this note: The deplorable state of Australia's roads is not something that has occurred since 5 March 1983. Responsibility for the deplorable state of roads in Australia today rests with those who constituted the conservative governments for some 30 years since World War II. I also deplore the attacks that have been made upon the employees of public road authorities. I think they are best described and are most to be deplored as they appear on page 1347 of Hansard. They were uttered by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), who stated that State road authorities tend to get too fat, too lazy and too bureaucratic. I find it incredible that members of the National Party of Australia, which purports to represent people who live and work in the country and in country towns, should have such an attitude towards the people whom they claim to represent-country road workers. I thank honourable members for the contributions they have made to the debate. I move:
