SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one who introduced the bicentennial road development program into this Parliament, I am terribly disturbed on a number of counts that the Government has taken the action it has taken. As the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) has pointed out, the Government will give away $491m between now and 1988 as a result of not passing on the value of the indexation to roads built under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act. I think it is a disgrace that, at a time when there is so much need and demand to improve the road system in this country, the bicentennial road program should have been dealt with in this fashion. It is not good enough for the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) to say that we did not make provision in the Act for indexation. We never had any intention of indexing taxes in the manner in which the Hawke Labor Government has indexed them.
—What they have done is daylight robbery.

—It is daylight robbery on several counts. It is daylight robbery against the taxpayers of this country and it is daylight robbery against the motorists of this country, who are contributing to a trust fund to benefit roads . I am also disturbed that the Minister has given in to the States on two counts . Firstly, he has allowed the State road authorities to get around the tendering and contract system for construction of highways and national roads. The State road authorities have never wanted anything other than the flexibility they have always had, a flexibility they have used for day labour purposes. I am certain that nobody in this Parliament, not even the Minister, would have his house built by day labour. Who in this place would have his home built or have work done by day labour? Most of us want quotes and most of us call for tenders. Most of us want the best value for the dollar spent, whether it be on roads, private construction, the building of a home or anything else.

SPEECH.PARA: We are spending $5,000m a year on roads, all of it coming from either taxpayers or ratepayers through three sources-the Commonwealth, State and local governments. I think it is incredible that the public has now been asked to put up with a system that has not served this country well. Billions of dollars are being spent on roads in this country and billions of dollars are being wasted. We have only to drive around the countryside to see how day labour works. Plant is left at the side of the road for days on end, not being used. We have a tremendous opportunity to make the best use of the contract system. There is a shortage of work and a shortage of opportunities. One would have thought that the Minister and the Government would have stuck to the tender and contract system, which was working so well in the States. Sure, the State Ministers did not like it. They and their State road authorities wanted the flexibility the Minister has now provided them with to use the State road authorities' resources if they so wished and to use Commonwealth money to do it.

The other thing to which I take great exception is letting the States off the hook so far as their public transport systems are concerned. This Bill allows the State governments to reduce their level of expenditure on public transport from their own resources and make up the difference from the bicentennial road program in capital purchases of buses and whatever. It enables them to keep fares down to a ridiculously low level for commuters in metropolitan areas, if you like, costing in New South Wales $1.8m a day. The State Transport Commission in New South Wales has a $1.8m a day loss. Just recently the State Government purchased no fewer than 200 brand new Mercedes buses from Germany and five ferries, including a hydroplane, for Sydney Harbour from the Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund. Sure, they can do it under the Act, but they are going to subsidise an ailing, inefficient transport system that is doing nobody any good.

It is unbelievable that the Commonwealth Government would enable the States to subsidise their own inefficient transport systems in the way that they will under this arrangement. They should have been held to their end of the bargain. I think the Minister and his Government have destroyed to a very large extent the value of the disciplines that were inherent in the Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund. I thought this program would have done much to put our roads right by 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you ever do for roads in my electorate?

—What did I do for roads? The honourable member has asked the right man. The biggest boost to roads expenditure occurred while I was the Minister. The Government would not be able to boast about a 45 per cent increase in roads expenditure if it had not been for the bicentennial road program. I must say to my listeners in the Gwydir electorate that they had no hope at all until this bicentennial road program came to be. The people in my electorate have received a total of four bridges. The electorate covers one-third of New South Wales, and it has received four bridges from the bicentennial road program. I ask the Minister why he hates the north-western part of New South Wales. Why does he hate these country areas as much as he does?

SPEECH.PARA: It is an outrage that this Minister and his Government have prostituted the purpose of the bicentennial road program and have given in so badly and so weakly to the pressures imposed upon them by some of the State Ministers and road authorities, who no doubt will use the program to subsidise their inefficient State public transport systems and get their own financial systems in order. I think the Minister has let the side down. I do not think he ever liked the program. When he was in Opposition, as shadow Minister he was one of the few people who questioned the bicentennial road program. I remember one of his colleagues coming over to me and saying: 'Why does Morris hate the bicentennial road program?' I said: 'Because he did not think of it'. I say to honourable members opposite that they should not be too hard on the program. I can assure them that it is the best thing that has happened for roads in this country. They must not let those State Ministers of either political colour put it over them or let the State road authorities go on with the old day labour approach, doing the job in their own style, in their own way, in their own time. If we allow that to happen we will see $5,000m a year from Commonwealth, State and local governments squandered in a way that I think shows contempt for the ratepayers and taxpayers in this country.

—Is the Minister for Transport proposing to close the debate?
—I am proposing to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984 as they are related measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering those measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three measures which are before us-the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984, the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984-form a package of legislation, some of which is of great importance, some of which is of less importance. The Opposition opposes the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill. The Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill is, of course, consequential and we have no view that we think necessary to express on that Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary to understand the essential objects intended to be achieved by the package which is before us, in particular the amendments to the Judiciary Act and the amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act. It has been said in the second reading speech of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) that the purpose of the amendments now before the House in relation to the Judiciary Act is essentially to relieve the work load of the High Court of Australia and to make some amendments establishing an office of the Australian Government Solicitor. The amendments designed to achieve a lessening of the work load of the High Court amount to these: First of all, the curtailment of all appeals as of right from State supreme courts of appeal; secondly, the curtailment of all appeals or, to be more accurate in each case, the abolition of all appeals as of right from the Federal Court of Australia; thirdly, enlarging the power to remit to include a number of areas of exclusive jurisdiction of the High Court so that the High Court will be empowered to remit to the Federal Court matters presently falling within its exclusive jurisdiction . The amendment is necessary to achieve that purpose because of the fact that these matters now fall within the High Court's exclusive jurisdiction.

I will come back to those matters in a few minutes. I should like to say something briefly at the outset about the proposal to establish an Australian Government Solicitor. The proposal to establish the Australian Government Solicitor is a very difficult one to understand. One assumes that legislation is usually brought before the House with a purpose and that if one examines the legislation, whether one agrees with what it says or whether one disagrees with what it says, it at least will have an underlying purpose behind it and a purpose which is not simply cosmetic.

The Deputy Prime Minister tells us and the explanatory memorandum tells us that it is proposed to replace the office of Crown Solicitor with this corporate body -the Australian Government Solicitor-as a firm name for Australian Government work. What does this achieve? What are the advantages? Where is the public demand for this? Where is the demand in terms of efficiency of operation? No explanation on these matters is given to us and none could be. It is purely cosmetic and we are going to have in place of the office of the Crown Solicitor a body without a soul to be damned or a backside to be kicked. I suppose there is something somewhere to be said for that, but on examination no argument appears except perhaps it may be-I do not know, this is simply speculation-that the desire of the Government is to eradicate any symbols which tie the Government to the Crown. Having disposed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you read the Attorney-General's speech?

—I have read the speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans ), which is an astonishing piece of work when one considers how important the legislation is which is brought before this House and which seeks to justify-I now turn to the major question-the alterations proposed to the High Court's jurisdiction on the basis of work load and gives no information whatsoever to the House. I have sought to overcome that difficulty. I seek the leave of the Deputy Prime Minister to incoporate in Hansard three pages of statistical information on the work of the High Court. The information has been obtained by me from the office of the Registrar of the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This is the sort of information that the Attorney -General, if he wished to inform the public and inform Parliament, should have put before the Senate and it should have been put before this House. It tells us of the kind of work and the work load of the High Court over the years 1980, 1981, 1982 and 1983. But the Attorney-General has not placed this information before us. What does it tell us? I will touch on only a few of the details which appear. It tells us that, in 1980, 45 appeals were heard by the High Court and, in 1983, 40 appeals were heard. It tells us that in 1980 there was a total of 63 special leave applications determined by the High Court. In 1983 there were 50. It tells us that there were 28 criminal special leave applications determined by the High Court in 1980 and 37 in 1983. Taking all of the matters heard by the High Court-I speak here of the Full Court-whether they be appeals, objection to competency of appeals, special leave applications, order nisi and applications referred to the Full Court, matters brought before the court under section 18 of the Judiciary Act, matters before the court under section 40, electoral petitions and other applications, we have 184 matters in 1980 and 174 in 1983. Incidentally, there were 105 sitting days in 1980 and 104 in 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: That in itself does not show any marked increase in the work load of the High Court. On the bare figures, the work load would appear to be diminishing. But bare figures in themselves can be misleading. It is necessary to bear in mind that matters coming before the High Court these days can be of an exceedingly complex nature. The tendency is for very complex cases to come before the High Court. That can mean that the High Court has to spend more time determining a case than it would in the case of a fairly simple matter. Usually the average hearing time is within a day. Matters such as the dams case take longer. The dams case took seven and a half sitting days and the Chamberlain case took four sitting days. A great deal of time is required to write judgments in cases of that kind. Again, in order to put matters in context, it is worth while remembering that in 1983, whilst the actual figures declined, the Court gave judgments in a number of very important matters, such as the dams case, Chamberlain v. the Queen, the hospital contributions case, Sorby v. the Commonwealth, which was a case involving privilege against self-incrimination, Baker v. Campbell, a case of professional privilege, and two cases concerning bottom of the harbour legislation. I am indebted to the office of the High Court for assisting me with some information as to its workings.

I suspect that the work load is increasing. I suspect that there is an inevitable upward trend in that work load. I am very sympathetic of the arguments put on behalf of the High Court. But I think, when we look at the Court and when we look at the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No.2) and what this Bill will achieve, we need to consider the High Court's place not only in our legal system but also in the Australian community. We need to consider the nature of the work load which it presently has and which it foreseeably will have and then , of course, the effect of what is proposed by the Judiciary Amendment Bill in taking away rights of appeal which presently exist.

The High Court's place in our country and in our legal system is of immeasurable importance; it is the apex of our judicial system. The qualities of its members, the lucidity of thought and exposition that they bring to their work, the depth and breadth of learning which they have displayed over the years , have given the High Court an enviable and well-earned reputation throughout the world. It is a court of truly international stature; one whose stature far outweighs Australia's importance in world affairs.

It is invidious to make comparisons with other State courts or with courts of the States but, for the purpose of the argument, I think I must. Some great justices have not been appointed to the High Court. I can think of Mr Justice Jordan, Chief Justice of New South Wales, who was a very famous lawyer. Generally, appointments to the High Court are the best we have and can offer. To the practising lawyer, in a hard case it is the court of final appeal. I am very glad that the appeals to the Privy Council have gone even though I have in the past profited from the existence of that appellate tribunal's jurisdiction over Australian affairs.

Let us remember one thing: State courts are variable. There are good State courts and there are State courts whose quality is not so good. The great value of the High Court is that, as the final arbiter, it can be seen as the court controlling finally the operation of the court system within this country and the court that provides the final answer. If one is dissatisfied with the decision given by the court of appeal then one has a place to go. Honourable members should remember this: In the past there have been cases-it is not unusual-where the court of first instance reached one dicision, that decision was then affirmed by the court of appeal and the High Court then overturned both those courts' decisions. That will not arise in the future, save where special leave is granted.

Let me say something about the work load. I think I have outlined the nature of the work load that the High Court presently has to accept; it is a very onerous one. But, assuming that, and sympathetic as I am to the views expressed by the justices since I suppose in some ways, as a lawyer, the High Court is one of my very few remaining illusions, when one looks at the effect of the elimination of certain appeal processes, one sees that there is a powerful case on the part of the average litigant or the non-average litigant to say: 'No, you are moving too quickly. You should not do this'.

Dealing briefly with the power to remit, I was interested to note that the effect of what is proposed would be to enable the remittance of certain matters to the Federal Court now within the High Court's exclusive jurisdiction, but not matters in which a writ of mandamus or prohibition is sought against an officer of the Commonwealth or a Federal Court. This Government intends to remit matters arising under any treaty or to empower the High Court to remit those matters. In general I have no quarrel with the power to remit; it is a very valuable power. But whilst treaties may be remitted, matters where a writ of mandamus or prohibition is sought may not. Of course, we all know that the major way in which questions are brought up to the High Court-indeed, I believe the only way but I stand subject to correction-relating to industrial matters before the conciliation and arabitration tribunal for the purposes of determining whether that tribunal has jurisdiction, is by mandamus or prohibition. There is no reason at all why these matters could not go off to the Federal Court. That seems to indicate some kind of special treatment to the industrial interests of this Government. If there is another reason I would like to hear it.

Moving on from remittance, what we now have in the important parts is the abolition of an appeal as of right and, in particular, the abolition of an appeal as of right under section 35(3) of the Judiciary Act. A corresponding amendment is to be made to the Federal Court of Australia Act. As matters presently stand, if the dispute is over a matter of $20,000 or upwards and it is a final judgment from the Full Court of a State Supreme Court, there is an absolute right of appeal.

It is argued by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) in their second reading speeches that it is not appropriate to judge matters on such a basis. It is said by them that it is generally acknowledged that a financial test is not really an appropriate test for determining whether there should be an appeal as of right. It would have been useful for the purposes of informing the public if the Attorney-General had turned his mind in his second reading speech to the history of the power in the Judiciary Act-the right in the Judiciary Act-to have an appeal to the High Court . Had the Attorney-General done so he would have found that when the Act was originally passed by this Parliament in 1903 it contained a provision which in effect corresponded with the provisions now before the House but in which the limit was 300 pounds. He would have seen that at various times there have been rather limited increases in the amount that gave the right of appeal. That was so until an amendment was made to the Judiciary Act in 1976 when the amount was $3,000.

It says something about the validity of the argument that a financial test is not an appropriate one when we have had that test for 80 years or so. I do not suggest it is a perfect test. I can see the arbitrary nature of it. But who are the people who are going to go up to the High Court under the law as it now stands but who will be denied access to that court under the proposed new provisions? I give an example of a case recently which went to the High Court. It concerned an old man with bad eyesight who was involved in an accident. He went to the Supreme Court of New South Wales and received a verdict from that Court. He was then taken to the Court of Appeal and that verdict was taken away from him. The matter was purely a question of fact.

In considering the rules relating to special leave applications and the principles laid down over the years one must remember that for one to succeed in a special leave application one must demonstrate that there are distinct features about the case which one has presented which make it special and which discharge, as it were, the onus of convincing the High Court that leave should be granted. The plaintiff in Henderson v. Public Transport Commission of New South Wales would, I should have thought, have in future no prospects of getting to the High Court, yet he did. The High Court restored the verdict of the trial judge. That was in a case decided on 5 November 1981. Another case of a similar kind concerned the State of South Australia v. Johnson, where again the appeal was allowed from a judgment of the Full Court. That was purely a factual case. The High Court said, in a joint judgment of that court, that in the end the decision has become entirely one of fact.

Fact cases simply do not get to the High Court in special leave matters unless the fact cases are quite extraordinary. Clearly the consequence of what is proposed is the exclusion of the vast majority of cases where the Court of Appeal has gone wrong. That means therefore that there is no avenue left open. There is proposed to be substituted for the right of appeal in those sorts of cases, where the amount involved is $20,000 or more, a need to justify special leave being granted. As well there is a proposal to substitute certain rights in respect of constitutional matters, although I doubt whether those particular matters are really greatly affected. If I have time I will come back to that point.

It seems to me that the substantial question is what is going to happen in cases concerning the average plaintiff who gets knocked down or is injured in his factory, who does not get justice out of his local legal system and who would have but one recourse, that being to the High Court? Unless he is able to establish that there are such special and distinctive features about his case that special leave should be granted his prospects of getting to the High Court in future are poor indeed. It can be said that he has had his day in court and it can be said that since he has gone through two courts-the court of first instance and the court of appeal in his State-he has had a fair run. I come back to what I said earlier. State courts in this country are of variable standards. They vary from State to State and they vary within the States from time to time. Anyone acquainted with the court systems of the States would know that at some times in a particular State there will be a very good court of appeal-perhaps an outstanding one-but at other times the court of appeal is of a far more mixed quality. In that case what is to be done?

What is proposed is that the plaintiff or the defendant will be left essentially with no recourse except, as I said, where that person can satisfy the High Court that special leave should be granted. This affects not only the ordinary plaintiff-the person who concerns me is the blood and bones plaintiff, as it is said in the trade; the person whose body has been damaged and whose mind has been disturbed by what has happened to him-but also people who have important commercial transactions and who go to court about those transactions. Perhaps no great question of law is involved but a large amount of money may be involved. Millions of dollars may be involved. They also are to be denied access to the High Court unless they can establish that there is some special feature of their case which requires the examination of the High Court.

I remind the House of how essential it is in a special leave application that the special features of that case be established in the application. It is on the applicant to make out a case. He has an onus to discharge and it is not an easy onus by any means. We know that it is proposed that the High Court go to Sydney and Melbourne to hear special leave applications, and so it should. If it is to be available only by means of special leave applications, effectively that means that anybody who goes to it must go through four hearings. These are, the hearing at first instance and the hearing before the appellate tribunal-be it the State appeals tribunal or the Federal appeals tribunal. Next there is the application for special leave and lastly, if that application is successful, the hearing before the High Court itself. Effectively what is being added in cases which would otherwise have a right of appeal to the High Court under the law as it now stands is the extra burden of a hearing just to get to the court itself so that the court can determine the case on the merits.

We know therefore that that will make it even more costly. We also know that there will not be that superintendence of the decisions of the courts of appeal throughout this country that presently exists. That superintendence is of great value. We know that persons who should have their cases determined favourably to them and who, under the present system, would have the opportunity of convincing the High Court that something went drastically wrong and should be remedied, will be denied that opportunity. That is perfectly plain. To demonstrate it I used the illustration concerning the old man who was involved in an accident with the Public Transport Commission of New South Wales.

I recall another damages case which I argued. It simply concerned a person, a human being who was damaged in an accident. Honourable members should see what happens. It taught me a great deal about many things, including the need to drive slowly and carefully. The man did not do very well in his own court system . He did not do at all well before the court of appeal. I cannot remember the name of the case-it was years ago-but I recall very clearly Mr Justice Jacobs saying, in the course of argument-and we were, I am glad to say, successful-'the court of appeal seems to have seen this case in black and white terms and not to have understood the greys'. One must understand that as one goes through the appellate process, the arguments become refined and the points emerge more sharply because the preparation of the cases cleanses out the dross and concentrates the mind wonderfully as one proceeds with the important points. It is surprising how frequently one can argue a case at first instance, argue it again in front of a court of appeal and find a point emerging before the High Court which seemed unimportant before the other courts but which becomes the determinant of that appeal. We are to be denied that ultimate recourse. We will not be able to say at the end of the day, as we could under the law as it presently stands: 'The court of appeal was mad. We will go to the High Court. The High Court will fix it'. We will have to consider very well and very closely whether there is a right, whether there are special features, regardless of the justice of the matter, which will entitle us to go before the High Court.

I make a last point. I hope that we never see the High Court adopt the United States practice whereby the Supreme Court determines whether an appeal should go to a higher court on the basis of its own considerations, without hearing counsel. Our Court must never be closed to the public or to counsel. Superficially, the United States system may appear to be more efficient, but if one excludes counsel and the public one does not know how justice is being administered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill which is before the House tonight is known as the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), mentioned at length, the main aim of the legislation is to relieve the workload of the High Court of Australia . In future the High Court will consider all appeals which come before it and will grant special leave to appeal if in its wisdom it believes that special leave should be granted. It will be necessary to make out a case for the granting of special leave. I do not see that as being a more costly procedure than that which obtains at present. In a sense, I see it as a much more simple procedure. It saves the cost of preparing appeal books for appellants. It saves all the difficulties of gearing up for an appeal and then, after a short hearing before the High Court, having the appeal struck out. So I think it is a most efficient procedure in an age when legal aid is available to more and more applicants, plaintiffs and appellants.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House that most appeals to the High Court are between companies and concern very esoteric issues, such as patent and customs issues and other such prosecutions. They are not, as the previous speaker would have us believe, all about Mr Henderson, a very worthy gentleman who suffered an injury. Most appeals are of a somewhat less exciting nature. I point out that the new clause 35A, which is proposed for the Judiciary Act, clearly states:
In considering whether to grant an application for special leave to appeal to the High Court . . . the High Court may have regard to any matters that it considers relevant but shall have regard to-

It goes on to say that the High Court shall have regard to certain other factors . But it clearly says that it may have regard to 'any matters'. The justices of the High Court are men who are chosen from the leading jurists in our nation. They will overview the applications which come before them regarding special leave. I will not belabour that point. I know that the Law Council of Australia, which is based in Melbourne, has been lobbying members of parliament, particularly the lawyers of Parliament, on this matter. I know that the Attorney -General (Senator Gareth Evans) has considered this matter.

I want to touch on the important area of appeals from tribunals which involve pensions. Several people from the Ex-Prisoners of War Association saw me about the right to appeal from repatriation tribunals. They pointed out that the High Court in Law v. Repatriation Commission determined that the widow of a former prisoner of war who had started smoking when he was released from a Japanese prison camp and who ultimately died of cancer was entitled to a war pension. I inquired into that matter. I assured the Ex-Prisoners of War Association that there would still be a right of appeal from a tribunal or from a Federal court to the High Court on a matter of that nature because it was a matter of great public importance and because there is an important extension in the law which relates to war pensions.

The Ex-Prisoners of War Association was concerned about the possibility that there would be no more appeals to the High Court in relation to pensions and war caused disabilities. The judges of the High Court have the right to consider all applications which come before them to see whether there is any merit at all in the proceedings rather than giving false hope to the applicants or being party to delaying tactics. From time to time insurance companies and other organisations delay payment arising from verdicts for their own purposes by appealing to the High Court. They run up unnecessary costs for plaintiffs who perhaps have been unsuccessful in a lower court. They then appeal right up to the High Court. We must look at the other side of the coin, which is that of serious delay for plaintiffs and for people who are denied verdicts because, as happens at present, there is an automatic right of appeal to the High Court if a verdict is worth more than $20,000.

The other section of this Bill will establish the Office of the Australian Government Solicitor. I am pleased that this move is being made by the Attorney. Of course, it arose from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which the previous Government established and which certainly rebounded on it because it revealed to the nation and to the world the quite incredible situation which existed in the Western Australian Office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor, where there was gross delay and incompetence and, in fact, far worse than that. These matters were dealt with. People have been dismissed. There was a national scandal in relation to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. I feel that the Attorney has tightened considerably the procedures in his Department. The idea is that the responsibility will not devolve on a Crown Solicitor any more. It will devolve on the Australian Government Solicitor who is defined in the legislation as being 'a body corporate'. That body corporate will be responsible for all Commonwealth litigation and all the matters which the Crown Solicitor's Office previously handled.

I had the advantage of working in the Sydney office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor for many years. I served articles there to a quite outstanding and practical lawyer, Frank Mahony, who was a very sensitive administrator. Later I worked in private practice, and I believe that a lot would be gained by the staff in the Australian Government Solicitor's Office if they spent time working in private firms. It would also be an advantage for solicitors in private practice to work for the Government on an exchange basis, much as teachers exchange between one country and another. These are matters for the present Crown Solicitor who with the passage of this legislation will become the Australian Government Solicitor.

The problem with the Crown Solicitor's Office has always been that it runs a large number of branch offices in each of the States, but it runs them at a distance from Canberra. It is the lawyers in the capital cities of the various States who have the carriage of matters. This is much the same as most of the running-down cases where decisions are not being made by the defendant, the other driver, but by someone from an insurance company. This is a similar situation. When the honourable member for North Sydney said that there was no demand to change the name to Australian Government Solicitor he seemed to have forgotten all about the bottom of the harbour cases, all the scandal arising from the Costigan report, and all the difficulties in the Western Australian Crown Solicitor's Office. There has been a thorough-going inquiry into the running of the Government's legal services and it has produced these changes. I again pay credit to the hard work and ability of all the people with whom I worked in the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's Office, the people who spend their lives there working for the Government, the good, hard-working lawyers who end their careers without any assets to sell, with no goodwill and only their retirement to look forward to. These men and women work very hard for the Commonwealth and worry about their problems and the cases they handle.

Getting back to the subject of the High Court, I was interested in the comments by the honourable member for North Sydney that the High Court is sitting on fewer days, or certainly no more days than it did in 1980. Under the new sitting arrangements this House is sitting for fewer days than it sat last year, but it is sitting for many more hours than it did last year. It is not a very satisfactory test to give us just a bland statement that the High Court is handling fewer cases. It is important that the judges of the High Court handle the really important matters in our nation and that the Court not be clogged up with automatic appeals on running-down cases which may be brought by insurance companies to delay the payment of damages to a successful plaintiff. This is one of the rights insurance companies have always had and one they have exploited in this country. The government insurance companies in some cases also ruthlessly exploited this right of automatic appeal to the High Court.

Appeals to the High Court that have been brought by special leave have been criminal matters, matters where the life or the liberty-usually the liberty, fortunately, in our nation-of an individual is at stake. These matters normally proceed by way of special leave to appeal, and so they should. The judges look at an application and see whether there is any merit at all in the appeal. If there is, they use their powers to grant leave for the case to be heard. These matters are dealt with quickly; there is little delay. I feel that the Opposition is drawing the long bow in this House tonight by saying that the Government is acting reprehensibly in cutting out this automatic time-wasting procedure, which has been a problem to the High Court for a long time.

This change has been made at the request of the judges of the High Court. I worked at the High Court as a clerk in the early 1960s, when Sir Owen Dixon was the Chief Justice. There were seven judges at that time and the number has not increased. They no longer perambulate around the nation as they did, which was a very time-wasting procedure. They would get down to Tasmania and might have only half a day's work. Nevertheless, they had to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—That is not meant to be a criticism of Tasmania. It is a question of fact. It might be that there was only half a day's work in Brisbane, but they had to perambulate around the nation. That was very difficult and very expensive . Now the High Court sits in Canberra. I am pleased to hear that it will consider special leave applications in Sydney and Melbourne, the main centres of population. I believe the Opposition is drawing the long bow in saying that this is a retrograde step. The matters coming before the High Court will be considered by the judges in applications for special leave. Proposed new section 35A of the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) clearly states that the High Court may have regard to any matter in granting applications for special leave. The proposed new clause states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) whether the proceedings in which the judgment to which the application relates was pronounced involve a question of law-
(i) that is of public importance, whether because of its general application or otherwise-

If there is a question of law the matter can have public importance or otherwise . That would cover the situation mentioned by the honourable member for North Sydney. In considering any matter the judges would be able to look at a case such as the one the honourable member mentioned. Judges have complete, unfettered discretion to look at a case. The special leave applications are simply presented. Normally an affidavit would be prepared by a solicitor. If there was a judgment or transcript from the lower court these would probably be included and copies would be given to the judge or judges considering the question of special leave. At very little cost to a potential appellant a short precis of the case and the grounds for appeal would be looked at.

Having worked in a court, having an appreciation of the high standard of justice we have in this nation, and knowing that the Australian populace expects the High Court to be the court which will overview all other courts and, as the honourable member for North Sydney said, ensure some consistency amongst the courts, I do not see any possible danger in this Bill. It is a step to stop the insurance companies from clogging up the lists in the High Court with their unnecessary, time-wasting, frustrating appeals for applicants who have been unsuccessful in a lower court. From time to time we have all been confronted by a constituent who has won a case, perhaps got a substantial verdict for damages in a motor vehicle third party personal injuries case, and has had an insurance company for some policy reason pushing on appeal from one court to another to try to stop the damages awarded in the judgment from being paid. Those are the people who will benefit from this decision.

I assure groups in the community who are worried about it that this move will not in any way restrict or prevent appeals on other matters such as pension matters. Indeed, under the present law it is hard to see how one could appeal on a pension matter, as did Mrs L., the prisoner of war widow. I have assured the Ex-Prisoners of War Association in my State that an appeal on a matter of such public importance would be considered by the High Court. I am sure that the judges of the High Court in their wisdom would grant special leave.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure the House will pass this legislation. It covers two matters; the question of appeals to the High Court and changing the structure of the Crown Solicitor's Office, the Commonwealth's legal arm, to a body corporate, henceforth to be known as the Australian Government Solicitor.
Debate (on motion by Mr Groom) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table, pursuant to section 162 of the Superannuation Act 1976, the annual reports for 1982-83 of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and the Commissioner for Superannuation. The report of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust includes the financial statements for the year ended 30 June 1983, together with the report of the Auditor-General with respect to those statements.

SPEECH.PARA: I also table for the information of honourable members, as I am required to do, a further report by the Auditor-General, drawing my attention to certain other matters of concern to him which have arisen in the course of his examination of the statements. Limited copies of these report are available from the Bills and Papers Office, the Senate Records Office and the Parliamentary Library. Copies will be distributed to all members and senators as soon as they become available . I table as well the Report of the Inquiry into the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. Copies of this report are available and have been distributed. Having tabled the reports, I seek leave of the House to move a motion to authorise publication of the reports.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the further reports of the Auditor- General on financial statements of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust for the year 1982-83, the report of the inquiry into the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and the annual reports of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and the Commissioner for Superannuation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The House will recall that on 7 December 1983, when I tabled a further report by the Auditor-General, which arose from his examination of the 1981-82 financial statements, I announced that there would be a thorough examination of the matters and that I would inform the House further on the matters raised by the Auditor-General on the conclusion of the examination. I established an inquiry into the Trust and appointed Mr J. V. Monaghan, a Commissioner of the Australian Public Service Board, to conduct it. The terms of reference for the inquiry were to examine and report on:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Those matters of concern drawn to my attention pursuant to paragraph (d) of sub-section 161 (2) of the Superannuation Act 1976 in the section-pages 5 to 23- headed 'Other Matters of Concern' in the report of the Auditor-General dated 11 November 1983;
(2) any related matters arising in the course of the examination; and
(3) such proposals as are considered appropriate for remedying any shortcomings that are identified.

The inquiry was assisted by a consultant from Ernst and Whinney, who was appointed with the purpose of providing a private sector perspective. The report addresses both the specific matters raised by the Auditor-General and a range of concerns of a more general character. The general issues included matters of consequence in connection with the Trust's objectives, its relationship with the Commonwealth Government, its accounting and investment policies and the structure of the Trust. These issues are central to the operations of the Trust.

It is clear from the report that the Government is indebted to the Auditor- General for bringing the whole operation of the Trust and its office to the attention of the Government. It is apparent that there have been substantial changes since the Trust's establishment in the nature of its operations, and that there are problems to be dealt with. The management and investment performance of the Superannuation Fund is important to both the contributors and the Government, and the contributors are entitled to be assured of the security and integrity of the Fund. While the report points to a less than satisfactory performance in certain areas, contributors will be reassured by the conclusion that there appears to have been no significant impairment of the security and integrity of the Fund.

The inquiry has not found that the former Trust was reckless or incompetent in making investment decisions. It has, however, identified a number of serious weaknesses, reflected in confusion regarding the role of the Chairman, the failure to implement a fully planned, integrated investment strategy, inadequate direction and control of the office and dissension among senior officers. In examining the specific projects that were the subject of the Auditor-General's concern, the inquiry is critical of arrangements used to achieve tax savings for investment partners, and in a differing degree for itself, and of the failure of the Trust to record reasons for its decisions.

The report also notes that the evaluation methods used, particularly in the property area, have generally been sound, but sees a need for improved management of existing assets and points to inadequacies in documentation and procedures in the Trust's office. For these and other reasons the report concludes that there should be an immediate increase in staffing with further consideration of staffing needs after the report has been considered by the Government.

As will be seen from the recommendations contained in the report, the inquiry has covered a wide range of the Trust's operations including many areas of a technical nature, and has recommended changes to the Superannuation Act and/or the Superannuation (Investment) Regulations regarding specification of investment powers, prescription of interest rates applicable to contributors and other matters. I have already taken steps to establish a working party comprising representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Trust, the Public Service Board and my Department to advise on the further steps that will be required. I have in mind to introduce amending legislation during the Budget sittings. Meanwhile, I shall, in line with the first recommendation of the report, be bringing to the attention of the Trust the conclusions reached in the report. I shall also have my Department initiate prompt action, in association with other relevant authorities, concerning those interim measures that have been recommended in the report.

In regard to the composition of the Trust, I note the references within the report to the valuable contribution made by Mr Hammond, the Chairman, and the then Trust in introducing innovation in investment policy, especially in building up the property portfolio, and that Mr Hammond has remained available to the Trust during the period of this inquiry, the work of which he has facilitated in every way. The inquiry has also pointed to the possible advantage in Mr Hammond's services remaining available to the Trust for a period.

I note also, however, that the report expresses some serious reservations about Mr Hammond's management of the operations of the Trust, particularly in relation to its status as a government instrumentality. The report observes that Mr Hammond's personal style of doing business sits uneasily with the necessarily institutional character of the Trust. A government body, and one with functions such as those of the Trust, has of course to observe a number of management requirements which might not apply in other contexts. The Government will be giving immediate consideration to questions of staffing of the office of the Trust, the arrangements under which staff costs are borne, the composition of the Trust and the possibility of enlarging its membership, as well as the other matters which are to be referred to the joint working party.

Since the inquiry was established, Mr Hammond has stood aside as chairman and Mr W. J. Smith has been acting in that capacity. The report of the inquiry notes the value of Mr Hammond's contributions to the work of the Trust, and I wish to express my personal appreciation of Mr Hammond's work in a period of difficulty and considerable change. The conclusions of the report, however, do not appear such as to justify reinstating him in his previous position. As a result I will, as the report suggests, discuss with Mr Hammond the question of his future relationship with the Trust.

The Commonwealth Banking Corporation has agreed that for the time being the management of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation officers' superannuation fund will provide advice and support to facilitate the continued effective opeation of the Trust. I am most appreciative of the assistance offered by the Corporation at this time.

The further report of the Auditor-General dated 30 March 1984 that I have just tabled with the 1982-83 annual reports, as with the similar report that I tabled on 7 December last year, deals with some technical accounting and investment matters and other more substantial matters concerning the performance of the Trust in relation to certain investment transactions. The Auditor-General concludes that his audit of the financial statements for the year ended 30 June 1983 has done nothing to dissipate his concern that the management of the Trust does not appear to be of an appropriate standard of competence and professionalism. As appropriate action will shortly be taken regarding the conclusions and recommendations of the Monaghan inquiry, which address the concerns that have been raised in relation to accounting and investment policies and the management of the Trust, and bearing in mind in particular the urgent need, in the interests of contributors, for the Trust to return to full operational capability with the confidence of the financial community, I do not propose to establish a further formal inquiry into these matters.

However, where these matters have not been fully addressed by the Monaghan inquiry and where there may be opportunity for remedial action, they will be carefully examined by the Trust and my Department in consultation with the Auditor-General. In conclusion I should like to record the Government's appreciation of the efforts of Commissioner Monaghan in his timely response, in depth and detail, to the necessarily urgent task of the inquiry into the Trust's affairs; my appreciation of the work of Mr W. J. Smith, previously Director of the Grievance and Appeals Bureau, who accepted appointment as acting chairman of the Trust during this difficult period, and Mr R. C. Davey, Commissioner for Superannuation, who has acted for almost 12 months as a part-time member of the Trust; and the Government's intention to ensure that the Trust resume full investment activity on a sound and effective basis as soon as possible. I also record that as representatives of the contributors, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and other unions have been very helpful in the way in which they have co-operated with the conduct of the inquiry and indeed the other changes which have been necessary as interim measures. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement just put down by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) is a sizeable indictment-to put it at its very mildest-of the operation of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. When the matter first came before the House I thought there may have been a possibility that the findings of the Auditor-General might have been more in line with those of a statutory body, taking a Public Service view of some actions which were very much within the private sector. However, I noticed these words in the statement put down by the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there appears to have been no significant impairment of the security and integrity of the Fund.
I am sure we would all be pleased to hear that. The Minister continued:
The inquiry has not found that the former trust was reckless or incompetent in making investment decisions.

That is probably the best way that it could be put. When one reads that there was dissension among senior officers within the Trust one sees quite clearly that it is not a happy party. Because of this alone it is time that the Government had a close look at the management of the Trust and the way in which the officers went about it.

I note that the Minister proposes to put up a working party consisting of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Trust, the Public Service Board and the Department of Finance. There is no doubt that the Department of Finance and the Trust have a very significant interest in this matter. Because of the employment opportunities which will arise no doubt the Public Service Board will be involved. I can also see some reason for the ACTU being involved. However, I totally fail to see why the composition of a working party such as that would neglect to take on board a competent financial group, wholly independent, which could make a business assessment of what is going on. If one is dealing in trust management, if one is dealing in property management, if one is dealing in share management, quite clearly a merchant bank, a chartered accountant or someone who can provide detached management advice is needed. I am surprised and shocked that that is not taking place.

Quite clearly Mr Hammond has made a contribution and has changed the total style of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund. I think that is well known. His style has not mixed with the way in which the instrumentality has worked. However I do not believe that people who take on these positions should be allowed to run free and fast. I hope that if he is to be retained the job specification will be well and truly set out to him and that he will be told that those specifications must be made to work. Along with that, the officers within the Trust must work in co-operation and with a single purpose. If there is dissent among senior executives of any corporation or trust it is bound for disaster. No wonder this Fund got into the state it did.

I am similarly concerned because it appears that in the short term we have turned to the Commonwealth Banking Corporation to run the Trust. If that is the case why not extend that principle, put the Trust out to tender and get the best professional management we can in Australia for this sort of investment? Today in Australia there is very competent investment management. I would never have said that in the 1960s, and the same would have applied in the early 1970s. But I am bound to say that in the 1980s the degree of professional investment has risen quite markedly. Through the advent of the merchant banks, through the advent of substantially better training and substantially more expertise and experience gained by Australians overseas, we do have in the country today a very wide group of people who could be asked to submit tenders for the management of this Trust rather than go about restructuring what appears to be an unhappy team and to persist with the type of program that is in hand.

The second letter from the Auditor-General to the Minister, dated 30 March 1984 , when lined up with some of the comments that have come back from the Trust in response to the comments made by the Auditor-General, certainly show some disturbing factors. I find the treatment in the accounts given to the Willows Waterworld property in Townsville hard to accept in commercial practice. I found that the group concerned with the Western Australian properties which failed to meet its rent and at the same time put that rent on interest bearing deposit and paid half of the interest to the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund had an innovative way of going about things. I also found the way in which the Chatswood Property Trust transferred the amounts involved and slipped $11m off the end not related to the equity base to be innovative. I certainly found the position in relation to currency hedging unusual. On the final page of the Auditor-General's letter to the Minister he stated:

On the occasion of my earlier report I noted that I was not calling into question the soundness or propriety of investment decisions since it was not my function to do so. Nor am I able to do so now. I would, however, observe that it is time for the Trust itself to undertake a major prudential examination of its investment portfolio, of the arrangements it has made for the detailed management of the portfolio and, indeed, of the philosophy that has governed its investment policies and practices.

From reading the pages that preceded that comment that is an understatement of some of the practices that have been going on within the Trust. I am pleased that this has come forward. I urge the Government to take action in this area. We cannot have other people's funds, which we invest in a trust, handled in what I would regard as a pretty slap-dash manner. I urge that the working party be expanded to embrace commercial expertise and that consideration be given to the question of putting the Trust into the hands of a professional management team rather than attempting to staff it here in Canberra with public servants who, with the best will in the world, are certainly not trained in investment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government will establish a new National Film and Sound Archive. The Archive will preserve moving images and recorded sound as part of Australia's twentieth century cultural heritage. The Archive, based on the existing film and sound archives presently located in the National Library of Australia, will develop presentational material such as literature and artefacts relating to the history of Australian film and recorded sound. It will contain facilities to encourage public and industry access to the collections, and for screening old films for public viewing. The National Film and Sound Archive will be made administratively independent of the National Library immediately, and will initially be an office within the Department of Home Affairs and Environment reporting to that Minister which, of course, is me. Its staff and finance will be separated from the National Library immediately and its accommodation as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The position of Director will be established and advertised nationally. A National Film and Sound Archives Advisory Committee will be appointed to develop planning for the future development of the Archive. It will advise the Government on a range of matters including accommodation, staffing, regional representation, appropriate charges for services, preservation program and timetable, relations with the industry and trade, and deposit requirements. The Advisory Committee will be asked to report within 12 months of its appointment. The Government has also decided to provide increased resources in the form of staff, funds and equipment to develop the Film and Sound Archive. The increased resources should permit preservation of more nitrate film and the handling of newer technical conservation problems. The new National Film and Sound Archive will be more accessible to the public and the film industry. Offices will be opened in New South Wales and Victoria and the Advisory Committee will examine the desirability of opening offices in other States.

The National Library's management of its holdings of film and sound recordings has been criticised but I think this criticism is unfair. It must be remembered that the Library took the initiative to preserve this vital inheritance. The Library, as a whole, was restrained by its allocation of resources from the previous Government, but its film and sound sections have received at least a fair share of those limited resources and some, apparently unrecognised, success has been achieved in building up the collections and establishing a working relationship with the industry. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the work of Harrison Bryan, the Director of the Library, and the Chairman of the National Library Council, Dr Forbes, who are in the gallery at present.

Nevertheless, the Government has decided that there is a need for a separate institution with a charter of its own and guidelines established by the Government after consultation with all the interests concerned. In addition, an interdepartmental committee will inquire into and advise on policy generally concerning all the Commonwealth's holdings of film, sound recordings and related issues. Policy advice will include matters such as the co-ordination and rationalisation of all Commonwealth activities in this area-acquisition of material, cataloguing, conservation, reproduction, access arrangements and co- ordination with relevant State and private sector interests. There are many complex issues involved in the consideration of how other Commonwealth holdings of film and sound recordings will relate to the National Film and Sound Archive. In view of these issues, and the need for consultation, the Government will consider the requirements further after receiving the reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This is a somewhat extraordinary decision because of the convoluted logic contained in the statement by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). Naturally, I have consulted my colleague Senator Martin, the shadow Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, about this matter. There has been much speculation in recent months as to the future of the film archives. This has been the result of concern about the risk of our losing, through deterioration, valuable and irreplacable early Australian film records. The National Library has claimed that insufficient government funding has led to this situation. Today the Minister says that he believes that criticism of the Library is unfair. Nevertheless, the Government has decided to remove the film archives from the Library immediately, and without, really, the amount of consultation that one would have expected with the National Library Council by the Minister. I understand that the inclusion of the sound library was hardly discussed at all and was really a surprise parallel factor to the shifting of the film archives.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's decision to remove immediately from the Library the Australian film archives staff and finance and to transfer them to an office within the Department of Home Affairs and Environment is startling to say the least. A number of options have been publicly canvassed in recent months. More money could have been given to the National Library, with a direction that it be used for the benefit of the film and sound archives. Other alternatives were to place it with the Australian Film Commission or the Australian Archives. The Government has decided on a course which will need much greater public expenditure-removing the archives from whatever independence it enjoyed as a part of the National Library and making it part of the bureaucracy.

One must conclude that this could be the worst possible option. It saves no money. Indeed, it will cost more than several of the alternatives. It does not assure any form of independent cultural development, and it runs all the risks inherent in becoming part of the bureaucracy, as I have already mentioned. Only time will tell whether this arrangement will meet any of the criticisms that were made in regard to the previous one. However, all things considered, the Government should not be surprised if public reaction is sceptical about the haste, the lack of consultation and the very great expense that will be incurred in this particular arrangement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I followed with considerable interest the statement made by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). I am pleased that he indicated that he thought that the National Library's management of its holdings of film and sound recordings had been criticised unfairly. As the representative of this House of Representatives on the National Library Council, I hope that that defence of the Library by the Minister will be translated into additional assistance for the Library in the Budget for the year ahead, because the problems that he is trying to address are problems that the Library has been trying to address in very straitened financial circumstances over a considerable number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the Library has in recent times been criticised about the situation of its map collection. Of course, in no small measure that has been brought about by the deferment of additional accommodation for the Library by the previous Government, and, as in so many other areas of administration in this country, there are long-standing problems to be redressed. I trust that the recognition by the Minister that the Library is not at fault in this matter will mean that he will continue his support in the Budget Cabinet to get a greater degree of financial assistance, because there are other problems, and the problems will not be solved by dismembering the national collection. They will be solved by increased government support.

One of the arguments of the people who sought to establish a separate national film and sound archive was the fact that the film and sound archives were submerged within the National Library, a statutory corporation, and had no separate identity. I do not think that the decision made at this time has addressed that problem, and I do not think that it is the last that the Minister will hear of that problem.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA AMENDMENT BILL 1984AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT SOLICITOR ( CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984]
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you have mentioned, Mr Deputy Speaker, the House is debating the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No.2) 1984, the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1984 and the Australian Government Solicitor ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984. I shall concentrate my remarks on the first of the Bills. It has two purposes: Firstly, to relieve the High Court of Australia of some of its work load; secondly, to establish the office of Australian Government Solicitor. I want to comment on the establishment of the office of Australian Government Solicitor.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) quite rightly pointed out, the Government has not explained the real reasons why it is establishing such an office. Earlier we heard a speech from the honourable member for Lowe ( Mr Maher), who attempted to suggest that this office is being established because of comments made by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I could not quite follow that argument. It seemed to me not to make much sense. The real reason is that this Government is attempting to take us very quickly down the path to a republic. That is the real reason for this decision. In recent times a number of decisions , the purpose of which have been to cut our ties with the Monarchy, have been made. Later this evening we will resume the debate on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. Part of that Bill-I will not go into the details-seeks to drop the oath or the affirmation of allegiance which up to this point new citizens in this country have been obliged to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think that the honourable member is pre-empting debate on a Bill which will be debated in the House later this evening.
—There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Braddon.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I can understand the honourable member's sensitivity about this issue. This is an important point. The Government is attempting to hoodwink the people of Australia. It is trying to create the image of a responsible government when underneath this is a lot of radical action to change some of the great institutions and great traditions that we believe in in this country. Let us take, for example, the Australian flag which Australian servicemen carried onto Anzac Cove, which Australian service men and women have carried into wars and conflicts in which we have been involved and which Australian team members have carried with pride to the Olympic Games and the Commonwealth Games held during this century. All around Australia, in each part of this great country, in the Territories and the States, members of the Australian Labor Party make speeches calling for a change in our national flag. A local senator down my way in Tasmania said: 'Let us have a green and gold flag with a kangaroo on it'.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I draw your attention to relevance. This might be a wide-ranging debate but I do not think there is any connection between the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the sort of flag we may have in the future.
—The point of order is upheld. I ask the honourable member to come back to the Bills before the House.

—I was just explaining the Government's real motives for changing the flag and at the same time in the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill changing the title of our Crown Solicitor to the Australian Government Solicitor. Surely members of this House can see the connection between those two actions. I just warn the Australian people-it is no good warning Government members because there are not many in the House at present- about what is really going on behind the scenes. A number of actions of this kind are taking place at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) is concerned with the High Court. It is suggested by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that one of the purposes of this Bill is to relieve the High Court of some of its work load. I do not see that as a very good reason for changes of this kind. Why would one want to relieve the work load of the High Court? The inference is that the High Court judges might want to do less work, might want to have time for other things. This House should take action to ensure that the High Court can effectively carry out the proper functions that it is given under our Constitution. That should be the objective of the legislation. The objective should not be simply to relieve the High Court of its business.

The High Court, of course, is a Federal court. I think we should consider that point when we consider the work load it carries. I was most disappointed in the comments that were made by the honourable member for Lowe, who has since left the House, when he criticised the fact that justices of the High Court from time to time go around to the different States of Australia to hear cases, appeals and applications of various kinds. He implied that it is quite wrong for the High Court to travel, for example, to Tasmania. He said that there is no business in Tasmania. But Tasmania is one of the original States. We are entitled to protection under our Constitution and we look to the High Court for protection.

Let us look at the dam case. I do not want to go into that in too much detail but it was a very important case, as has been mentioned earlier. It took some days to be heard by the High Court. In that case the justices were not looking at certain precedents to determine the decision they should make. They were swayed, obviously, not only by their understanding and interpretation of the Constitution and the law but also to some extent by their feelings and philosophies. When such a fundamental matter as that one is being decided by the High Court it is obvious that the judges will be influenced by their fundamental philosophies and feelings and the atmosphere around the place.

I wish to make two points about that. They are very relevant to the Judiciary Bill. It is important that justices travel around Australia and do not just sit in this new building-I think it is far too imposing-on the shores of Lake Burley Griffin. They must get out and about and visit the various States to understand the feelings in those States. I think if they can do that, as they have done in the past-I do not criticise them for it-they will have a better appreciation of what the Constitution is all about. It is not just about Canberra, as the justices quite rightly appreciate, and it is not just about Sydney and Melbourne . The Attorney-General has said that under these new arrangements, with people seeking special leave to appeal to the High Court, there might be sittings in Melbourne and Sydney. The High Court and the Constitution are not just about Melbourne, Sydney and Canberra. They are about the outlying parts of Australia as well as the major centres.

I am disappointed at this stage in our history, 81 years since the High Court was first established in 1903, that we have not yet had one Tasmanian appointed to the High Court. I do not think South Australia has had a High Court justice either. I hope that before too long we will see people from those States being appointed to the High Court. It will mean that the High Court is truly representative of the total Australian community and that justices of the High Court will perhaps have a better appreciation of the feelings that exist in this country and a better understanding, therefore, of the real purpose of our Constitution. That purpose, in its fundamental sense, is to keep Australia secure and to ensure that the Australian community remains satisfied and happy with our institutions, particularly our governmental institutions. That is a very important point.

One of the purposes of the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to change the existing appeal provisions in the Judiciary Act 1903 so that a matter involving more than $20,000 which has been dealt with by a State Supreme Court-perhaps by a single judge and later the Full Court-cannot as of right now be taken to the High Court on appeal.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is cognately debating three Bills-the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill and the Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill. I have already made some comments on the first of those Bills, the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2). Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I had referred to the restriction on the right of appeal in that Bill. The Bill will remove the existing right of appeal to the High Court from State Full Courts in respect of appeals involving cases where the value of the subject matter being considered is $20,000 or more or involving the interpretation of the Constitution. The effect of these relevant provisions will be that no appeal will lie from a State Supreme Court to the High Court otherwise than by special leave of the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Along with a number of honourable members of this House who happen to be lawyers, I received representations in the form of a letter from the Law Council of Australia expressing some concern about those measures. I can certainly understand the expression of concern in those representations. On balance, I believe that it is not unreasonable to expect that the High Court should concentrate on matters of real consequence. I do not believe that the monetary test is the best test. There can be matters that involve more than $20,000 which are of no real consequence in terms of the general community, although they would be of real consequence to the individuals involved in the particular appeal. There always has to be some end to the judicial process, whether it be before a single judge of a Supreme Court or a Full Court, or whether it be before the High Court. Obviously, aggrieved parties who are not satisfied by the results of an appeal will remain aggrieved. There has to be some point at which the system says that a matter has gone far enough.

I think it is not unreasonable to expect that the High Court might be best able to judge these matters by way of determining an application for special leave to appeal. If the court is to retain its great reputation in the international legal world, not just within Australia but certainly overseas as well, I think it is fair enough that it should be able to concentrate its skills and its talents on matters of real consequence to the community. I think in concentrating on those sorts of matters the Court will best serve the general Australian community. I do not oppose that aspect of this matter, although I am concerned about the costs involved.

As has been pointed out by other speakers, including the honourable member for North Sydney in a very fine address on these Bills, there is the problem that appellants, the parties involved and their counsel, have to make a journey to the Court to make an application for special leave to appeal. If they are successful, they have to take the further step and be involved in the further expense of going to the appeal proper and making the appeal to the Court. From memory, in the second reading speech the Attorney-General said that it is likely that there will be an opportunity for people to make these applications in Sydney and Melbourne.

The problem there is that sometimes parties in outlying States such as Tasmania are aggrieved, and they might want to make an urgent application for special leave to appeal. There is an added expense involved in travelling to the High Court building in Canberra or to Sydney or Melbourne.
