It would be unfortunate if people in certain parts of Australia were disadvantaged compared with people in major centres such as Canberra, Sydney or Melbourne.

I think generally we can be very proud of the High Court. As I have said before , it has a great reputation which has developed since it was established in 1903 . It is a very important part of our whole constitutional framework. I agree with the words spoken by Alfred Deakin, the first Commonwealth Attorney-General, when he said that the High Court was the keystone of the Federal arch. Therefore , it is important that this Parliament considers how we can best ensure that the High Court is effective and efficient. It is not just a matter of trying to lighten the work load. I think it comes back to a question of how it can best serve the community. We should make the necessary administrative arrangements, procedures and rules for appeals to ensure that it carries out its functions in the best possible way.

I do not want to continue my remarks at great length. I again refer to the point I raised earlier about the establishment of the office of the Australian Government Solicitor. As I have said before, reasons that I do not think carry weight have been given for establishing this office. I would like to know from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), who is seated at the table, why this title has been decided upon. Why is it to be called 'Australian Government Solicitor'? Why do we drop the title 'Crown Solicitor'? What are the reasons for this? Surely the people of Australia are entitled to an explanation of that decision? It is no good just talking about the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. We understand that there were administrative problems and questions of efficiency in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, but those difficulties could be overcome without changing the name.

It makes one wonder what is going on behind the scenes. What moves are afoot? Why are we perhaps offending Her Majesty the Queen in this way by dropping this title? I do not say that lightly when one considers the Constitution and the role of the monarchy in the Constitution. She is the Queen of Australia. I believe that we should recognise that fact and show her due respect. I believe that this measure is an offence to Her Majesty. I think honourable members opposite should be very concerned about what they are doing in that regard. I do not think many of them really understand what they are doing. This is a measure of great significance, along with other steps that have been taken, including the other measure that perhaps we will debate later tonight, if we have the time -the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill and the changes that are being made there to the oath and affirmation of allegiance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is often suggested that there are too many lawyers in this Parliament. I am not sure that I agree, or indeed that the Whip would agree, with that suggestion because I think he has had some trouble persuading some of the eminent lawyers amongst us that they should give us the benefit of their legal wisdom by speaking in this debate. It is a very important debate. I am pleased to see that my fellow members of the legal eagles faction on this side of the House-the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), all excellent members-have or will be speaking in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: There are about eight former lawyers on this side of the House and that represents about 10 per cent of our numbers. I do not think anybody could seriously suggest that that is too many. I believe that all the lawyers in this House, not only on this side but also on the other side-I can see the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) nodding in agreement-have made a great sacrifice in coming here. I refer not just to great monetary sacrifice; I am referring to the alarming drop which occurs in our honesty and ethical rating when we change from being lawyers to being politicians. The Morgan gallup poll seemed to indicate that lawyers have an honesty and ethical rating of about 40.5 on its scale. I regret to say that federal politicians have an honesty and ethical rating of 16. There is an alarming gap of 24.5 when one turns from being a lawyer to a politician. It is very disturbing. I think I have the solution to the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —You leave the House.

—I could leave the House but I will not be doing so. I see that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) is proposing to leave the House to return to the law. That will take his personal rating up from 16 to 40.5. I suggest as well that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) might consider leaving the House and returning to law. That would take his rating from 16 up to 40.5. It might also take up our rating as politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the two cognate Bills deal with two matters. One is the establishment of an Australian Government Solicitor and the second is the removal of the as of right appeal to the High Court. I will deal first with the question of the Australian Government Solicitor. Opposition speakers have claimed that there is some plot involved here aimed at insulting the Queen. Nothing could be further from the point. The fact is that the office of Crown Solicitor presently is a personal office. The Crown Solicitor in Canberra currently has professional responsibility for all actions carried on throughout Australia by his office. When one considers that the Crown Solicitor' s office is currently involved in some 11,000 cases around Australia it is easy to see that the Crown Solicitor has an awesome responsibility.

The Australian Government Solicitor (Consequential Amendments) Bill will replace the personal office of the Crown Solicitor with a corporate entity. That will allow a decentralisation of this professional responsibility. In future the officers in charge of regional offices will bear the professional responsibility to the courts for the conduct of actions in their particular regions. It has been possible for legal firms in the Northern Territory to incorporate for some years now. The Bill will simply form the new Australian Government Solicitor into a corporate entity similar to incorporating a legal firm in the Northern Territory. In view of the patchy history of the Crown Solicitor's Office under the previous Government it is reasonable for the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to rearrange and rationalise the legal services performed by that office for its clients. This Bill will do exactly that.

I turn to the second aspect which relates to the removal of the as of right appeal to the High Court. I have been approached, as I believe have all lawyers in this House, by the Law Council of Australia and also by the Law Society of the Northern Territory. I want to quote from a letter I have received from the President of the Law Society of the Northern Territory outlining the concerns that that society has about aspects of the legislation. The President, Mr Bradley, said:

In the territory, we have no Full Court of our Supreme Court and therefore one of the appeal processes presently available to all of the other people in Australia, is not available to territory residents. Access to the High Court for Territorians has been regular in recent years, and of reasonable frequency having regard to the population living in the Northern Territory. I believe that such access for Territorians is of fundamental importance having regard to the emerging nature of our law and the relative uncertainty of much of the modern legislation affecting Territorians. I therefore urge that you consider the Bill which I understand to have been presented before the Senate. If you do not reach the conclusion that the Bill is not in the interests of Territorians, then I invite you to meet . . .

The two points the President raised concerned the absence of a State court of appeal structure and the special position of the Territory's legal system in dealing with an emerging body of law and modern legislation. The Federal Court of Australia currently operates, in effect, as a court of appeal from the Northern Territory. When appeals are heard by the Federal Court one Territory Supreme Court judge serves on that court of appeal. Given that, I think that there is some merit in the claim that the Territory should have its own court of appeal. In the past it has been difficult because there have not been enough Supreme Court judges to form a court of appeal to allow appeals from one of their number to go to three of the others. The position of Aboriginal Land Commissioner has been established in the Territory for some time. Additional judges have been appointed to the Supreme Court. There are five judges of the Territory Supreme Court and there are proposals to increase that number with the appointment of one or two land commissioners. I should add that land commissioners are also judges of the Territory Supreme Court. So with their appointment there will be six, possibly seven, judges of the Territory Supreme Court. That is enough to allow the establishment of a Territory court of appeal. I believe that that will overcome the problem raised by the President of the Northern Territory Law Society better than the proposal not to remove the appeal as of right from this legislation.

The second matter raised by the President of the Law Society is the question of the special position of the Territory's legal system in dealing with an emerging body of law and modern legislation. While he does not say it, I think that one of the pieces of legislation to which he would be referring is the Aboriginal Land Rights Act in the Northern Territory. There have been numerous appeals to the High Court by the Northern Territory Government concerning that piece of legislation. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is at the table. I am sure he can confirm that the Northern Terrritory Government has been very active in litigation concerning that piece of legislation. Most of those appeals -to use a broader term-really involve writs of mandamus or prohibition to the High Court. This legislation will not prevent the Northern Territory Government or any other party from taking that course of action in future to the High Court . All it will do will be to allow the High Court to remit particular cases which it considers not to be of great public importance to the Federal Court when it deals with Aboriginal land rights claims. So the legislation will not drastically affect the right of people or bodies in the Northern Territory to refer matters to the High Court.

Another matter which has been raised is the costs involved in travelling from the Northern Territory to make applications for special leave to appeal. The Attorney-General addressed this matter in the debate about this legislation in another place. He proposed a consideration of video conferencing to allow the people in outlying States to make their submissions to the High Court by way of a video conferencing link, from the Darwin to Canberra, Darwin to Sydney, or Darwin to Melbourne. The second area that the Court is considering is a wider use of written submissions. So there are two areas that are being considered which may assist in reducing the cost to people in outlying States and Territories in making applications for special leave to appeal.

The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has consulted with the Law Council of Australia about this piece of legislation. Indeed, he has indicated that the legislation will be reviewed not later than two years after its introduction to see whether it is operating effectively. In its letter the Law Council of Australia raised a number of its concerns relating to the legislation. I will not deal with them all because I will not have time. I will deal with some aspects of the policy of the Law Council of Australia. The letter states:

If a monetary criterion is adopted, then the present limit of $20,000 should be raised. Further, the law should be that the appellant must show that the result of the appeal may advantage him in the requisite sum; that is a stiffer test than the present one.

That is the case except that it ignores the basic concern that is being addressed by this legislation, that is, that the High Court should really be dealing only with matters involving the application of the law in areas of public importance where the Court has some belief that the law is in need of examination and has not been properly stated by the courts below. That is one area.

I suppose the second area is where a miscarriage of justice might have occurred in a particular case. So this piece of legislation is aimed at those two areas. We can go on increasing monetary levels until we are blue in the face, but that will not really address the basic concerns that are covered by this piece of legislation. The second aspect of the Law Council's policy is this:
Consideration should be given to providing an appeal as of right where the appeal court below is divided in opinion, subject to a mechanism to exclude appeals raising purely factual points.

The position is that a division of opinion in the decision of a full court really does not necessarily indicate that there is a real doubt as to the state of the law. The question may not be one of any general or public importance. This gets us back to the basic criteria or concerns that I addressed just a few moments ago. The third area covered by the Law Council of Australia is as follows:

The Full Federal Court should be given jurisdiction to entertain any application for a prerogative writ which may at present be made to the High Court, with an appeal by special leave to the High Court.

The Federal Court has now been given jurisdiction to entertain applications for prerogative writs except for reviewing decisions of the various Commonwealth industrial tribunals and the Family Court of Australia. This is the fourth area raised by the Law Council in its policy:

Appeals to the High Court should be permissible in cases where special leave is presently necessary or will become necessary under these proposals, on the certificate of the appellate court from which the appeal is brought that, in its opinion, a point of law of general importance is involved or that the point is one which ought to be considered by the High Court.

The Council is proposing that in the appeal from the Federal Court to the High Court the Federal Court should determine whether the special leave to appeal should be allowed. I understand that proposal was not acceptable to the justices of the High Court, and it is not surprising because it is not consistent with the view that the High Court should be able to decide what significant matters should come before it on appeal. The fifth area of the Law Council's policy states:

A right of appeal should be granted in criminal cases with respect to any ground relating to a point on which the appellate court below was divided in opinion, but only where the applicant has been sentenced to life, or to a term of imprisonment of five years or more.

At present, of course, criminal appellants have to seek special leave to appeal to the High Court, and the Law Council is suggesting that that be watered down somewhat. Again, I refer to the comments I made on the basic criteria for the matters that should come before the High Court and the concerns that are being addressed by this Bill, that is, that the High Court should be dealing only with matters of public importance where the High Court believes that the law is in need of examination or has not been properly stated by the court below, or that a miscarriage of justice has occurred in a particular case. A number of other points are raised by the Law Council's policy, but I do not have the time to address them at this stage. It has been difficult to obtain accurate statistics as to the level of appeals as of right which are dealt with by the High Court.

The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), I understand, produced some figures earlier in the debate. But I believe it is still difficult to glean from them exactly how many of the cases are being dealt with by leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, but the figures are all there. I did not have time to read them all out because they are fairly long.

—I see. The Attorney-General in his comments in another place claimed that, in 1981, 40 per cent of all appeals came as of right; in 1982, 60 per cent of all appeals heard by the Court were as of right; and in 1983, 64 per cent of all appeals were heard as of right. While he referred to the difficulty in ascertaining exactly how many of the total number of matters dealt with by the High Court involve special leave to appeal, he said that generally somewhere between 30 per cent and 50 per cent of the Court's total workload, measured by the number of cases it is hearing, involve appeals as of right.

SPEECH.PARA: The concerns expressed by the Northern Territory Law Society and also the Law Council of Australia I believe have been dealt with by the Attorney-General, both in consultation with the Law Council of Australia and in the legislation. I note that after considerable concern was expressed and discussions took place about what criteria should be applied when considering whether to grant an application for special leave to appeal, the Attorney-General agreed to amend the Bill in another place to spell out the criteria involved. That is now contained in proposed new section 35A and it refers again to the criteria I mentioned before: Basically, that the proceedings in which the judgment to which the application relates involve a question of law which is of public importance, whether because of its general application or otherwise, or that they involve a question of law where differences of opinion between different courts or within one court as to the state of the law have occurred. It also expresses as a criteria whether the interests of the administration of justice, either generally or in the particular case, require consideration by the High Court. I think the concerns have been dealt with by the Attorney-General, and I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate interrupted.
