DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent me from moving forthwith a motion of censure of the Government for its attempt to mislead the Parliament and people on the significance of its endorsement of the strategic basis paper and to deceive the Parliament and people on its deep divisions over the basis for developing Australia's defence and strategic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion for suspension in writing?

—Yes, it is seconded by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair). The Oppositon feels compelled to move for the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders because an extraordinarily serious matter is before the nation this evening. Honourable members will recall the publication in the National Times last week-I show it to honourable members to remind them- of an exclusive article headed 'Australia's New Defence Strategy'. The article contained what is termed the strategic basis for Australia's defence policy. Throughout the week this Government has sought to prevaricate, to hedge, to obfuscate that endorsement. Tonight a paper has been produced, again in an edition of the National Times, in which the truth is stated about what Cabinet really decided, and this is the reason for the Opposition moving for the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders. On the front page of the newspaper is a simulation of the Cabinet submission and it alleges that the Minister has put this on the cover of the Cabinet submission in regard to the timing and handling of the announcement of the decision:

SPEECH.PARA: No specific public announcement is required but I shall present the policies outlined in SB83-
which is this document-
in my public statements on defence matters. I shall present the policies.
The reason we moved for the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, to save hearing this speech twice, the Government agrees to the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders to allow the Leader of the Opposition to move his motion.
—I have to go through the formalities. I take it that the Leader of the Opposition wants to move to the censure motion and not the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders. Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion is seconded by the Leader of the National Party.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for its attempt to-
(1) mislead the Parliament and people on the significance of its endorsement of the strategic basis paper and,
(2) deceive the Parliament and people on its deep divisions over the basis for developing Australia's defence and strategic policies.

I thank the Leader of the House (Mr Young) for taking this substantive motion immediately. I will not reiterate my criticisms which I have already gone through in relation to his determination as to whether and how he will accept this as a censure, but let me say that the terminology of this censure motion says it all. We censure the Government for its attempt to mislead the Parliament and people on the significance of its endorsement of the strategic basis paper and to deceive the Parliament and people on its deep divisions over the basis for developing Australia's defence and strategic policies. The deception is obvious. The editor of the National Times, Mr Brian Toohey, in the forthcoming week's edition of the National Times, the 6 to 12 April edition, at page 3 headed 'What Cabinet decided', sums it up fairly well in the first paragraph. As he has indicated in the overflow column, Ronald Reagan has got in ahead of us. He has written to him asking him to join forces, which is some force of support. The first paragraph of this story is worthy of quotation:

The Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, has broken new ground with his claim this week that a document can be endorsed by Cabinet without the Government agreeing with any of the policy descriptions contained within it.

The reality is that at page 4 of this document there is what is alleged to be the Cabinet's endorsement of the strategic basis paper. The secret Cabinet minute is set out in this document. Firstly, week after week there are leaks of matters of the highest order, the very basis of the Government's defence planning and the policies endorsed by it for the formulation of broader approaches in the field of defence and foreign affairs. Secondly, there has been the denial throughout this week from no less a person than the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) himself that there was any endorsement of these policies. What he said in this Parliament was not the truth. What he said in this Parliament was a lie. Let me remind the House of what the Prime Minister said in relation to this document. He said:
To the extent that a document of that title-
it having been referred to earlier-
was considered by Cabinet last year, it was, as the Attorney-General stated in another place on Friday-
I ask honourable members to listen to the next words-
simply endorsed-
It is no longer endorsed, confirmed or approved; it is simply endorsed-

by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence polices. As is well known, it is not a policy document, but to the extent that any policy prescriptions are contained in it, these were not specifically endorsed by the Cabinet.

We have established by the effluxion of a week's time that what was being denied this time last week as being an unauthenticated document is now authentic. We now have the publication of a secret Cabinet minute which starts by saying:
The Cabinet-(a) endorsed the strategic basis of Australian defence policy.

There is no evidence that this document was returned to the officials who formulated it with further query. There is no evidence that in fact there was any disagreement with it. There is no evidence that in fact anything other than an endorsement was given to that paper. We have known by oral testimony, so to speak, in the words of Air Marshal McNamara, that this document exists, that it has been endorsed and that he agrees with it. So we proceed another step. We have the lies and the deception earlier on about the document which has now been authenticated by extrapolation of verbiage of Ministers and by Air Marshal McNamara himself; beyond that we have the leaking of such highly sensitive material; and beyond that we now have the confirmation by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) during the week that this document was nothing more than a document akin to a road map to help one get through the streets of Brisbane. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has been such a joke in his conduct of foreign policy that we are, regrettably, virtually a non-entity in international relations today because he does not comprehend the firm elements of the paper that the Defence Committee put forward and that the Cabinet endorsed-a factor that cannot be overlooked.

I say bluntly that the material that was produced in the National Times last week, which appears to have been authenticated, could be endorsed by every honourable member on the Opposition benches. It goes to the heart of our international relations. It deals realistically with the scenario, globally, between the Soviet Union and the United States. As I said two days ago, unless one understands what one's global appreciation is, one will not get one's regional relations right. That is the reason why the Foreign Minister is wanting to pour cold water on the document. But the reason that the Prime Minister wants either to deny that the document exists or to deny that the policies have been endorsed is that he is fearful that certain people who proclaim themselves as men and women of principle on the left of his Party will reject the elements rightly endorsed by this Government. The deception is a deception not merely of this side of the Parliament or of the Parliament as a whole; it is a deception of all honourable members sitting here and a deception of the Australian people.

Members of the Government ought to come clean and say publicly what they have said privately-that they agree with what was in the document, they agree with the scenario put forward by their defence committee-and not obfuscate and lie over a period of a week as to, first, whether the document existed; secondly, whether they had endorsed it; and thirdly, whether they were going to treat it as anything more than a guide, a directory, through the roadways of Brisbane, as the Foreign Minister has said.

The strategic basis is a policy document. Let us not muck about. The policies that are contained within a basis that is put before a Cabinet are endorsed, rejected or questioned further. On this occasion they were endorsed. We say, properly so. But behind it all have been the lies and deceit of a government in not affirming that to the people or to its own Party. Where do members of the Government really stand on the question of non-proliferation, despite all that they have said? Where do they really stand in regard to the Western alliance? As I said the other day, if they accepted and endorsed what was contained within this strategic basis, they would recognise that their peripatetic role as a broker regarding Vietnam cannot stand up. They should recognise that we are part of the Western alliance, and recognise that the invasion of Cambodia was the invasion of a client of the Soviet Union upon a client of the People's Republic of China. If members of the Government do not comprehend the Sino-Soviet dispute or the global dispute, they cannot get that relationship right, and they do not get it right.

What we have is a further series of documents from a government that is chronically unable to retain the nation's secrets. Although the Prime Minister has accused the National Times of lying about the strategic basis paper, the truth is now out. It is now clear that the attempt by the Prime Minister and the Government to discredit this particular newspaper is a desperate effort to cover up what is rapidly becoming one of the most serious instances of Cabinet ineptitude and internal divisions that a government has faced in this nation. These revelations show that the statements of not only the Prime Minister but also the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in another place, attempting to disown the document, are little more than the circumlocution of men trapped by their actions. The fact is that that strategic basis paper was endorsed and was accepted by the Cabinet without question. An endorsement means just what it says . It was endorsed. It was confirmed. It was accepted and they sought to shuffle away from it. The tragedy of the sloppy simple-minded way in which the document was obviously accepted is reminiscent of other examples of disregard of the responsibility which a Minister of the Crown must carry in this country.

I wonder whether Cabinet engaged in a long boozy lunch before it passed the strategic basis paper through the Cabinet without so much as a whimper. We recall the wondrous event before that meeting. But to put it in the context of what these men were addressing some hours after we had won the America's Cup, it was the basis for our entire defence planning.

There are three Ministers in the chamber. They endorsed the step down the line to Australia obtaining nuclear weapons and they have not got the guts to say so. It ought to be a matter of deep concern, after a week of revelations of the ineptitude of the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), the conflicts between that Minister and the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Howe)-incidentally, they are also brought out in the further edition of this newspaper-and the lengthening string of specific blunders in defence and foreign affairs, that the nation now learns that the Government is in total confusion about where it stands on fundamental policy matters.

The fact is that the Hawke Government has no defence policy and it is incapable of formulating one. It leaves Australia rudderless in defence planning; of that there is no doubt. What we have now, in view of the Foreign Minister's rejection of the Defence Committee's strategic assessments is that there is no other conclusion to be drawn than that the Minister for Foreign Affairs has sought this week to reject that paper if one refers to what I mentioned before. On 3 April he compared the strategic basis document and the notion that it was endorsed for guidance purposes with the use of a telephone directory and a street map of the Brisbane area. Obviously we are faced with an ongoing struggle about the validity of strategic advice to the Government from its top bureaucrats.

It is a sad day when I come into the Parliament with revelations of the deepest magnitude so far as the defence planning of this nation is concerned. After a week of shuffling about and denials from the Prime Minister down as to whether the policy was endorsed, it is clear that that policy was endorsed. The document as a whole was accepted by the Cabinet and endorsed by that group. I said that the leaking of the document a week ago would certainly be the most damaging revelation in terms of our national intererst in my time in politics. From that moment on, people have sought not only to indicate disapproval with what was contained in the allegations but also to imply that there was no endorsement of policy. Today's issue shows that to be an absolute lie. In regard to the Cabinet decision I want to refer to two statements. On 2 April the Minister for Defence said:
The strategic basis document has never been adopted by any Cabinet as policy.
He went on with this extraordinary gobbledegook and said:

Policy statements are made by the Government and by Ministers and are publicly announced where it is appropriate to do so. The document, as has happened on each occasion when the document has gone before Cabinet in the past, is endorsed as guidance for the preparation of recommendations on defence policy.

The fact is that documents such as that relating to the defence basis have been returned by Cabinets before. Other Cabinets have shown more than a passing interest in what is to be the formulation and the basis of their defence and foreign affairs program. They have questioned them, sought further information and argued about them. That is a reality which we know about. We also know that the Prime Minister said on 2 April:
To the extent that a document of that title-
honourable members should listen to these words-

was considered by Cabinet last year it was . . . simply endorsed by way of guidance . . . As is well known, it is not a policy document, but to the extent that any policy prescriptions are contained in it, these were not specifically endorsed by the Cabinet.

What the Opposition is drawing attention to this evening, therefore, is, firstly , the leaking of the most fundamental assessment that the defence committee of this nation can make and the fact that it was endorsed by the Government; secondly, that the lies that the Government has maintained for a week that that document was not endorsed have been proved to be absolutely false, that it was accepted by the Government, seemingly without question; and, thirdly, that differences have been propounded by the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister simply to try to draw attention away from the fundamentals of this document.

Either members of the Left who are in this Parliament at the moment will have the guts to say to their leftist friends in the Ministry, 'Did you endorse this or not?' or there are grave ramifications for these men of principle. But not for me. I do not think there is a person on this side of the House who would not give warm endorsement to the document as we have read it to date. Not a person. If that is the case, why does the Government not endorse it also? It has endorsed it privately; why does it not endorse it publicly? How can one endorse but not endorse? I question how one can say they are not policies, as the Minister for Defence has said, when his very document said:
I shall present the policies outlined-
in this particular document-
in my public statements . . .

The reality is, therefore, that they are policy matters, as for years the matters addressed were to be the subject of policy documents, for the formulation of further material and policies and that there has been obfuscation and lying by this Government because it wants to keep the truth away from the Australian people. If one is honest in endorsing a document, why does one not tell the people? Why does one not tell the Parliament and why does one not tell one's own Party? It is because one knows the divisions that rankle. The Minister for Defence Support has revealed himself, for example, as one, like the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), who accepts the Judas money. Thirty pieces of silver or putting him into the Ministry will buy that man off. His attitude is: 'Give me an extra quid and I will forget about my principles. I will not even be dinkum with the fellows who elected me to Cabinet'. I do not give a damn for the espousal of leftist policies, but I give a damn for my nation and for what is contained within this document. I endorse what is in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Little Nell.

—Why does the Foreign Minister not have the guts to get up, for example? The poor little fellow. No wonder he was trampled on in the manner that he was 14 months ago. He did not have the guts to stand up for himself. He was rolled by a man who has twisted him to such an extent that the fellow who stood in here espousing an enlightened view of the world compares a strategic document with a Brisbane street map. The Foreign Minister ought to be condemned for the words that have come out of his mouth this week and for accepting without question matters which he is now questioning in public but which he had no courage to question in the Cabinet or in the parliamentary party. That is the reason-the denials that have occurred-why we seek to censure the Government for the misleading statements and the attempts to deceive the Parliament.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Speaker. There are two serious elements in this censure motion. The first is that the Government has endorsed, in private, the strategic basis paper which was presented to Cabinet on the morning after the America's Cup success. We all know of the euphoric mood in which all of Australia welcomed that victory. We all know the sleepless night we all enjoyed. We all know how the Cabinet, that following morning, must have considered the paper. But let us look at how it considered it and the endorsement that it was given. Secondly, and more significantly, we censure the Government because today's revelations in the National Times show that the Government endorsed the paper in private and denied it in public. We have heard this over and last fortnight. The divisions within the Australian Labor Party show the contrast between, on the one hand, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), who apparently will respond to this motion, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes). In a moment I will show honourable members what each of the Ministers has said.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to remember that the man who apparently will respond to this censure motion claims that he was not present on the occasion when this strategic basis paper was considered. Of course, his own permanent head is a member of the defence committee. This paper is prepared by a defence committee, not overnight, but after prolonged and close consideration of all the options that are presented to it by the Department of Defence and by the top security departments of the Government. The conclusions are reached and the paper is presented. The statement with Cabinet's endorsement is simply headed 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy'. There are no recommendations. It is called the ' Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy'. Cabinet endorsed that paper called the 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy'.

What has happened is that this Cabinet has endorsed the defence policy. The Foreign Minister, whose permanent head was a member of the committee that made the recommendations, had the opportunity to go back to Cabinet to seek its rebuttal. But no, what happened? It is only as a result of the publication in the National Times last week that we heard the Foreign Minister compare the article to a telephone book. No wonder the Left is leading, because that is where the mole comes from. I want to get to that in a minute. What the Foreign Minister has done is progressively try to disavow himself from the affirmation of Cabinet. What he has done is try to ensure that he has distanced himself from his Cabinet colleagues. What he has done is say that he does not trust the advice of the Chief of Defence Force Staff. What he has done is say that he prefers the advice of Des Ball of the Australian National University. What this man is doing in public is denying the principal advice of his Department, of the Defence Department, and of the top security agencies of this Government to Cabinet in a paper which he, through his permanent head, has endorsed. We have heard from the Chief of Defence Force Staff that the Foreign Minister has other advisers.

So the two elements are that first, in private, the Government has endorsed the strategic basis paper and, secondly, in public it has denied it. A third point is that the Foreign Minister and his colleagues of the Left are showing their true colours. That is what this motion is all about. The very thin facade of Hawke Labor is beginning to show itself in true colours. Let no one be mistaken; there is not unity on the other side of the House. We have the new centre left regime. We have the aspirant to the Prime Ministership sitting at the table. We have the man who we have all heard through the book entitled The Hawke Ascendancy, was stabbed in the back. This is his comeuppance. This is his big opportunity. He will show where the priorities to the Left lie. He will show the people of Australia just what sort of attitude he has towards the nation's defence.

What has really occurred in the Australian Labor Party is that somebody within the Cabinet has decided that he cannot wear the private endorsement of the responsible strategic basis paper which analyses properly, and with total responsibility, the defence situation this nation faces. So what has happened? Just as we know about the discussion in the car park, somebody has a relationship with Brian Toohey that mirrors the relationship with Eric Walsh that Mr Justice Hope said so much about. This is all about the left wing ratting on the Government; and well it might for the Government's views need to be very carefully looked at.

We need to know what was in the submission of the Minister for Defence. Let there be no doubt about it; on that particular day there was a strategic basis paper and Cabinet submission No. 392 from the Defence Minister made recommendations on its endorsement. Honourable members should just listen to what it says. The document states:
Cabinet's endorsement of SB83 is necessary to the defence review that I wish to conclude as soon as possible . . . No specific public announcement is required--
Of course not. Cabinet was going to keep it in private. Honourable members should remember that the left wing was not prepared to live with it. The document continues:

No specific public announcement is required, but I shall present the policies outlined in SB83 in my public statements on defence matters, and state our position . . . to the Parlaiment in late September/early October.

What happened is that through Brian Toohey the left wing said: 'Hey, whoa there. This is a responsible strategic basis paper. We are going to have to face spending money on the nation's defence. We will suddenly have to match up to the consequences of having an endorsement of a responsible assessment of the threat situation in our region. We are not going to be able to live with a rundown defence force that my colleagues first revealed in this Parliament early last week'. Of course, what has happened is that this Government is winding down the operative end of the Defence Force. Honourable members will remember that this Government has taken away Defence Force training opportunities; it has removed the fuel for ships to go to sea and the fuel for the aircraft for flying. Progressively over the last 12 months it has reduced the operational capability of the Australian Defence Force and the left wing is afraid that this document will require the Government to start spending money as it should. We find in this submission, first, that the position is not just as the Prime Minister has said. Honourable members will remember that he said it was simply a recommendation to Cabinet. He said that no specific endorsement has been given. He said that it is simply an endorsement for the purpose of developing defence policy. That is not what the decision says; that is not what the submission says .

The second interesting thing in the strategic basis paper in the National Times last week related to the comments regarding the whole field of nuclear capability. Honourable members will recall that phrase that developments relating to nuclear capability in countries within Australia's neighbourhood should be monitored in order 'to ensure that the lead time for Australia could be matched to developments in other countries should the Government so decide'. There is no mention of that in the Scholes submission, the submission of the Minister for Defence. There is no mention of that in any of the answers we have heard. We had a comment from the Prime Minister in the Parliament the other day. On page 1164 of the Hansard he is reported to have stated:
. . . nor has the Cabinet or any cabinet committee discussed the possible development of a nuclear capability by Australia.

That may be. But Cabinet has certainly discussed or should have discussed the question of developments relating to the nuclear capability in countries in our region. I wonder whether it was intentional or whether it was just by accident. In Cabinet decision No. 1265 there is no mention of the nuclear capability facet . I wonder why. Is that the reason the document has leaked?

What has happened is that the Government has now been revealed. It has endorsed a responsible submission and no Labor member is prepared to acknowledge it. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) consistently in this House has tried to walk away from it. The Minister for Defence has tried to move away, too. He said that the strategic basis document has never been adopted by any Cabinet as policy. He knows and acknowledges that earlier governments have looked at the stragetic basis paper and said 'No, we do not agree with it. We will send it back. We will get it changed.' The Minister for Defence said so himself; but not this Government. This Government endorsed the paper that was before it. No matter that Government members had been up all night, no matter that they were in the euphoria of the America's Cup result. The point is that this paper was endorsed; it was not changed; it was not sent back; the Minister for Foreign Affairs did not ask for it to be reviewed. The Minister for Foreign Affairs' permanent head was on the committee that decided it. The Minister for Defence's permanent head and the Chief of Defence Force Staff were on the committee that recommended it; the permanent head of the Treasury was on the committee; the permanent head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was on it. They endorsed it. Every one of those Ministers, if he acted in his job responsibly, should have known of the contents before it went to Cabinet.

It is no use the Minister for Foreign Affairs, like Judas, coming into this place consistently over the last week comparing the document to a telephone book . It is no good his talking about the fact that it was just something that could be distributed like any sort of public document and that it did not really count for anything. We all remember the headline, 'Hayden slams cornerstone of leaked defence paper'. Here is this Judas trying to say these things about a paper of which he was part and whose permanent head contributed to its preparation. If he is anywhere near exercising his proper responsibility, of course he should have known what was in it. It is no use his now saying he prefers Des Ball to Neville McNamara. Neville McNamara, of course, is the Chief of Defence Force Staff. He is the man who under legislation is charged with providing military advice to the Government. If the Government does not accept the advice it can send it back . But of course it did not reject the advice; it accepted it. What happened was that Government members had that meeting, they had a recommendation, and my colleague the Leader of the Opposition referred to it.

One has only to look at the title: 'Strategic Basis of Australia's Defence Policy'. There were no recommendations. It refers to Australia's defence policy. It was a Cabinet decision. There is no question about its just being recommendations, some waffly paper that does not matter. What this paper has done is to lay down responsibly directions that this nation's defence should take. What these Ministers are doing is walking away from the public responsibility for the private decision that was required of them. Not one of them now is man enough to acknowledge that he was privy to it before it went to Cabinet. Not one of them is man enough to acknowledge now that the Cabinet endorsement, which thanks to the National Times we can all now read, was given by that Cabinet. Now, not one of them is prepared to accept that he did not adequately consider the consequences of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty.

No one in that Cabinet is now prepared to accept that, within its terms, were provisions that related to our considering developments relating to nuclear capability in countries within Australia's neighbourhood. Why? Because this Government is trying hard to tell the people of Australia that it is the Government that it is not. Whether it is in defence today, whether it is in economic policy tomorrow, whether it is in health today, whether it is in any one of the other policy areas tomorrow, what Government members are trying to do is the thimble and pea trick. They are trying to persuade the people of Australia that they are a responsible lot of high-principled Ministers. These documents give the lie. These documents show that this Cabinet has considered in private, decided in private, and denied in public. Any government that is not prepared to stand by the principles that it should properly pursue is a government that does not deserve to succeed. This Government and these divisions within it are just the beginning of the end.

What is happening is that in the conclusion of the career of the now Minister for Foreign Affairs as Leader of his Party we saw the same knife in the back approach that has forever characterised Labor in opposition and in government. Thanks to Brian Toohey, we are beginning to see the end of this beginning. It is only a step towards the end it so rightly deserves, and I believe it is one that inevitably must come for a Government that cannot be honest unto itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) rather offensively has likened me to Judas, who at least had his price, which was 30 pieces of silver. The Leader of the National Party has established his price. He displayed that he was prepared to rob his father, down to the last brass farthing from his father's grave.
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to withdraw that remark. It is obviously offensive.
—If it is argued that it was not the last brass farthing, it can only be because the right honourable member did not--
—Order! The Minister will withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker. The Leader of the National Party, well known for his virtuoso appearances before the criminal courts and royal commissions of inquiry into improper conduct--
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. This is a debate about the defence and the security of Australia. This man is trying to divert it because he does not know what else to say!
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Tell us about defence.
—I will give the platform-
—Tell us about security.
—I will give the platform to the Western Australian basher if that is what he wants.
—That's a beauty. Tell us about defence. I am not frightened of you.
—I say, Mr Speaker. I have been threatened by the honourable member for whatever his seat is.
—Come on, get on to defence.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—I must say that these after- dinner speechs make extraordinarily slow progress after members of the Opposition have been charged up with bottled enthusiasm, or whatever it is, during the dinner break. However, if I could move on, the Leader of the National Party made a pertinent observation. He said in speaking to the censure motion that there were two serious elements which were deficiencies. They were quite apparent-the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). What a pathetic performance! What is the situation with which we are confronted? It is a censure motion on the basis of the latest edition of a newspaper. I suppose that the next censure motion will be on the then current issue of the Toorak Times. Is this what the Opposition has been reduced to? A scissors and paste job on the latest issue of some give-away newspaper? Is this the intellectual bankruptcy to which the Leader of the Opposition has been reduced?

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition performed the role of a reader here tonight. For God's sake, let us clean up this Opposition. Let us get it functioning properly. Let us put the rightful Leader of the Opposition in his place-Brian Toohey, not the reader, Andrew Peacock, who cannot speak for himself but who has to regurgitate and go round in circles saying time after time what Brian Toohey said. If the words are going to be the words of Brian Toohey, we might as well have his voice in the House leading the Opposition.

The Leader of the Opposition observed that I had been trampled on politically 13 months ago. It is true, quite obviously true, and it hurt. I trust that I recovered with sufficient dignity to maintain some respect in the community. I can only express the wish that the Leader of the Opposition displays similar dignity when he is trampled on in a few months' time. Being attacked by the Leader of the Opposition is like being savaged by a dead sheep, and there they are up the back, lined up like vultures, senators from the Opposition ranks, waiting to feed off the Peacock carcass. He was so bereft of any integrity, he was so deficient in any substance, that he resorted to misrepresentation totally and completely. For instance, he said that the Government was taking Australia down the road of a nuclear capability. What a desperate lie that was because the newspaper-and we do not acknowledge whether the report is correct or not--
Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to that in a second.
—Order! The House will come to order.

—I will come to that in a second. The whole attack has been based on a newspaper report. The man is so bereft of any integrity and fundamental decency that he even totally misrepresented the report. He said that we had endorsed a move towards establishing a nuclear capability for this country. That is a lie. Any man who makes that statement on the basis of a report in black and white, claiming that that report says it when it does not say anything like it, is obviously a liar. The Leader of the Opposition has established tonight that he is so desperate, with the pressures behind him, clinging on with a popularity rating--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, for God's sake; I would not have said I was the world's best when it came to smiling and winning with the public in the opinion polls, but I never stooped or dropped so low as he has. Whenever I slipped, I recovered. He just goes back and back and back. Talk about biological regression in the political field; this man is going to disappear through some sort of fundamental organ, the way he is going. Here is the National Times. There is nothing in the National Times-the strategic basis-that said that we should get a nuclear capability. There is nothing we did that endorsed that we would get a nuclear capability because in fact the report in the National Times does not even suggest that that was what the alleged report was all about. This is what it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Developments relating to nuclear capability in countries within Australia's neighbourhood should be monitored in order to ensure that the lead time for Australia could be matched with developments in other countries should government so decide.

I repeat: 'Should government so decide'. We made no such decision. I speak for the Government, after consultation with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and my colleagues in Cabinet, and I have consistently stressed our commitment to the non-proliferation treaty, to try to establish a comprehensive test ban treaty and a range of arms control measures, and have repudiated any such suggestion. I will say this for the Leader of the Opposition, no one will ever go broke underestimating his intelligence. The fact is he misrepresented it, and he knows it.

Let me make this point: The strategic basis report does not involve the endorsement of policy, as he said. Now I believe him in this sense, that when he says it does he is honestly stating a situation he believes to be correct; that is, in all those years when he was Foreign Minister he did things without realising he was doing them wrongly. At least when he came in here tonight and said that he believed that that was right when it was wrong he was being honest. But what a dope to have as Leader of the Opposition! Seven years as a Minister, and he was wrong every year and he did not know it. The facts are that the strategic basis report provides nothing more than a framework as a general guide on what might be the principles which would apply. It is subsequently an obligation--

TALK.START.PARA: —You endorsed it.

—We will come to that in a tick too. But it is subsequently an obligation on departments, under the continuing guidance of their Ministers to develop concrete policy items. They are accepted or rejected. They are refined in the process if that is appropriate. But there is no commitment to any concrete policy, not even one, as a consequence of the strategic basis report coming before the cabinet. Yet this man-can I say it? Will honourable members dispute with me when I say, this dope?-who leads the Opposition, says otherwise. What did he do while in government for seven years? He must have been the Rip Van Winkle of the Cabinet. No wonder the previous Prime Minister could forget about him.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the facts from Air Chief Marshal Sir Neville McNamara, a man respected by both the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party-that paragon of virtue and integrity, the man who has lectured us on honesty. It just shows what inflation will do to the value of a commodity these days. On 20 March, before the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, easily the most prestigious and, might I say, as far as I am concerned one of the most influential and credible committees anywhere in the parliamentary system, there was a hearing. Its Chairman, the honorable member for St George (Mr Morrison), asked this question of Sir Neville McNamara:
How relevant is an analysis of the strategic basis, particularly in a situation of low threat, in forming Force structure?
Then the honourable member for St George added:
In that context, how effective is it to formulate a force structure on the basis of a very imprecise strategic basis or threat analysis?
In response, Air Chief Marshal Sir Neville McNamara said:

You are quite right that the strategic basis in itself cannot be a clear pointer in definitive terms as to the sort of structure or the content of the Defence Force that we should have, but it does form the first step.

Neither the former Minister for Defence in the last Government, whose eternal achievement was to reduce defence spending-he now complains that we increased it by more than 4 per cent in real terms-nor the Leader of the Opposition, who was Minister for Foreign Affairs for several years in the previous Government, knew that. Air Chief Marshal Sir Neville McNamara said:
There can be various judgments stemming from the strategic basis as to where priorities and emphasis should be placed, and they do exercise some judgments as a result of that.

But what he makes clear is that this is nothing more than a very generalised document. So much for all the nonsense that has been going on here tonight from this desperate Opposition led by a particularly desperate Opposition Leader. The Leader of the Opposition accused us tonight of lying, of trying to deny that the report existed. No one denies that a strategic basis report exists. Confirmation or denial is another matter, and it was never confirmed or denied by the now Opposition when in government when its strategic basis or a whole range of other sensitive and crucial documents were leaked. I will waste no time on that. The Leader of the Opposition says that we will not confess that we endorsed the document. I will tell honourable members what the Prime Minister said of the Government in this House on 2 April:
. . . simply endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies.

That is exactly what is appearing in the National Times, right or wrong-with no confirmation or denial from me, for sound reasons always practised by previous conservative governments. What is in the National Times does not conflict with what the Prime Minister said here on 2 April. The third great point that the Leader of the Opposition made was that I made some reference to the strategic basis being like a road directory. Let me say this: When it comes to finding his way around politically, the Leader of the Opposition will need his directions in Braille. That is how blind he is to some fundamental facts. The Leader of the Opposition talks about the dishonour, the disgrace, the outrage the damage-he uses all of these extraordinary superlative adjectives in describing these matters. Because a leak has taken place, allegedly, the Government should fall; Ministers should go to the chopper.

What about the Opposition's own record? Did any of it members resign in 1976; did the Leader of the Opposition resign when he was Minister for Foreign Affairs and a confidential cable from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, giving an account of a discussion between the Canadian and Indonesian Foreign Ministers on Australia, Timor and Indonesia, was leaked to the papers? We all remember how extraordinarily embarrassing that was. He did not resign. Did he resign when the Cabinet document outlining Federal Government measures in the event of a nuclear accident was leaked in 1978? No! Nor did he resign in 1980 when despatches from the Australian High Commission in New Delhi, critical of the Indian Prime Minister, were leaked. He never resigned; he never withdrew as a matter or principle. The Leader of the National Party talking about anyone resigning as a matter of principle for improper conduct is as convincing as an alcoholic proposing to burn down breweries. We reject this nonsense from the desperate Opposition that is going nowhere except into reverse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard yet again the desperate efforts of this discredited Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to answer serious charges against the Government. Every time a situation requires a serious debate , what does this little man do? In this case, for over half the time available to him to rebut these serious charges, he stooped right down into his favourite position, in the gutter. Now he goes out of the chamber because he cannot take it. He uses personal invective against members of the Opposition. There is no substance in any of the Foreign Minister's response. What did he say? He took to the Opposition for basing its censure motion on newspaper reports. Let us look at them. At this stage I remind the House and the people of Australia of what the censure motion is. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for its attempt to-
(1) mislead the Parliament and people on the significance of its endorsement of the strategic basis paper, and
(2) deceive the Parliament and people on its deep divisions over the basis for developing Australia's defence and strategic policies.

Is there any substance to those charges? We did not have any rebuttal from the Foreign Minister. Let us look at what the National Times and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said. Let us all in this House remember the basis of the Prime Minister's so-called appeal to the people of Australia. The Prime Minister of Australia has built his position on assuming a mantle of truthfulness and honesty. He surrounds himself with this so-called aura, and so far one has to acknowledge that he has convinced the Australian people-so far, I say. Let us look to see whether this mantle, this aura of forthright honesty, can be sustained in the face of the clear evidence before the House and the people of Australia tonight. In the House of Representatives on 2 April 1984, this week, the Prime Minister answered a question from one of his colleagues, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand). He asked about nuclear capability and about the document entitled 'The Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy'. I quote this answer because it is important if we are looking at the claim of honesty and truthfulness which the Prime Minister carries around with him at all times. The Prime Minister said:

To the extent that a document of that title was considered by Cabinet last year it was, as the Attorney-General stated in another place on Friday, simply endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies.
Honourable members should listen to the next part. Listen to what this truthful, honest and straightforward man said:
As is well known, it is not a policy document, but to the extent that any policy prescriptions are contained in it, these were not specifically endorsed by the Cabinet.
I would like to read those words again because I think they contain the absolute gravamen of this censure motion:
As is well known, it is not a policy document, but to the extent that any policy prescriptions are contained in it, these were not specifically endorsed by the Cabinet.

That is what the Prime Minister said earlier this week. Let us look at the actual document endorsed by Cabinet. It was 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983 (SB83)'. Under the headline on the front page of this document are the words 'Timing and Handling of Announcement of Decision'. It then states:
No specific public announcement is required but I shall present the policies outlined in SB83-
I remind honourable members, yet again, that SB83 is the Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy-
in my public statements on defence matters.

Who will outline the policies endorsed by the Government? The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) will outline them. This Cabinet document was considered by the Cabinet. It was, I would hope, seriously considered; I would hope that it was taken seriously. I would hope that Cabinet was not too euphoric and that the Prime Minister had got back in time from his celebrations following the winning of the America's Cup. I would hope that the Cabinet, as was its proper role, considered this document very carefully. As we all know now, it endorsed it. The Prime Minister said:
. . . to the extent that any policy prescriptions are contained in it, these were not specifically endorsed by Cabinet.

There is a clear difference in those two statements-one, the document that we have here available to us; the other the statement by the Prime Minister. They cannot both be correct; one must be untrue. Either the Prime Minister is telling the truth and the document outlined in the National Times is not correct, or the document outlined in the National Times is correct and the Prime Minister is not telling the truth. This House and the people of Australia deserve and need to know the answer to that question. It can quite easily be outlined. If the Government is so convinced that it is right and that this alleged article in the paper cannot be sustained it should make the documents available because the only way in which the truthfulness of this Prime Minister can ever be trusted in the future is if this question can be answered. They cannot mutually stand together. We cannot have a policy document endorsed by the Cabinet and the Prime Minister saying that the policies in that document, the prescriptions contained in it, were not endorsed. Let us look again at the decision outlined in the National Times, decision No. 2165. It states:
The Cabinet
(a) endorsed the strategic basis of Australian defence policy 1983 as guidance for the forthcoming review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies

Here we have it again; the policies were contained in that document. The Minister for Defence is sitting at the table. I am very glad to see him taking part in a debate at last. The front page of his document, submission No. 392, stated:
No specific public announcement is required but I shall present the policies outlined in SB83 in my public statements on defence matters.

Perhaps the Minister for Defence will tell us which statement is correct. Is the Prime Minister's statement correct and the document alleged to be the Cabinet submission outlined in the National Times incorrect, or is that the correct document and is the Prime Minister telling a lie? We really do need to know the answers to these questions. The other question to which we need to know the answer is why this document and these documents were leaked in the first place. Why is there this tremendous division within the Labor Party, within the Labor Government, that would cause some member of that Party, some member of that Government, to take the action of releasing one of the most strategic documents ever to come before any Cabinet? Why would that person take the action of leaking that document to a national newspaper? I do not think the Prime Minister should have public servants spend too much time scurrying around trying to find out which department the document was leaked from. I think that would be a waste of time. I think the Prime Minister should concentrate on those departments and those ministerial offices that had access to the document in the first place.

We need to realise that there are very real and understandably deep divisions within the Labor Party. But what is contained in this document is anathema to many of its members, particularly those on the socialist Left. I am wondering how many parliamentary members of the socialist Left will defend the Government on this issue. I would like to see some of the brave new world people from the socialist Left stand up in this Parliament and defend the Government by saying that they agree with what the Government is doing. We hear not a word. I would like to see the honourable member for Melbourne stand up and defend the Government. We know what the honourable member for Melbourne thinks about the situation. Let me quote from the letter that the honourable member for Melbourne sent to his colleagues. This is what he thinks about Australia's relationships and about the good relationships we have with the United States and with countries in the Association of South East Asian Nations. Let me remind honourable members again of what he says in that letter because it has something to say about the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and his actions. The honourable member for Melbourne in a letter sent to all his colleagues says this :

The US . . . is practising its normal policy of isolating and undermining a country whose policies and attitudes it finds unacceptable. The ASEAN nations are supporting their own reactionary positions which keep workers in oppression, poverty and fear.

That is what the honourable member for Melbourne has had to say. He is nodding his head. I am glad to see him acknowledge that. That is what he thinks about our relationships with ASEAN countries and the United States. I asked the Foreign Minister-I am sorry that he is not in the chamber to give a better answer than the one he gave the other day-whether he would dissociate himself on his own behalf and on behalf of his Government from the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for Melbourne. Not a bit of it. The Foreign Minister, as is his wont, as he did yet again tonight, tried to make light of the situation. He tried to avoid it by making light of it, by suggesting that it was all a joke , and by pretending that he could not even remember the electorate that the honourable member represented.

These matters that are addressed in this series of documents have now seen the light of day as a result of their being leaked. I suggest that the leaks came not from departments but from ministerial offices. We all have a fair idea which offices they came from. How could any Minister or ministerial officer leak a document such as that, thereby putting the security and the good name of Australia at risk?

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—Did somebody say that Howe leaked them? I do not know whether that is right. How could they be leaked? I would not have any idea. We have been seeing more clearly day by day a disintegration within the Labor Government. Previously there were only two factions: There was the Right and the socialist Left. Now we have the emergence of a new faction-the Centre Left, led, of course , by that doyen of invective, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Now we have the Centre Left, thus introducing a new element of fragmentation in to the Labor Party. One of the leading members of the Centre Left, the Minister for Finance ( Mr Dawkins), at the National Press Club challenged the Left by saying that it should forget its opposition to the mining and export of uranium. What happens very shortly after that? Within a few days, the National Times suddenly finds available to it a document which would embarrass the Government and bring a great deal of difficulty for our relationships with other countries. I do not think that we can say that it is sheer coincidence that we have this embarrassment piled upon embarrassment by today's release of the Cabinet documents themselves-not the strategic basis paper, but the facsimiles of the Cabinet documents themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again that either those documents are incorrect and they are not a truthful fascimile of the documents which went before the Cabinet-they are either that and the Prime Minister did not lie-or they are correct-and this is the gravamen of the whole situation-and the Prime Minister lied to the people of Australia and this Parliament. If he lied to the people of Australia and this Parliament, as on the prima facie evidence he did, this censure motion, properly brought by the Opposition, should be endorsed by all of this Parliament and particularly it should be endorsed by members of the socialist Left within the Government, whose integrity, honesty and forthrightness will now be challenged if they vote against the censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the charges in this debate and having heard the Opposition's first three front-line lawyers-and I understand that we are about to hear the fourth-I do not really think that this motion was worth leaving a dinner with the Commander-in-Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, which I should have thought was an important engagement for Australia.
—You have got to come in here and tell the truth.
—That will disqualify me forever from joining the Liberal Party or the National Party. The House should take note of the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . mislead the Parliament and people of Australia on the significance of its endorsement of the strategic basis paper and deceive the Parliament and people on the deep divisions over the basis of developing Australia's defence and strategic policies.

We have just had one lawyer do what lawyers do in order to make their living- argue over semantics and words. In this particular case, he put before the House the argument that two contrary propositions can both be accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you taken silk, Michael?
—I thank the Minister very much.

—I apologise to the honourable member for Warringah. At least he is entitled to make the sorts of mistakes out of which lawyers make millions. In a number of instances in the speeches made so far, members of the Opposition purported to quote from a document. Here is another copy of the document that they can use when they come back. It is three weeks old, but it does not happen to be a Government document. It is a copy of the National Times. That is what honourable members opposite are quoting from, and they ought to know the difference. The honourable member for Warringah, in a broadbrush charge, said that we should not investigate all of those people who have had the document; that what we ought to do is look at Cabinet Ministers because they are the only people who would have a motive for leaking the document. That is what the man said. I assume that he also agrees that it was a Cabinet Minister who leaked the Department of Foreign Affairs cables from Jakarta, the Community Aid Abroad cable on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Morrison brief on his trip to the United States of America and the United Kingdom and the strategic basis document in 1976. In 1976 a strategic basis document was leaked. The coalition parties were in office and the then Minister, the honourable member for Warringah, says that no one else but a Minister would have leaked it. That is what he said in his speech. He said that one of the Ministers who was in the Government of which he was a member leaked that document, the national intelligence paper on the Soviet Union.
—How did it leak?
—Well, they were leaked in your time, Andrew.
—How did this one leak, mate?
—Your colleague says that only a Minister would have leaked them.
—I think he is right.
—You do? So you think a Minister in your Government leaked those other documents?
—No. I meant on this occasion it was leaked by your colleagues.

—Now you are equivocating. Now we know what it is. It was the public servants who leaked when he was in office. He could not trust them when he was in office but they are totally trustworthy when we are in office. His Ministers did not leak? What a lot of utter rubbish! This Government and I as Minister for Defence will treat this strategic basis document as it is.
—What is this?
—I thought you might be interested in this as your new policy document.
—Is it genuine?

—The National Times is genuine; there is no doubt about that. It is written on the front. We all believe that. On 30 March the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) was attacking the contents of the documents. He said that the document contained a requirement for the development of nuclear weapons. We all know that is untrue. Nevertheless the source is one from which we would expect that type of statement. Within a week the Leader of the Opposition was standing up, endorsing all the contents of the document. Neither of them has ever seen the document. They have seen the National Times, and there is a difference. Tonight we have had the most stupid and idiotic attempt to turn a basic document, which even the National Times says was endorsed for the guidance in the development of policy-
—Are you admitting it is the right document?

—I am not admitting anything. I said that even the National Times claims that. Even the National Times states clearly that the document which it purports to have states that it was introduced by me as a document for the guidance for future planning of defence policy. Even the Oxford Dictionary does not define 'basis' as 'actual'. That is what Opposition members are saying in this House.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker, is the Minister therefore claiming that the National Times document is a false document?
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I have not said that the National Times is a false document. I said that the Government neither confirms nor denies the accuracy of documents which purport to be security documents.
—What are you so upset about?

—I am not upset, actually. I am rather enjoying this because Opposition members are making fools of themselves. The question that has to be adked in this House is: On what basis did the former Government deal with strategic basis papers? Did it endorse them as the policy of the government, as it now claims they are, or did it endorse them as a basis for the future planing of defence policies?
—That is interesting.
—I can assure the honourable member that I read the document itself.
—That would have been hard. How long did you take?

—If the honourable member did not read such a document because it would have taken him too long he was rather negligent in his duties. He was the Foreign Minister and he had some obligations in that area. The Opposition has carried out what must be the most trifling and irresponsible series of attacks in order to undermine the standing and the competence of our defence forces and our relations with our neighbours over a considerable period. We do not have to look far to find out why. The Liberal and National parties are totally discredited in economic policy. They are unable to mount substantive arguments in this place or outside it to justify any of the matters which they put forward in this House. They have tried using newspaper articles, which no responsible person would do, to bring into disrepute or collision with the Government the Chief of Defence Force Staff, who did not make any statement in contradiction with me, the Government or the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
—Deborah Snow was wrong, was she? The National Times didn't get it right?

—If the Leader of the National Party is prepared to dispute the transcript as compared with a newspaper report it is no wonder that his credibility in this Parliament is so low. I am saying that the Chief of Defence Force Staff was not wrong in what he said and he did not contradict what the Government is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole thrust of the National Times articles was based on a contention that the Government was proposing to acquire or to get the capacity to acquire nuclear arms. That is not the policy of this Government. It has never been and never will be, although it is now suggested to be the policy of the Opposition. Nuclear capacities are not in the interests of the Australian defence forces. They would weaken our strength and our defence capabilities. That is agreed by our defence advisers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that? Substantiate that.
—Order! I give the honourable member for Hume a last chance on interjecting. I call the Minister.

—This Government will form its defence policies on the best advice available to it, on the policy considerations on which the Australian Labor Party was elected. It will maintain an adequate and proper defence force for this country and it has commenced doing that by increasing the funds available to defence in this Budget. After a period of total neglect and absorption of costs which should have been paid for outside the defence budget and a real fall in the defence budget in the year in which the Leader of the National Party took office as a Minister--
—Rubbish, Gordon.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—The right honourable gentleman is trying to hide behind the failed purchase of the Invincible. He is trying to suggest that the drop in real terms in the defence vote in 1981-82 occurred because the then Government bought the Invincible. It was because it absorbed a pay rise into the defence vote because the Treasury and the Government of the day would not meet the additional costs. Honourable members sitting opposite know that and I know that. Honourable members sitting opposite have even sought to blame this Government for actions which they took as positive policy decisions. They froze the acquisition of all but absolutely essential defence equipment in February 1982. They directed the Defence Force that it was not to enter into any contracts and it was not to meet any financial obligations that could be avoided. That is what they told the Defence Force in Feburary 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) told us the other day about boots. He did not even have the decency to talk to the commanding officer about the problem. He sat on it for weeks to try to make some cheap political capital out of it. I will tell honourable members what has gone on with boots. The former Government did not order any when it was in office. The shortages that he spoke about have been evident since 1979. That is how long the shortages in some sizes have been evident. Since coming to office--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I invite the Minister to address the questions that have been put to him.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Because of the incompetence or, more importantly, the deliberate sabotage of defence stores, there are currently 24,000 boots in stock. We have ordered another 92,000 to bring the stock up to what they ought to be.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable Minister's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That the question be now put.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the motion be agreed to. All those of the opinion say aye; of the contrary no; I think the ayes have it. Is a division required? The House will divide.

INTERJECT.PARA: The bells being rung-

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that the question now is that the motion be agreed to.
—The motion is that the question be now put.
—No, the motion was put and carried.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. It was not, Mr Speaker. We called for a division on the motion that the question be now put.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You called for a division after the question was put that the motion be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
