upon which Mr Hodgman had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

(a) its shameful and disgraceful action in seeking to remove Her Majesty The Queen from the oath of allegiance and the affirmation of allegiance, against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians, and without having first put such an important amendment to the people of Australia in a referendum,
(b) its deliberate devaluation of the importance of the honour of Australian citizenship, and
(c) its overall failure to consult properly with the people of Australia before bringing into this Parliament such radical republican legislative proposals'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said most of what I wanted to say the other day before debate on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill was adjourned, but I reiterate that this Bill is humane, reasoned and well in touch with Australian multiculturalism. This Bill is committed to ending discrimination on the grounds of marital status, sex, and present nationality. The changes to the pledge of citizenship reflect proudly our national identity, integrity and autonomy. The qualifying period gives the opportunity for new settlers to take part in this country's affairs as citizens within a reasonable time. It gives the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and it takes citizenship out of the way of political interference. It removes the sad enigma of Australia being the only Commonwealth country to continue to use the concept of British subject status in preference to its own nationality. Furthermore, it is in line with the opinion of the Australian people, despite the attempts of racial intolerance to stir up debate and division to the contrary.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed, but not surprised, by the attitude expressed by members of the Opposition to this Bill. Like the 1948 Citizenship Act, they are still basically entrenched in the mentality of immediate post-war Australia. The current Act is based upon the thinking of that day. It is based on the attitude of the White Australia policy, on the feeling that migrants and their culture should have been swallowed up by anglicised Australia. That attitude was that refugees from war-torn Europe had to prove that they were good enough to be real Australians. Times have changed and attitudes have softened, but the basic attitudes of the conservative minority section of Australia remain in some quarters. Thankfully, as we read the Zubricki report on the national consultation into multiculturalism and citizenship, we find that most Australians today seem to have a more humane, open and neighbourly attitude to our newer settlers.

It is worth noting that during the year ended 30 June 1982, 59,137 people renounced their former citizenship and took out Australian citizenship. As well as that, 1,779 people who were at that stage stateless now have the protection of Australian citizenship. Those 60,916 people came from 118 different nations. They brought 118 different cultures to our national mixing pot. They came from places such as Albania and Zimbabwe, Finland and Guatemala, Ghana and Vietnam. Instead of attempting to restrict the rights to Australian citizenship we should be pleased and proud that so many people from so many lands and cultures can live so peacefully together in Australia.

Australia can be proud of its multiculturalism. It can be proud of the attitude and spirit which was developed predominantly during the Whitlam years. Multiculturalism and racial tolerance should be cherished and encouraged. This Bill clearly embodies Australia's growing multicultural society. The amendments contained in this Bill will at last erase the regressive attitudes embodied in the old Act. Despite the racially intolerant attitudes of a minority, whose attitudes are contrary to current attitudes, it clearly represents Australian community opinion of 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1984 and to summarise much of what has been said from this side of the House during the past three days. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). If I may say so, I believe that he has been both fearless and consistent in his support of this Bill. Too little recognition has been given to the consistency displayed by the honourable member for Denison in regard to the whole question of Australian citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to respond to the statements just made by the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr Staples), who has accused members of the Parliament who sit on this side of the House of being insensitive to the wills and wishes of migrants. He said that 69,916 people chose to renounce their former citizenship and to become Australian citizens last year. I and every other member of the Federal Opposition applaud the decision made by those 69,916 people. I applaud the mixing of their cultures with ours. I am as pleased and proud as the honourable member is of the fact that they made that choice and I, too, am proud of Australia's multiculturalism.

The Opposition is endeavouring to act responsibly in assessing this legislation . It is not our intention-nor has the honourable member for Denison at any time suggested that it is our intention-to oppose all of this legislation. The honourable member for Denison has simply moved an amendment which, in fact, applauds the Government's action in doing such things as ensuring that there will be no discrimination on the grounds of sex or of marital status against those who elect to become Australian citizens. There will be an opportunity for those whose age prevents them from being fluent in English not to have to meet that qualification. We applaud that sort of flexibility. What we have said is that the acceptance of this amendment will allow us to be sure that the people who choose to become Australian citizens genuinely intend to be citizens of Australia, to be responsible and loyal citizens of this nation.

I have no problem at all in supporting some of what the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) said to this House in his address on this Bill. Let me read part of his speech to underscore my point.

Honourable members will agree that obtaining citizenship is a necessary prerequisite for full participation of an individual in the total social and political fate of any democratic country. Citizenship entitles a person to vote and stand for public office, to be employed as a permanent public servant or judge, and to hold an Australian passport. It means eligibility to act as a juror as required, and to be eligible for military service as required. Citizenship confers both rights and duties.
The Opposition has no difficulty with that at all. All we do is remind honourable members opposite of what was said by the honourable member for Melbourne; who said:
Citizenship confers both rights and duties.

What the legislation is doing is watering down the rights and duties to which would-be citizens of Australia pay allegiance. Effectively the legislation waters down the oath of allegiance as it exists by eliminating, if you please, recognition of the monarchy, by reducing the concept of honour to God and by reducing the time limit that we impose on those who intend to become citizens prior to their right to citizenship. All that we on this side of the House seek is an assurance of loyalty of would-be Australian citizens.

The honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) in addressing the House said that he believed that the pledge that currently existed was much too ambiguous. He accused the Opposition of supporting a pledge which he said forced people to be uneasy about the things that they were asked to renounce. It forced people to be uneasy because they were not sure what allegiances they were losing or forgoing. I maintain that that statement is nonsense. When we ask people to owe allegiance to our nation and to our Queen, we do not ask them to renounce their culture. We do not ask them in the present existing oath to lose all of their human characteristics. We do not ask them to lose their extraordinary gesticulations or accents or their personhood. We do not expect that to disappear. All we ask is that before we amend the oath we ensure that whatever oath exists makes some demand on people for loyalty.

The honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) said that a report had been handed down by the former Minister, Mr Hodges, and because that report had been handed down and made certain specific recommendations we ought to endorse them. What is this-government by report? I would have thought the role of the Parliament was to look at the options in a report and then make responsible decisions. My plea to the Parliament tonight is simply for responsible decisions in the area of the oath of citizenship that we offer. The honourable member for Burke dared to suggest that the Parliament had some sort of mandate, if you please, to do what it likes with the oath of citizenship. The honourable member for Burke dared to suggest that we were challenging the basic right to citizenship of people who would be citizens. I think that too was nonsense.

The honourable member for Burke suggested that the Government came into this House with a mandate. He suggested that the Government had a right to amend the oath of citizenship as it pleases, but he conveniently lost sight of the fact that even if the proposal before the House became law, the oath that is sworn by members of parliament will still be an oath that pays allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen. So the honourable member for Burke is conveniently sugesting that in Australia we will have two classes of people: Those who come into this House and swear one oath of allegiance and those who choose to become citizens and swear another. Why is that? It is because the only way we can change the oath that exists-the oath to which members of parliament pledge themselves-is by referendum. The honourable member for Burke knows, as does the Government, that such a referendum would be defeated. So rather than use the open door, the open technique of referendum, the Government chooses the back-door technique of claiming a mandate and is now bringing in two oaths of allegiance.

The honourable member for Burke has suggested that we are challenging the basic right of Australian immigrants to become citizens of Australia. The present situation does not deny anyone who genuinely wants to become a citizen the right to do so, and the Opposition does not seek to deny anyone, by its support of this amendment, that basic right. All we seek is loyalty; all we seek to establish is that those who would become citizens of Australia are prepared to be governed by this Parliament, to be subject to the judicial requirements and laws of this land, and that they be passionately pro-Australian. Of course we also seek that people who would become citizens of this country become subject to Queen Elizabeth, our Queen.

I remind the House that no other Western democracy has reduced the time scale for citizenship to three years, let alone two years. We will become the Western democracy with the lowest qualifying time for citizenship. Is that the act of a responsible government? I doubt it. I was particularly distressed to hear the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear) saying that because Her Majesty the Queen does not live in Australia, it is no longer appropriate for Australians to pledge allegiance to her. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) clearly and irrevocably said that the Pope also lives outside Australia but those who are of the Roman Catholic faith find no problem in pledging their allegiance. The other point I make is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not choose to live in South Australia in order to claim the allegiance of South Australians. I have never heard so shallow an argument as the suggestion that in order to owe any allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen, Her Majesty should live in Australia. The honourable member for Tangney went on to suggest that he meant no criticism of Her Majesty by saying that she did not live in Australia. I feel that that is the cheapest form of criticism that one could have levelled at her.

The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) made the very real point that more demands are made on people wishing to become citizens of the United States of America than we currently make on citizens in Australia. All too many people opposite have been anxious to say that we ought to adopt something more of the United States of America style of government. I remind them that if there is one thing in our nation that the people of the United States of America envy, it is the fact that we have an apolitical head of State, the fact that we have a system of parliament and judiciary that is founded on a person who can be independent. I am also forced to my feet to protest at the undemocratic decision to make God optional. I remind honourable members opposite that 81 per cent of Australians believe in God in some form acceptable to them. It is not the concern of this Parliament, nor is it a part of this debate, to decide what form God takes. All that we can do in giving Australians an opportunity to invoke the name of Almighty God is to allow them to acknowledge that there are mysteries that human beings cannot plumb; allow them to acknowledge that there is a level of human frailty. It is that measure of humility that is all too foreign to this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, like your speech.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Wakefield is making a very sincere and genuine speech. I ask you to control the rabble that is trying to disrupt him.
—Order! There is no point of order but I do ask honourable members to restrain themselves.

—I thank the honourable member for Denison for his support. The other point I wish to make is that this acknowledgment that there is some being superior to ourselves, no matter what form we believe it takes, is essential to real, unselfish citizenship.
—A point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. There is nothing in the legislation about taking God out of the oath of allegiance. The 'God' is still there for those who want it.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—I remind the honourable member for Macarthur that my understanding of the alternative oath and pledge is that we have now decided not to give people the opportunity, in the first instance, to invoke the name of Almighty God when they sign a pledge but to make that optional. I am suggesting that the majority of Australians would not use that as an option. The Opposition's concern is that this recognition, this essential humility, is now optional rather than the initial form of pledge that is taken. Let us acknowledge as a House that we have been the inheritors of a successful post-war migration program. As the honourable member for Wakefield I have in my electorate a vast number of people who have been successful post-war migrants. Indeed the fruit growing community in Wakefield would not exist as a viable community without them.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested that the migrants in Australia are confused by the present oath. I doubt that, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) doubts it and so does the honourable member for Denison. The reality is that we have 15 million homogenous people living in Australia and the majority of those migrants have pledged an oath of loyalty as it currently exists to Australia. We ought to ask ourselves what the present existing oath has prevented migrants or those who would be citizens from doing. What has our present existing Constitution, wisely framed as it is, prevented us from doing?

This evening all I have endeavoured to do in this place is defend the right of people to first be assessed as responsible citizens before citizenship is made readily available to them. I have sought to defend the right of people to have as a first option, if they wish, the invoking of the name of Almighty God in the pledging of an oath. I have sought to defend the right of Australians, who are governed under a monarchy, whose judicial system has the pillar of monarchy in it, to recognise the monarchy when they pledge allegiance to this nation. I have sought to defend the right of every new Australian to be a part of a proud and unique nation. There are things in this legislation which are necessary. Why soil it with divisive, weakening proposals? I can only hope that in another place wiser counsels will prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, a Bill which I wholeheartedly support. It is unfortunate that in the last few minutes and in the speech made by the Opposition spokesman on immigration, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), we have heard the last gasps of the defenders of the British empire. I would have thought that we would not have heard in this Parliament in the 1980s honourable members talking about loyalty and how we have to test the loyalty of people before they can become Australian citizens. That was the concept that we debated in the Parliament at the turn of the century. It was the concept that was flung against my grandparents who were emigrants from Ireland. The defenders of the British empire in those days were the people who said: 'Of course you would not want to let the terrible Irish become Australian citizens'. What we find in this Parliament now, fortunately, is that the Irish have indeed inherited the earth. The majority of the members of the Government can claim some sort of Irish background. However, the type of argument that was put in this Parliament tonight by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) was an echo of the arguments that were put at the turn of the century about how we have to test the loyalty of immigrants and how we have to see that they are not adherents of some foreign country. The honourable member for Wakefield, for the first time that I have heard in this Parliament, raised the sectarian issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Holding-I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the five years that I have been a member of this Parliament and the 20 years or so that I have been involved in politics in one way or another in this country I have not heard the sectarian issue raised. I thought it was dead. I thought it died when people tried to kick the Irish out of politics in Australia. But tonight the honourable member for Wakefield suggested somehow that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) was involved in a sort of popish plot by bringing this legislation into the House. I have always had my suspicions about the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, but I never thought he was involved in a popish plot. But tonight the honourable member for Wakefield suggested something like that.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I made no such allegations, as the honourable member is well aware. All I did was make a comparison between what had been said by honourable members opposite-
—There is no point of order.

—The honourable member can try to slide off it as long as he likes , but tonight in this Parliament the Opposition raised a sectarian issue. I think that is somewhat disgraceful. I and my colleagues on this side of the House are willing to welcome all and any who want to make Australian their home, and we are willing to facilitate those people to take up Australian citizenship. I find it abhorrent that members of the Opposition, those people who represent the last gasp of the defenders of the British empire, would try to prevent those people who were not from British stock from taking out citizenship of this country. I will advert in a few moments to some of the speeches made by some Opposition spokesmen on this matter. But I consider it somewhat offensive that tonight in the Parliament a member of the Opposition attacked people of the Catholic faith. I think that is beyond pardon.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. That is a deliberate misrepresentation, and I am a Catholic. It is a lie.
—Order! That is not a point of order.

—The truth hurts when it is put to them. I thought that the honourable member for Dension and the honourable members for Hume (Mr Lusher) would be taking the honourable member for Wakefield to task for the attack not only on members of this side of the Parliament but also on them.
—Why do they hate Catholics?

—Goodness knows why they hate the Catholics. The serious point I want to raise tonight is the Opposition's allegation that we are trying to make God optional. I know that the honourable member for Wakefield has not been a member of this House for very long and he may not know that, in talking to a Bill, one should look not only at the Bill but also at the Schedules of the Bill . For the edification of the honourable member for Wakefield I will read the first Schedule of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. The second form of pledge in that Schedule reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I . . . renounce any current citizenship and all allegiances to any State other that Australia. I swear by Almighty God that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfill my duties as an Australian citizen.
I do not think that makes God optional. That makes God very positive.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the second option.

—The honourable member says that that is the second option, because under the oaths Act an affirmation is provided for those people who do not subscribe to the Christian faith. If the Opposition wants me to name the members of the Opposition who took the affirmation instead of the oath of allegiance when being sworn in, we can recount the number of non-Christians in the Opposition. I think that is rather irrelevant, but anyone who wishes to swear the oath of allegiance can do so under the provision of the Schedule to this Bill. So to say that the Government has made God optional is a foul lie, a lie that has been reported by-
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw those words.
—I have not imputed anything against anyone, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to withdraw the words, please.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I would not wish to take issue with you on the Standing Orders. I think it is not possible--
—Perhaps the honourable member could rephrase his statement .

—I state quite blatantly that under the Standing Orders I have the right to say that it is a foul lie for the Opposition collectively to make an allegation. That is a proper statement under the Standing Orders.

—Order! I suggest to the honourable member for Grayndler that there have been contrary rulings on this issue but I think it would be wiser if the honourable member were to fall in with the Chair's request.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, in deference to you I will say that the Opposition is misrepresenting the position of the Government in the extreme by suggesting that the Government has made God optional, because the Schedule to this Bill specifically allows the making of an oath of allegiance. For the Opposition to suggest anything else is absolutely untrue. Let me turn to the amendment moved by the Opposition.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. Is the honourable member going to withdraw or not? You asked him to withdraw and he is now--
—Order! I asked the honourable member to rephrase his statement. He has done that.

—The truth always hurts these people when it is nailed on to them. I shall now deal with some of the specific and more difficult parts of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Denison, an amendment that I consider to be scurrilous in the extreme. The honourable member for Denison suggests that by this legislation the Government is removing reference to the Queen from the oath of allegiance. I have no doubt that the honourable member for Denison is not one of the better lawyers in this country. He obviously has not practised law for quite some time. However, I always was of the opinion that the honourable member for Denison had the faculty of being able to read. Quite frequently we hear him tell the Parliament what the Constitution is. I have no doubt that he has never read the Constitution. The amendment that he has moved to the motion for the second reading of this Bill proves that he has never read it. I find it rather dangerous that a person who is willing to quote the Constitution all the time has not bothered to read the first part of it. I refer the House to section 1 of Part I of Chapter I of the Australian Constitution. The first operative paragraph of our Constitution reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which shall consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is herein-after called the 'Parliament,' or 'The Parliament of the Commonwealth.'

The Parliament is made up of three elements-the Queen, the House of Representatives and the Senate. However, the scurrilous amendment proposed by the Opposition spokesman on these matters suggests that we have left out the Queen. What we are asking people to do is quite sensibly and sanely take an oath for Australia. We are asking them, as is set out in Schedule 1 of the Bill, to swear an oath faithfully to uphold the Constitution of Australia. Section 1 of Part I of Chapter I of the Constitution mentions the Queen, the House of Representatives and the Senate. No doubt the honourable member for Denison has difficulties with logic and with reading. Obviously he has difficulties with the law. Anyone who has any sense or understanding of plain English-the honourable member for Denison is the last defender in this Parliament of the British Empire -would see that the Queen is mentioned there. We are asking people to recognise that.

If anything has brought the Queen into disrepute in this country, it is the blatant politicisation of the monarchy in Britain by the Conservative Thatcher Government of that country, which sends the Queen of Britain traipsing around the world to make blatantly political speeches on its behalf. No doubt people in this country get rather concerned about making the distinction in relation to whether that is the Queen of Australia speaking, the Queen of Great Britain or the Queen of Northern Ireland. They have something of a problem about that. No doubt the honourable member for Dension would remember that when he was taught by the good nuns as a boy he was taught about the Blessed Trinity, which was something that we were told would be very difficult to understand. Many of our new immigrants to this country have great difficulty in understanding the concept that the lady who stood up and spoke in Jordan last week was not talking on our behalf.

We have made the oath simpler. We have said: 'You will swear a straight oath to the Constitution of Australia; you will call upon God to recognise you swearing that oath; and that will satisfy the proposals under this legislation'. That makes it a lot simpler and much more understandable. In my view and, I am sure, in the view of my colleagues, it is a lot more Australian for us to do that.

A number of other proposals are put forward by the honourable member for Denison and by the honourable member for Wakefield. They said that they thought we were devaluing Australian citizenship by reducing the qualifying time from three years to two years. Of course, they would prefer to make it law that a person had to be here for 100 years, and probably dead, before he could become a citizen. If they had their way, they would like only these people who were second or third generation Australian-born to have the right to be citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is racist.

—That is quite true. But what we wish to do is to make it easier for all those who have chosen to make Australia their home to become citizens. The honourable member for Dension said that it was something terrible that we were repealing a section of the Act that said that all those people who were British subjects in 1949 in this country would no longer be able to say: ' Tomorrow I want to become a citizen'. They have had only 35 years in which to make up their minds whether they want to be citizens. There are 1.2 million people in this country who are able to become citizens but who have not chosen to become citizens. I find it offensive that 1.2 million people living in Australia have chosen not to become citizens but wish to have all the rights and privileges that go with living here. But the honourable member for Dension wants to say that anyone who can claim any sort of British stock can have the right of citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, we are the last country in the world that says that. Many years ago, even the Old Dart decided that that was not on. The honourable member for Dension travels around the world quite frequently. I would bet my life that the last time he was in London, he got in the queue at the Customs barrier under a notice that said 'Aliens'. If one is an Australian citizen in Britain, one does not get in the queue for British subjects; one gets in the queue for aliens. Even Britain, the old home country the honourable member for Dension wants to hark back to, does not now accept people from the Antipodes back into its bosom. I think it is a little unfair and offensive to extend a privilege that we have extended for 35 years and allow those people to make up their minds, but to say to those who have chosen to come here and make this country their home that they should wait for longer than two years to become citizens. It smacks of all sorts of paternalism. That is the last sort of thing we should be seeing in this country in the 1980s and as we go into the latter part of this century.

The honourable member for Denison also says in his amendment that we never consulted anyone about these changes, that we never talked to anyone. Once again , the honourable member for Denison obviously does not listen in his own party room. We have found tonight, by looking at his amendment, that he cannot read and he does not understand the law. But he was obviously asleep in his party room when his colleague the previous member for Petrie canvassed the issue. Unfortunately he departed the Parliament following the last election and does not represent that seat in this House now. He was a very pleasant man but his politics were a bit suspect. We now have, politically speaking, a much better member for Petrie in this House.

But Minister Hodges in 1982 introduced proposals to change the Citizenship Act. I have no doubt that he canvassed that in the Liberal-National Party party room. The honourable member for Denison was not listening and he obviously did not understand what his predecessor was doing. There has been widespread debate regarding these amendments to the Act. They were introduced by the Government last year and have lain on the table for quite some time so that everyone knows what we are doing. The amendments we are making to this Act have been applauded by people right across this country. The only people who do not like it are the dying monarchists who do not represent anything in this country except the sordid past.

In the short time left I would like to mention a couple of the positive points of the amendments to this Act. In particular, I congratulate the Minister for his amendments to the language requirement in this Act. For many years, in my electorate of Grayndler, which has one of the largest portions of new migrants in Australia, I have been quite concerned at the position in which migrant women have been placed in Australia vis-a-vis the immigration laws. The language proposals of the previous Immigration Act discriminated against older migrants and migrant women. There have been a number of studies by the Institute of Family Studies which have highlighted the plight of migrant women in Australia and their difficulties in receiving naturalisation and becoming citizens, along with members of their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been asleep. We support that amendment.

—The Government had instituted these amendments. The honourable member for Denison says the Opposition supports them. It is a bit late! Members of the Opposition should have done something when they were in government. They are very supportive now of many things that they knew about at the time but had no intention of doing anything about. The present Government is dragging these people out of the 1950s into the 1980s. Migrant women are very strongly discriminated against under the Act. Those migrant women who spend their lives at home, maintaining their children, do not have many opportunities to learn English. Those who are forced to adopt a dual role of both mother and income earner are normally employed in occupations where there is little English spoken . They do not have the time after work to go to English classes. The Minister has quite rightly reduced the language requirement. I hope, and I know, that the Minister has in mind extending the English language classes that are taught to new citizens--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: East Burwood Headquarters-Sovereign State of Aeterna Lucinda-Death of Mr Frank Doyle

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Holding) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Broadcasting Corporation is in the process of abandoning its East Burwood Victorian headquarters site after years of planning and considerable expenditure when 80 per cent of the Melbourne staff have moved to that part of Melbourne to be close to this facility. It will be at an addditional cost of about $2m per year. The basis of my concern is the proposal that the ABC has or is about to place before the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works a proposal not to proceed with stage 2 of the East Burwood site but instead to look for a central city location which will, amongst other things, destroy 10 years of development and planning at east Burwood to centralise the hereto dispersed location of the ABC around Melbourne. It will delay the already overdue provision of better facilitities by at least another several years; isolate Radio Australia at East Burwood, contrary to the expectation of those personnel that they would be joined by the other ABC staff; destroy the finalised plans for the site prepared by the Department of Housing and Construction task force; destroy the whole concept which began 10 years ago with the purchase of the East Burwood site, and delay the provision of new facilitities for ABC staff and with it the opportunity to install new equipment, have better working conditions, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: The new proposal is contrary to the instruction of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) in February this year, when he stated that government departments and authorities had been required to save money by, amongst other things, moving their offices from central city locations to the suburbs because it was not only cheaper but also closer to the homes of the employees. This brings me back to the original criticisms of this new ABC proposal. First of all, when a site is found in central Melbourne, it will cost about $2m a year more, as well as the waste involved in the forward planning, the wasted value of East Burwood, and so on. Even more important is the effect it will have on ABC staff in Melbourne, where for 10 years they were told to move to the suburbs around East Burwood because that is where they would all be housed. Eighty per cent of ABC staff responded by moving to or concentrating in that area. Now all of this is to be contradicted. All the effort, the cost of moving, the dislocation of families involved, et cetera, is to be wasted.

One could ask: 'How could we have an efficient ABC headquarters in the suburb of East Burwood?' The point is that there would still be facilities in the central city and that, together with new technology, would make this the most efficient and appropriate place. I call on the Public Works Committee to reject this proposal and I call on the ABC to think again about a proposal which is contrary to planning, cost benefit, ministerial instruction and the welfare of a large number of employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to talk about matters that some people would call treason. I think it is beholden on members of parliament when presenting petitions in this House to have regard to what they present. For my own part, while I would willingly table petitions with which I do not personnally agree, I would not agree to table any petition that was subversive, divisive in the community, or had all the hallmarks of a confidence trick. Mr Doug Anthony, the then Deputy Prime Minister of this country, on 10 October 1978 presented a petition in this House calling for the establishment of the sovereign state of Aeterna Lucina. The petition will be found on page 1592 of the Hansard for that date. It called upon the Commonwealth Government to recognise the sovereign powers of this entity, bestow upon it the same privileges that the Vatican State enjoys in Europe, and convert its de facto status, which he said existed then, to formal recognition. That, I believe, was a terribly irresponsible act. It is laughable to hear these people, who would give away parts of Australia, lamenting the reality of Christmas or Cocos Islands in the event of an attack on this country. It just shows the pure hypocrisy of their motives.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask honourable members to contemplate the irresponsibility of this act. Some people would call it unpatriotic, some would call it treasonable, I would call it foolish. It must be said that the then Deputy Prime Minister certainly looked the part. This Gilbertian character, who apparently believed in praising every century but this and every country but his own, was quite prepared to put forward the claims of the German gentleman, Dr Neuman, the self-styled Lord of the Knights, Dreamer of Dreams, and several other titles which he apparently bestowed upon himself.

In brief, this was the situation. This gentleman acquired 3,000 acres around Cooma in the mountains for $24 an acre or thereabouts. He then set out to subdivide it and sell it off in building lots at $3,000 per quarter acre block. All sorts of stringent regulations were bestowed on them. I have the full documentation here. There is a declaration of independence, his constitution and even a building code, if you please. This gentleman was quite successful in selling some of these blocks overseas at these exorbitant prices. Of course, when he sold them he bestowed them in the title of the sovereign State of Aeterna Lucina. I think literally translated that means 'Heavenly Light'. He had a torrens land title from the State of New South Wales. Many people were duped into going there.

He had letters from various Liberal members and, in fact, Ministers at the time . The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) who was, at that time, a Minister, replied to him. I have a copy of a letter here. It is in very friendly terms. The letter itself does not have much significance, but when we see what he is replying to, and bearing in mind that the petition had already been tabled , the honourable member for Warringah was obviously involving himself in the dispossession of 3,000 acres of this country. He was lending himself to what was obviously a fraudulent confidence trick. I have spoken to the honourable member for Warringah about this in passing. He still applauds the actions of this gentleman.

What has happened is that people in Europe were told that they should come to Australia and that Dr Neuman had special friends in the then Government who would provide him with preferential treatment in terms of immigration. These people were to come to Australia on visitors' visas and then walk across the border into his sovereign State where he would bestow upon them citizenship of this new fair land, which was, of course, only a figment of his imagination. It is rather sad that this is probably the only country in the world where we would willingly give away pieces of our land. This gentleman, in his evidence for its existence, says that when the same trick was tried in Germany, the might of the German Army descended on him in three days. The Government did not bother with the police force in Germany; it sent the Army. But here we have these paragons of virtue, these hypocrites of the first order, prepared not only to table in this Parliament petitions pleading that we give away parts of this country but also to assist actively in the dispossession of this land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to record my respects to the family of Frank Doyle, the former member for Lilley, who died in Brisbane on 13 March at the age of 62 and to pay tribute to Frank. Frank was the Federal member for Lilley between 1972 and 1974. He won the seat from the former Federal housing Minister, Mr Kevin Cairns, by 35 votes which was, at the time, considered one of the closest Federal poll results in history. Mr Cairns was the only Queensland government member to lose his seat in that Labor victory.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to his election to parliament, Frank was State Secretary to the Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen for more than 14 years and was also made a life member of the union. He was appointed as Queensland's first Director of the Trade Union Training Authority in 1974, a job he held until his death. Throughout a long and outstanding career he contributed greatly to the Labor movement and promoted the trade union training schemes throughout Queensland. He held many executive positions within the Australian Labor Party, including membership of the Queensland Central Executive.

Frank was valued by me as a family man whose sympathies lay with the underdog. His sudden death has saddened all those people who are associated with the Labor movement who knew Frank as a loyal and generous man. He is survived by his wife Eileen, eight children and 16 grandchildren.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I was making before I was interrupted is that people have been inveigled into coming to this country. Whilst it may seem amazing to people in Australia that people in Europe could be seduced into coming to Australia with this sort of tale, they should realise that in Europe one is faced with the Liechtensteins and Monte Carlos and-
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may be extended until 11.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the contribution of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) tonight on the East Burwood Stage 2 development by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I assure the honourable member for Murray that this matter causes honourable members on this side of the House considerable concern also. Many representations have been made to me by members of the Government. In fact this matter has been discussed by the communications committee of the Caucus.

SPEECH.PARA: As was indicated by the honourable member for Murrary, the East Burwood project was commenced as a means of rationalising accommodation for the ABC in Melbourne . Stage 1 was completed in 1982. Previous government approvals covered Stage 1 of the project. Following recommendations of the Board of the former Australian Broadcasting Commission in November 1983, I agreed to seek approval for Stage 2 of the project. In fact, on 18 November 1983 I wrote to the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) seeking his formal approval to refer the matter to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. The Board of the new Corporation has now advised me that it wishes to defer Stage 2 while it re- evaluates the project, but no final decision has yet been made.

On 10 February, the Assistant Managing Director of the ABC wrote to the Department of Communications advising that the ABC had decided to seek deferment of consideration of the project by the Public Works Committee. As indicated by the honourable member for Murray, the Board had called for options for the East Burwood development, as well as options involving sites in the South Melbourne area. This decision apparently reflected some concern of the Board about providing prompt news and current affairs coverage from a location relatively remote from the Melbourne central business district.

It should be emphasised that the Board's decision comes very late in the day. Stage 1 of the development at East Burwood is complete and there is a government decision to proceed with the development of Stage 2. On 2 March I sought from the ABC detailed reasons for the deferral. I must say that I found the response of the ABC unsatisfactory. It is necessary to pursue the matter further with the ABC. I can assure the House that the appropriate papers on this matter are in the course of preparation.
House adjourned at 11.04 p.m. until Tuesday, 1 May 1984, at 2 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 10 November 1983:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Aboriginal Art Works and Artefacts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 7 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Mr Adrian Dolman, a Victorian Art Collector is acting as an agent for the sale of a large collection of (a) Aboriginal art works with an estimated value of $300,000 and (b) Aboriginal artefacts with an estimated value of $100,000 in the United States of America.
(2) Who are the owners of these two collections and can he assure the Parliament that they do not contain any sacred objects that should be retained in this country for the Aboriginal community.

(3) Does the sale of the collections contravene (a) the wishes of the Aboriginal community to keep major collections of Aboriginal arts and crafts in this country and (b) the intentions of the Government regarding the sale of Aboriginal arts and artefacts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On the information available to me, I am unable to say whether Mr Adrian Dolman is acting as an agent for the sale of the collections of Aboriginal artworks and artefacts in the United States of America referred to by the honourable member, who the owners of the collections are, or details of the content of the collections. Government policy is that sacred objects be returned to their traditional owners.
(3) (a) If the honourable member can provide me with further details about the collections, I will be able to advise him on this matter.

(b) Under the Second Schedule of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, the export of archaeological and anthropological material derived from or relating to Australian Aboriginals is prohibited unless the consent of the Minister for Industry and Commerce is first obtained.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: New Parliament House: Use of Australian Slate

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 1 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Is Australian slate being used at any stage during the construction of the New Parliament House; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not currently proposed to use Australian slate in the construction of the New Parliament House.

It was originally proposed to use Australian slate as flooring in the main public galleries and pedestrian links in the building. However, tests carried out on several Australian slate samples indicated they were unsuitable for this type of usage. The tests indicated the slate had a low resistance to abrasion making it unsuitable for a building of this kind which has a long projected life and heavy use of floor areas.
It is proposed to use Australian granite in these areas instead of slate because it has more durable qualities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Assets Test: Staff Engaged by Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many additional staff were engaged in the Minister's Department, in both its national and branch offices in the Australian Capital Territory, to administer the Government's proposed assets test.
(2) In what specific ways will staff in the ACT now be usefully utilised until the Government's intentions in relation to the assets test are clarified.
(3) If staff are to be transferred to other departments, to which departments will they go, and what will be the specific duties undertaken.
(4) If staff are to be absorbed within the Department of Social Security by postponing recruitment, what duties will the staff be asked to undertake, in the meantime, to keep them usefully occupied.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 7 March the Department had 65 staff working on the income and assets test in the ACT. These staff were deployed as follows:
Central Office
Assets Test Secretariat 4 Benefits (policy & legislation) 7 Systems & Operations development 19 Training 16 Secretariat and Information 1 Accommodation and Services 1
ACT Regional Administration
Co-ordinator 1 Training 1 New recruits 15
Grand Total 65
(2) Until the Government's intentions in relation to the income and assets test are clarified the above staff will be employed as follows:
Central Office

Assets Test Secretariat: Two to remain on assets test matters, one transferred to the ACT Regional Administration to undertake a special project related to reconciliation of the ACT advance account, one to work on systems and operations development matters.
Benefits: Staff will continue on current duties until 6 April 1984 and then be redeployed to work on normal benefits/policy administration matters.

Systems and Operations development: Staff will continue systems and operations design on basis of existing legislation but concentrating on elements that would be common to any assets test. The team is also working on amendments to current systems, identified as essential, prior to the administration of an income and assets test.

Training: Four staff have been redeployed to the ACT Regional Administration to clear up workload backlogs, six are involved in the development of and advanced pensions examiner course, two have been redeployed to help clear backlogs of ministerial correspondence, one will continue to work on assets test training material, one has been transferred to management training, one to assist with STRATPLAN implementation, one position is no longer filled.
Secretariat and Information: This officer has been assigned to a project dealing with a review of procedures concerned with client identification (proof of identity).
Accommodation and Services: Accommodation work will continue.
ACT Regional Administration

The assets test co-ordinator has been redeployed to clear a backlog of staffing matters, particularly staff selections. The training officer is now engaged on general training matters within the Administration. The 15 new recruits have been absorbed into normal regional office work.
(3) No staff will be transferred to other departments.

(4) Because of high staff turnover rates and the flexibility allowed under average staffing arrangements the 15 new recruits taken on in the ACT Regional Administration have already been transferred to normal departmental programs to which the ACT Regional Administration would otherwise have needed to recruit. They are no longer regarded as assets test staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 27 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Government's program for effecting an Act of self-determination for the non-self-governing Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
(2) What questions will be put to the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in respect of their self-determination.
(3) If one of the proposed questions includes an offer of integration with Australia, will alternative proposals to that arrangement be advanced, or will no one particular proposal be submitted.
(4) Is there any substance to the suggestion that integration with the Northern Territory may be proposed.
(5) Have discussions taken place with the Northern Territory Government on this proposal.
(6) What greater association would the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have with the Northern Territory rather than, say, Western Australia.
(7) Do all persons born on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have Australian citizenship.
(8) How many people born on Cocos (Keeling) Islands have settled in Australia, and in which States or Territories.
(9) Will Mr John Clunies-Ross and his family be eligible to vote in any questions of self-determination.
(10) Will an Act of self-determination be effected before or after legal proceedings for the acquisition of the home and curtilage of the Clunies-Ross family is completed.
(11) Will Mr Clunies-Ross be asked to leave the Cocos (Keeling) Islands before or after the Act of Self-Determination is affected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An Act of self determination will occur on 6 April.
(2) The people will be asked to choose between integration with Australia, free association with Australia and independence.
(3) See answer to question 2.

(4) No. In the event of a decision in favour of integration with Australia, the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands will not be integrated with the Northern Territory. Both Territories will retain their separate identities. However the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands will be included in the Northern Territory Federal electorate.
(5) Yes.

(6) Inclusion of the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in a Western Australian electorate would require an amendment to the Constitution involving a referendum. Attachment to the Northern Territory electorate which does not involve change to the Constitution, is the preferred solution.

(7) All persons born in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands on or after the transfer of the Islands to Australia on 23 November 1955 are Australian Citizens. Under the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act, as amended, persons who were ordinarily resident in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands immediately before 23 November 1955, who now are ordinarily resident in Australia or an external Territory and who wish to take up Australian citizenship may do so by making a declaration to that effect. Almost all Cocos Malays in the Territory are now Australian Citizens.

(8) The 1981 Australian census shows 494 people whose place of birth is the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. These are known to be resident in Western Australia with some possible exceptions. The 1981 Christmas Islands census shows 32 people in the Ethnic Group: Cocos Islander; Cocos Malay.

(9) Mr Clunies-Ross and his wife are eligible to vote. The question of whether his son, John, and his daughter-in-law are eligible to vote is a matter that will be determined by a committee of appeal set up under the Referendum (Self- Determination) Ordinance of the Territory of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
(10) The Act of Self-Determination will occur before legal proceedings for the acquisition of the Clunies-Ross property on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are completed.
(11) Mr Clunies-Ross will not be asked to leave the Territory before the Act of Self-Determination is effected. The remainder of the question is hypothetical.
